content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												It took me 125 hours to complete this game (all side quests and DLCs included)! Well, that perhaps is no match for Elder Scrolls, but, still, it's a lot of content!What looks and starts as just another ARPG, soon turns into immersive and beautiful open-world experience with overwhelming number of quests. And the cartoonish style is actually very beautiful, when you give it a closer look! The variety of landscapes and details – just exploring the game's world is rewarding on its own. (Take a look at my screenshots and you'll know what I'm talking about).I believe it would be fair to say that, "Kingdoms of Amalur" is "Skyrim meets Mass Effect"... just without sexy lesbian shower scenes... and without choices that actually matter. Well, about that... Choices - this aspect is actually one of the minor faults of this game. It gives the impression that you have to make moral choices that will affect your future, but (apart from few barely significant exceptions in some of the side quests) all those choices change is, whether you accept a sidequest and how the NPCs answer you. They don't affect the main storyline and don't lead to alternative endings - there are no alternative endings. On the other hand, you won't be regretting anything and wishing that you had done something differently.Especially because you can change your class (!) at any point in the game and redistribute your skills and abilities ("skills" are boosts to your stats in this game and "abilities" are your class-specific skills). And, in this aspect, KoAR is rather unique. There are 3 traditional classes in this game: rogue, warrior and mage. Also, you can combine any two of them or all three of them. This system reminds me that of Mass Effect. The only difference is that your choice is not fixed in the beginning, but you specialise your character in one of the three directions with each next level.What else? Loot. There's a lot of it! But only few items are actually worth something - as always in this type of games! But, contrary to Borderlands, for example, you won't be spending as much time sorting your inventory. Just put everything you don't need to junk right away. Then you can sell it or salvage to craft new items.Crafting, exploring, potion brewing, lore stone searching (they grant stat boosts), side quests, faction quests (they grant valuable rewards in the form of cards), appearance customisation, improvement of your headquarters – there is really a lot of content in this game. And that might feel overwhelming sometimes. You just grow tired of this game, especially because at one point this game stops being challenging even on the hardest difficulty. And the enemies and battles start to feel the same. You just want to find out how everything ends. But it just doesn't. This game takes for what feels like an eternity.My suggestion is to take breaks from time to time. Thus, when you return to it, it will still feel fresh.Don't ruin the experience for yourself! Because the story is rich and interesting, the combat system is versatile, the skill trees are complex, the numerous kingdoms of Amalur are beautiful, the sidequests are unique (well, most of them), there are various factions of enemies and the game itself offers immersive fantasy adventure experience that will take you hours to complete.If only the graphics were more realistic, the enemies were more challenging towards the end and there was no level cap (=40), this would have been the perfect game for me.Nevertheless, 10 EUR well spent.My overall rating: 9/10

number of helpful: 52 of 75 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												What a disappointment. I wanted to like this game, I really did. I read that it was a decent RPG with good game mechanics and pretty graphics. However, in my experience, the most the game could muster from me is one giant "meh."To start, the good points: Combat in Kingdoms of Amalur is by far it's best feature. Combat is fast, acrobatic, and exciting. Taking down mobs of enemies with a variety of weapons while dodging and firing off magic spells is an absolute highlight of this game. Controls are responsive and intuitive. Boss fights can be thrilling. The voice acting in the game is definitely above average, if not very good. The main story quest (from what I got through) seems interesting. And the game definitely looks pretty, albeit more on the cartoony side than the likes of The Witcher or Skyrim (although that's not necessarily a bad thing.) Overall, what I read initially is not untrue; this is a decent RPG, good game mechanics, and looks pretty good.Unfortunately, that's where the positives end and the disappointments begin.Most glaring is, lest you be fooled, Kingdoms of Amalur IS NOT AN OPEN WORLD ENVIRONMENT. It is a series of corridors arranged in such a way as to give the illusion of one. Resource placement within this corridored environment is lazy, with resource generating plants conveniently located periodically along the periphery of said corridors. The side quests are similarly lazy and primarily consist of fetch quests (go and kill these guys, bring me back my ring. Collect a bunch of ingredients for potions to save the town, bring them back to me.)Also, if KoA came any closer to straight ripping off elements of Skyrim and the Elder Scrolls series of games, I think we would have had a lawsuit on our hands. Equivalents of the Fighter's Guild, Mage's Guild, and Theives Guild? Check, check, and check, Strikingly similar lockpicking mechanism/mini-game? Oh, you betcha. Alchemy, Blacksmithing, and Enchanting requiring specific workstations of each? Bingo. Hidden traps represented BY BEAR TRAPS, actuated spike tiles, and trip wires which set off various nasties. Yup. (I mean, the bear traps might have been the last straw for me).KoA also suffers from trying to cram way too much weapon and item variety into the game than is necessary. The result is the player being positively overwhelmed by the sheer volume of useless crap you pick up during play. Luckily, it provides a convenient and free fast travel mechanism to travel back to nearest towns to unload your useless junk. Oh, and that reminds me, all the towns I visited were essentially carbon copies of each other, with the various crafting stations, a pub, and a couple of random houses in each.While KoA definitely has it's high points -- with combat being at the absolute top -- it relies too heavily on overused RPG tropes coupled with a very heavy "borrowing" of mechanics and game elements from other titles. It suffers from the developers trying to cram WAY too much content, instead of focusing on providing a smaller, truer open world environment, innovative mechanics and quests, and overall immersive experience. In the end, as pretty as the game can look at times, what the game is lacking is originality. The leads to most quests and the search for crafting materials to feel more like chores, than fun. At only 8 hours into the game, I found myself overwhelmingly bored. And it's a shame.(IF YOU DID NOT FIND MY REVIEW HELPFUL, please leave a comment as to why. I welcome the constructive feedback.)

content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												Kingdoms of Amalur Reckoning is perhaps one of the most underestimated games on the market. From a glance it boasts nice graphics, decent amount of content and a well-crafted combat system. However, I can assure you it’s also offers a beautiful fantasy world that has completely engrossing likeable characters with tonnes of side quest (With all DLC).  I’ll admit playing with PC controls can be somewhat challenging, however the controller settings are an utter breeze. The game has a vast range of unique weaponry and armour available, which makes every task, every hidden object, and every enemy slain feel greatly more rewarding. The only complaint I have in relation to this game, is the item limit, it can be a royal pain when you’re collecting different sets to switch between. Aside from your abilities and destinies there are various skills to upgrade:  Alchemy, blacksmithing, detect hidden, dispelling, lock picking, mercantile, persuasion, sagecraft and stealth, which are upgradable from basic to master. These enable you to interact better within quests or be worse off depending on which you focus on. Persuasion can make all the difference when getting caught out in committing an offence against the town, as can lock picking as you’d probably guess why.  With the availability of the Fate Weaver it is easy to respec at any given time to get a different experience from the game which holds ones interest for longer than a one route only game. I wouldn’t go as far as to compare Kingdoms of Amalur Reckoning to Skyrim, however, it’d definitely be my next choice from it. 8/10 Incredibly solid game.

number of helpful: 20 of 21 people (95%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26
												Before its release to Steam, I played hours upon hours of Kingdoms of Amalur for the Xbox 360, and I can tell you my experiences with this game had me loving it more and more each time I played it. KoA is a fresh take on the RPG Adventure games we're so used to playing, this one in particular giving us a very unique character that develops based upon your choices and decisions. Instead of listing the pro's and con's of this game in a bullet layered format, I'll instead give an in-depth analysis of what this game has to offer for you potential buyers!Main Story:Right off the bat, the main story line leaves you in suspense as you traverse further to figure out 'Who you really are', and 'What really happened.' I will refrain from giving out spoilers, but the entirety of the main quest line has an interesting plot, in which the character has many ways of going about, all leading up until that moment where you fulfill your goals and get your questions answered! The questline is not generic in any way, other than the fact that you find yourself broken, defeated, and lost in a world in which you have to learn, once again, about where you came from, and what it is you're meant to do. All of this becomes apparent as you meet new key characters along the way that help guide you on your path without giving you too much to lean on in the beginning of the game. That being said, delving into the questline in order to find the truth was truly captivating to me, and I enjoyed each and every quest from start to finish. Side Quests:While the side quests are always completely optional, I can't stress it enough that actually taking the time to do them is both fun and rewarding! Several factions are mapped out across The Faelands that have their own unique and interesting questlines, not to mention the incredible rewards each has to give! These Factions are not the only side quests given within the game, as there are other civilian and non-dynamic character quests that are given throughout the entire game. Some quests can be tedious, but unlike other games, these tedious quests truly do reap great rewards for the character. Not only will completing a quest leave you with a bit more gold in your pocket, or an extra item to equip, but completing these side quests will increase your relationship with other npc's, sometimes so much so that they will be willing to share a few items of their own with you. All in all, the side quests are incredibly refreshing, and add a bit more flavor to the game when you're not so interested in just following the main story line. Dungeons:This is something that I can't really express much love or hate for, as the dungeons in Kingdoms of Amalur were honestly satisfactory, for me at least. Each dungeon, while very different, had extremely generic layouts and areas that had no unique flavor setting them apart, other than perhaps the loot acquired from each of them. Don't get me wrong, the layout is beautiful and it does give you that dungeonesque feeling, but when it comes down to it, I just don't feel like they added enough diversity. Other than the aesthetics, the rewards given in each dungeon speak of their own value, as you'll never be left empty-handed for completing one. Combat system: I've finally reached my favorite aspect of the game... the combat. I absolutely love the combat to this game, possibly due to the fact that, well, its insanely unique! There are no set combos or time frames that it takes for your character to swing or attack. YOU attack when YOU want to attack, and this aspect of combat really gives you a sense of control and realism with your character. The different weapons and unique patterns of attacks offered for each type of weapon is absolutely awestriking. My first time using the chakrams and seeing how flashy and insane the moveset was really set that weapon apart from the rest. Not only do you have the ability to create your own combinations, you can tie your combination in with two different weapons, making the number of combinations unexhaustable. A staff and a sword, or a chakram and a great hammer, a wand, a greatsword, faeblades, a bow, so on and so forth! This all ties in well with the fact that you are not limited by your imagination to throw magic, or any spells in the mix. This truly gives your character a sense of value, as you are, within reason, your own, indistinguishable person. Gear/Crafting:I really enjoyed some of the gear sets in the game, and you always have that excited feeling when you pick up a piece that has better stats, and just looks plain awesome! Starting out, your gear will obviously be mediocre, but that doesn't take away the fact that these sets 'get the job done.' Each new piece of gear is unique in its own way, and when we add gem sockets and enchants to the mix, you will find an entirely different craft all together. The crafting system works in a systematic way where you'll need to acquire several pieces of equipment that have 'matching qualities' before you can create your new weapon or armor piece. Of course, this goes without saying, the better equipment you have and the higher your skill, the better your gear will be when you make that fresh new piece. Adding gems to gear in order to give your character some type of buff, whether it be increased mana, or extra burn damage, etc, is always satisfying, and lets not forget to mention... You can name a piece after you craft it. I don't know about you, but I love giving names to gear of my craft to give it that unique and one of a kind feeling. All in all, the gear in the game is not sorely lacking, but I will say that there was room for improvement on the aestheitc aspect of it, such as maybe adding more flair to a crafted piece or unique piece, but that aside, the gear in the game, as well as the crafting system, is rather balanced.Skill Tree/Perks:Could I go ON about how I love the skill tree in this game... While there are not an infinite number of talents, there sure seems to be an infinite number of ways you can build your character. With the three main skill trees, (Might, Finesse, and Sorcery) you can literally build your character any way you want. There are multiple different fate cards for each type of build, so there is never a scenario where you'll feel unrewarded for going into this tree, that tree, and the other. You will always be compensated for the way you spec, so much so that you'll recieve your own unique buff while you traverse farther down your own unique spec. The perks, too, have very rewarding qualities to them, giving you a plethora of options for how you want to build your character so they fit to your liking. Whether it be increased chance to lock pick, or finding hidden treasures with ease, all of these different perks really are rewarding in their own way. There are many other aspects of this game that can be talked about, but I believe that the true value of this games comes within the eye of the beholder, so I'll stop this review here. If you're looking for a fun, refreshing game, Kingdoms of Amalur brings the package to the table. The cartoonish graphics and unique gameplay give this game its own unique flair, and the story only becomes more exciting with the DLC content as you explore different and unique areas to the game with their own interesting storylines and rewards! I hope this basic review helps you decide whether or not you want to take a peek at KoA: Reckoning. With that being said, I wish you luck, fateless ones!

content:
Posted: February 20
												I haven't played enough of the game yet but I cannot wait to write the review since this game is simply fantastic. I wish they would have created a sequel and this time fix a few of the issues that people didn't like with the original game. +MASSIVE World, especially with DLC. I cannot stress this enough.+Quests, quests, quests, quests, and even more quests. Too many quests honestly.+You can make your character look bada**. And I mean real bada**. Not from the middle or near the end, no, right from the beginning itself. You can make him/her look batshit crazy.+Complete customisation. You aren't bound by any rules. You can play your character the way you want to play him. You can even change your class midway through the game if you didn't like the class you're playing with and are too lazy to restart.-Darn repair system. This ruins it for me, although some might like how it helps keep the player looking for new gear. It gets real annoying when you have to keep repairing your armor/weapons and find new repair kits over and over again.-Scaling. The game has a really weird enemy level system. Supposing I enter an area at level 2, all enemies in that area, every single one, will be level 2 for the rest of the game. This is why it gets extremely easy in higher levels when you return to old areas. -Invisible walls. If you're going in expecting complete freedom to roam everywhere in any way you want, you will find other games more appealing than KoAR. There's always that one invisible wall that doesn't let you jump down stairs, ledges, clear open spaces etc.

												Had this game back on 360 when I was a peasent. Had to buy it again because it's that good, also own the PS3 version, easily already sunk hundreds of hours in and looking to get more clocked in on PC. I like it over Skyrim honestly. Great visuals, high fantasy, great voice work, art style, world lore, not to mention how amazing and satisfying combat is. (Especially with the difficulty mod). If I could change 2 things about this game, 1: I would make it more open in sense of players can do/craft more. Just more little misc things for people to do, would have been nice but doesn't make it any less enjoyable just a personal thing. 2: Open source it, this game would have been perfect for modders and would have added (I feel) a much larger community/life span to the game. All in all, get this game. Enjoyable from beginning to end, can feel tedious at times, but that's not even a bad thing in the grand scheme of it.

Posted: July 13, 2014
												This is a really tough one. I so want to love this game. It's huge, with ton's of quests, tons of loot, tons of places to explore, looks good, sounds good... but it just feels so average and generic.The outdoor areas look very much alike with just varying amounts of grass and trees, the exceptions are few. The caves, tombs and dungeons get old very quickly. Even though you get a fast travel system I have often felt like I wanted a horse. The side quests are simple and mostly boring. The world doesn't react to you at all, you don't ever change it or affect it, which is really sad for a single-player game, it often feels like an MMORPG in this regard.I kinda hoped for a Gothic game with a better combat and maybe in raw technical sense I got one, but it never managed to grab me and make me want to play it and I've given it an ample amount of chances. It just completely failed to make me "care" about anything at all. The world, the story, the people, my own character... I don't know why. I really want to like it, it's not exactly lacking anything major that I'd want from it, but what it delivers just doesn't feel exciting and/or fun.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2013
												This game was such a beautiful let- down. the scenery was gorgeous, the side quests were more befitting a hero than Elder- scrolls side quests ("Go slay these giant spiders." vs. "Hey, would you mind carrying this bag up those stairs? kthx."). and all the classes started with unique abilities and weaponry. But about midway through the game, you start realizing how lop- sided the class options are. Stealth is nice for killing one dude, but there will always be 15 other "hive- minded" dudes in the area ready to swarm you. The mage is flashy and interesting, but you only get four real attack spells, and only one of those deserves constant use. To make matters worse, despite you having the ability to be the grand archmage of everything ever, you dont get access to any of the spells that enemies use. like teleportation across the battlefield, and auto- targeting tornadoes.  The only class ready to stand against anything is the might class. Anything close to you gets pulverized by your hammer (the only weapon option with a decent speed vs. damage output trade), and anything out of its short range gets yanked in by a hookshot. It is a powerful combo that breaks down targets that will always laugh off magic or stealth approaches. Now  for the ability sets. lock picking and spell breaking protected chests is a matter of probablility, so quick saving and loading makes points into that moot, same for stealing, so putting points into these is worthless. the only decent options are sagecraft and smithing to make decent gear, a point in persuasion ( to gain access to yet another probability game) and detect hidden to find better gear and more money. TL;DR- Get this game when it's 50- 75% off. Gameplay gets boring, but exploring the environments will be worth while, and it's pretty long, to boot.

												Before playing KoA, I had read reviews that tried to pit it against Skyrim for some reason, an odd choice considering that the gameplay and "feel" are at opposite ends with both of these games. One thing you really need to ask yourself before you purchase this game is " Do I have a lot of time to invest in another long drawn out RPG". I asked myself that before I bought KoA and just ignored how much time I do actually have to commit. Though I havn't finished KoA and I bored of it at about the 70 hour mark, I did enjoy the exploration and the way the game felt to play. It's not exactly open world or a sandbox but there is a lot to see, lot's to explore. I found myself swapping out specs because playing the one style got tedious and my time got taken up with a lot of travell. Otherwise, I'm actually glad a bought this, I may finish it when I have more time, up to the point I've played was enjoyable, just a little burned out. If you do buy this, be prepared to commit with small amounts at a time.

If you like Tolkien-esque fantasy in a Fable clone, pick it up - if it's on sale.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2012
												Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a fully voiced action RPG with an open world and vibrant Fable/WoW-style visuals that aim for character over realism. Combat, magic and animations are top-notch, completely decimating Skyrim, but the soundtrack, story, dungeons, atmosphere and even quests are inferior.Size and scope of the game are on an MMO scale with fast travel, a wonderful map system and a seemingly endless supply of side quests. There's no feeling of grinding but much of the content does feel like filler and, if you stray from the storyline too long, the repetitiveness and single-player MMO feeling will hit.With loot that feels like Diablo-lite, with randomized stats, set pieces and uniques to be found; skills such as lockpicking, persuasion, stealth and detect hidden, all with perks at certain points; warrior, rogue and mage ability trees a la WoW talents; and crafting systems of alchemy, gems/sockets and blacksmithing, Kingdoms of Amalur is an RPG through and through.Overall, a wonderful game if you like being set free to do your own thing but can accept the pitfalls that tend to come with open-world RPGs.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												Forget about the fiasco with 38 Studios and how it's not Skyrim and bluh bluh bluh you should play this game.The combat in this game is awesome, and I say this as someone who spent all of Skyrim sneak-sniping and refusing to get into melee. Mouse and keyboard works incredibly well after you get the hang of the camera, both weapon combos and dodging feels fluid and responsive, and melee combat is both satisfyingly visceral and very flexible. Wthin the three archetype skill trees and supporting "perks"/destinies, you can pick pretty much any playstyle you want and change it up on the fly, since respecs only cost in-game gold. I've spent at least two battles killing enemies without using any spells or weapons, but instead by dash teleporting through them - and THEN I found the teleport-slash dagger critical attack that lets you enact your favorite shameful anime samurai fantasies. It's pretty great, is what I'm saying.Story-wise, Amalur is solid but not precisely innovative; you have a lot of medieval-era peasants trying to make a living but there's a big bad and a bigger bad who want to destroy the world as you know it, and you're the Special One who'll etc etc. it gets less annoying as you get deeper into the story and find that most people don't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about how special you are. However, the Scottish-Roman gnomes are fun, and there's a few interesting twists in the (tons of) sidequests and main quests available. You shouldn't try to do them all, but you won't need to anyway since there's plenty of EXP to go around.Also, this game is pretty as hell. Very high fantasy. Much bloom. But pretty.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												I got this game from my girlfriend because she wanted me to try it out, I was complaining about games not meeting my standards/expectations and that I got bored of them so quickly. All I can say is that it was the right choice from her, gifting me this awesome game!Graphics might look "outdated" compared to many new games coming, but it has the charm that so many games lack. I continue to hop into it and not even to follow the story line - I enjoy all the things you can do, been doing so many side quests that I was in a whole completely different place than where my main story line played.I have an emotional connection with the game, which almost no game has been able to give me besides "Jade Empire". KoA has the same combat style as Jade Empire, really fastpaced the only difference being KoA is way more brutal. I love the sneak take downs, always different and always very rogue-like. I remember sneaking up on this enemy and actually patiently waiting for him to turn around for 5ish minutes, sneaked up right behind him and executed a sneak attack. My character covered the mouth of the enemy, stabbed him three times in the chest while pulling him back downwards, layed him softly down on the ground while crouching, slit his throat and then looked around to observe the surroundings - if her attack was noticed by the other mobs in the area. This game has so high immersion that I completely forget to check the time, it isn't the easiest when you are trying to fix your sleeping pattern, haha! Pros:- Immersive gameplay- Story rich, the story grabs a hold of you from the start and it has a high sense of importance (we all know those games trying to force you to do stuff for the "story" and you hate it because it is so tedious and you are not interested in it, because poorly written/executed/makes no sense/makes little sense or it is just plain stupid and boring, this game has no such thing as any of the above, the story is rich and interesting)- Your character looks badass!- Fastpaced combat, it gives satisfaction with killing blows, sneak attacks, random badassery with any other weapons than daggers for example.- Brutal combat!- Awesome cutscenes, I have watched every single one!- Good/evil choice settings (gotta love that!)- Big world - not huge, not tiny!- Unique characters/enemies, even talking to random NPCs is satisfying! Cons: - No romance almost (every RPG needs a romance option, even if you will not play it). There are like three minor options for romance and it feels like the concept is very overlooked- Spiders (not as much as a con as it is a personal problem). Imagine running freely towards any destination, then suddenly you hear a loud rumbling, your camera spans out and out comes a huge spider! While the minor cinematic goes on, spiders have surrounded you... it isn't a dealbreaker, the loud noise makes me jump everytime. That was a small list for cons, I know!

content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												There are no other games like this.It is futile to argue whether this game is good or bad. Lets say this game is bad. What alternaive do you plan to suggest? Witcher 3? Dark Souls? Baldur's Gate? Dragon Age 3? All of these alternatives are great, and you should definitely get them, but none of them can fill the niche that KoA:R belongs to.KoA:R was the only action RPG with decent combat system before Witcher 3 came, and because Witcher 3 pretty much carves its own very specific niche, KoA:R holds its position still. KoA:R excels in one other area where almost all other games in its genre falls flat: it has a vibrant and varied art style. Unfortunately the same can't be said about its story and AI.In retrospect, if you divide the soul of RPG into four determining factors, they will be:1. Combat2. AI3. Art style4. StoryThere are few RPG games that are good at one or two of these, but none that is good at at least three of them. KoA:R is special becaue it is the only one that shines in the combo { Combat, Art style }. It also tops { Combat } alongside Witcher 3 and Shadow of Mordor. Incidentally, Witcher 3 tops { Combat, Story }.KoA:R's art style might be great, but the Big Huge Engine does not live up to its name. Zones are segmented and the cities are pretty small. The battles are also not really that big. However, the world is vibrant and has a majestic feel to it. You can see when the developers ran out of budget to keep paying Todd McFarlane because Klurikorn and Alabastra are trash, and the DLCs switch to realistic art style.There are also many minor factors like freedom of choice, crafting and potions, quality of open world, degree of role playing, etc.If you can resist comparison with Witcher 3 and Dishonored, KoA:R has some degree of freedom of choice, but it is straightforward. Potions are boring, but crafting is awesome in this game. Every item can be dismantled into its core components, so you only grind for effect drop. Dashboarding is involved, but after finishing the Gravehal Keep, you don't even need to do that.It is combat where this game excels. Magic, might, and stealth each is played in its own different way. Within each, every weapon type has its own set of awesome skills. You can also mix and match to your heart's content. My first playthrough had a magic build, with some rogue elements mixed into it. My second playthrough was with a pure rogue build, and it played like a totally different game. I am planning to have a third playthrough with a pure might build. Each of the three primary builds has its own faction, and for the sake of variety I suggest sticking to only your specific faction in each playthrough, (because the faction missions bring out the real fun of each playstyle).

content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												If you liked Skyrim, Fable and alike this has some elements of those like lock picking, committing crimes,massacring villages,crafting of armor,weapons, potions, and a few other things. Combat is the funnest thing, but it can be kinda repetitive, but still good, and very fluid. Its also open world, so you can explorer wherever. Story is not bad, not the best in my opinion, but not the worst, it just feels a little generic at times, it does have some interesting parts tho. Lots of side quest if your into that stuff. They have a good art style, the world looks beautiful and have a lot of interesting designs to the map, music sounds good, weapons and such look good. I haven't ran any into any bugs or crashing issues, but that might change or not, plus might crash for you, maybe not. A issue I dislike in the game is the camera, sometimes it doesn't want to zoom in when your surrounded by a million enemies. The skill system, could use a little work for how its presented. Fortunately you can reset your skills. There also a tree system for abilities, might,sorcery and finesse, which determine you're play style. You can mix up points into each one of those, or spend it all in one aspect, like in the borderlands game.Anyways, its a fun game. You have different play styles, like stealth,range, up close, magic stuff. Things might seem to start slow, but they start to pick up the speed as you progress in the game. Their a lot of story stuff if you're interested in that stuff. Most of all, the combat just fun, mainly brought it for the combat, anyways worth trying out.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												I've had a bunch of fun with this game. The world is really interesting, the combat is a ton of fun, and it's beautiful. I don't think I can overstate this. There are tons of dark, grungy, washed out worlds out there. I love Skyrim, (250+ Hours and counting) but it's colors are grey, brown, and blah.  Amalur is gorgeous, colorful, vibrant, living. The combat has a decent amount of variety, and once you get in the upper levels of power, especially as a mage, you really do feel like a tiny god, stomping on those who displease you. It's also super easy to respec a character, don't like the thief powers/attacks? Respec to a warrior and aim pointy end towards other man. Not a fan of hitting things with sharp objects? Go mage and bring down the pain. I also really do enjoy the story of this game. It's got it's share of cliche bits, but overall, it really drew me in, and kept me interested. There are a few problems with this game that I have to face, even as a booster. It's pretty damn easy. Like, I normally play stuff on easy, maybe normal, and I didn't feel overly pressed when I played on hard. It's also easy to level past the game if you're a sidequest sort of person. There are a lot of quests of the MMO variety (fetch 10 wingdings, kill 10 grobnarks, etc, etc.)Overall, however, I really do recommend this; it's a blast.

number of helpful: 17 of 21 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												Perhaps one of the best Medieval Fantasy RPGs I've played in a while. The graphics are amazing, almost World of Warcraft-like. Each region is stylized differently, but follows what I think is the standard MMO style, which I don't mind, but I find it quite predictable. Gameplay, wise, the combat is really fun. Being able to transition between using a gigantic hammer and the smallest daggers is something rarely used in a few video games. The monsters are fun... for a little while. After a little while, you start noticing there's only a handful of monsters... used over... and over... and over again. Soon enough you'll find them everywhere you go. You'd probably grow tired of seeing Leanashe constantly, I know I do. The Fate powers is extremely badass, I loved using it from the start. But as you get more and more powerful weapons and spells, you may realize that the Fate powers are really only used for Bosses, not really for anything else. So chances are, you'll be playing through the game with a full Fate bar most of the time, and you won't even bother to use it. Though one thing that may♥♥♥♥♥♥you off the most in the game is the out-of-nowhere cutscenes that the game just pushes on you. And in the beginning, especially with the spiders, those cutscenes will scare the ♥♥♥♥ out of you. As for the story, it's pretty decent, but it can become dull over time. When you realize you have badass powers to alter Fate, you feel (appropriately) like a badass. Having everyone tell you that throughout the story, it gets to the point where you just tune the story out instead of enjoying it. Thankfully, there is something that can save you from ultimately giving up on the game's story, and that would be sidequests. There's a TON of sidequests to do. Almost wherever you go, there's a handful of sidequests that needs to be done. Sure, some people don't like doing so many sidequests, but it gives me something to do when I grow bored of the storyline.The game does have it's bugs, and I have encountered a few that have messed up a few quests for me. I haven't gone back to them, so I'm not entirely certain there's any way for them to be fixed. There are moments in the game where sound on weapons just cuts out completely, and the only thing you can hear are the after-effects of slicing at something or casting a spell. During a cutscene, the textures/models would take a moment to render as well. The last 2 bugs weren't exactly a problem for me, but they were slightly immersion breaking.Time to review the DLC! The Teeth of Naros is the shining star of the pack. An interesting land with interesting collosae people with a beautiful Greek-themed city. The story is great, and the final boss fight was truly amazing, albeit EXTREMELY difficult earlier on. The Legend of Dead Kel was a little bit less impressive. You were forced to stay on the island until later on in the DLC, so you were stuck on that same island for a while. The monsters introduced in this DLC were actually really well done. But that's the only good thing I can say about it. The story sucked. Pretty bad. Ooh, look, you're special... again. I don't want to♥♥♥♥♥♥on the fact that the game has you play the most important role in the main story AND the DLC stories, but really they make you so many different things, it gets confusing. But, it's not as bad as having the "You can change fate" plot point be the main thing everywhere you go. As for the armour DLC, it just gives you some starter armour. It WILL get replaced after a short while, so it's not worth having around, unless you're having a hard time finding any armour at the start.Overall, even though this game is fairly buggy, and it does get dull after a while, I still absolutely love it, for several reasons, but the biggest one would be that they made the mages INCREDIBLY badass. In most games like Skyrim, I would oftentimes have problems playing as a mage, because I feel their attacks are incredibly underpowered. But I was truly blown away at how the Mages were designed in this game. The Mage NPCs are extremely powerful, even slightly difficult to deal with since a lot of their attacks are homing. The mage abilities that you get in-game are beautiful as well. The more you progress, the more powerful your attacks actually look, and that's the most relevant in the Chakrams. So if you haven't purchased the game, and are a fan of Medieval Fantasy RPGs, I strongly urge you to pick this game up. You'll have a ton of fun!

content:
Posted: January 18
												This game is the pure essence of "Fantasy Action Adventure".Set in the fairytale-style world of Amalur (obviously), you are thrown into a conflict between mortal Humans and Immortal Fae.The story isn't too inovative but neither is it boring. No one aspect of the game is truly amazing, but they all work really well together to make a solid adventure that will have you hooked for many many hours. The best way to describe it quickly would be to imagine World of Warcraft, but with single player, a more direct combat system and a more involved crafting system. There are many areas in a pre-scripted world. Some things are persistent while others respawn. It really pays to explore every nook and cranny, as the next corner could hold an interesting quest or even a dungeon.Pros:+ fast-paced combat system where your reaction times and movement matter just as much as tailoring your stats to your playstyle.+ lots of game time. I played it for 50+ hours and aren't close to the end yet.+ a good crafting system. It isn't overly complicated but still allows you to make a large array of items that you can tailor to your specific play style. (also, custom names which I personally love.)+ respeccing is possible, so you don't have to worry about building your character into a corner.+ clear separation of battle skills and crafting skills, so you never wonder "is this going to help me kill things better?"+ Fully voiced, high quality dialogue with a diverse range of voices. This is actually really impressive because of the sheer number of characters and interactions. + Player owned realestate which can also be customized to your liking to aid you with crafting and storage.+ no DLC ads in-game, no struck content, no micro-transactions. Just buy the game and play it till you get bored.Cons:- no multiplayer whatsoever.- no mods or add-ons as far as I can tell.- pre-scripted world. Much like in most MMOs, once you explore 100% of the game once, you won't be surprised again.The game really doesn't have many negative aspects. Anything you think is bad will probably come down to personal preference. Do you want to go on a big adventure in a vast fantasy world? Then this game is definately for you!

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
 Overview   9.5/10I know that Steam shows that I only have 2.9 hours on record in this game.  However, that is because it's my third PC playthrough.  I had bought it a while ago from some site, I can't even remember the name of the site anymore - and I played it through... Twice.  Then, I bought it on my Xbox 360 and played through it.  Then once I sold my 360 and bought a PS3, I bought this game and played through it AGAIN.  Now I have purchased it through Steam and am playing through it again for the 5th time.  I've also been willing to purchase this game 4 times, if that is any clue as to how great this game is.  I am so sad that the company closed after the release of this game.  Poor marketing, honestly, is the only reason it happened.  They released around the same time as Skyrim, which, is not the same gameplay or style of game at all, however, both are Fantasy RPGs, and Skyrim is the fifth game in a lineage of Elder Scrolls - one of the most popular Fantasy RPG series of our time.  That mixed with the fact that "Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning" is a very long, hard to remember name for a game - this company unfortunately fell.  Story: [/b]   This story is not just some basic action story.  Sure it has it's cheesy moments, but honestly, what game doesn't?  Also, the story in this game was written by R.A. Salvatore, arguably one of the best fantasy authors of all time, certainly one of the most renowned.  Quests: [/b]  Some quests do seem fairly tedious, however the amount of quests in this game, and the amount of work that went into creating all the quests is incredible.  Especially with the size of the world being what it is.   All of the characters have their own personality, and that is great.  I am a game designer myself, and just seeing all the work that was put into this game amazes me every time I play it.    Gameplay: [/b]  The combat in this game is unparalleled.  I have never seen a Fantasy RPG that utilizes rolling to dodge, as well as the different weights and feels of each weapon, and with essentially a "clip" of arrows for a bow, and magic, all able to be used interchangeably in the same battle blows my mind.  And the stealth kills with daggers and faeblades? Come on.  Those are probably the coolest execution kills I've seen in any game ever, save for maybe Shadow of Mordor.  But that game came out two years after (and as we all know, technology and games improve SO much in the course of even a single year).  I also love the way you twist fate in order to gain additional EXP from your kills.  The crafting in this game is incredible as well.  I love the way you can break down weapons and armor for their different pieces, and use those to craft (and name!) an entirely new weapon or armor piece.  I do wish that there was not as much level-scaling as there is, however.  And the camera angle in this game is horrendous.  Even though the world is giant, the camera angle makes you feel cramped for space throughout the whole game.  Aside from those two small things, this game is one of the most wonderful gaming experiences I have ever had. Pros:  Smooth CombatGreat StoryFun MagicIncredible executionsFun QuestsAmazing Crafting Cons: Bad Camera AngleLevel-Scaling (personal dislike)Overall Rating: 9.5/10

content:
Posted: August 6, 2013
												This game here is a double-edged sword really. On one hand, you have:- Some absolutely insane and breathtaking scenery- Great art style, creature designs and a lot of eye-candy- Fun and dynamic combat- Very in-depth lore- Rich character building- Non-linear(ish), massive open world with fast travelBut then on the other hand, there are some pretty annoying cons, such as:- Next to no memorable characters, and if there are any, they are hardly likable- Terrible dialogue, talking to NPC becomes a chore you'd want to avoid- Limited character creator with presets instead of sliders, chances are you'll be running into twins throughout the game- Some skills like lockpicking are utterly useless- No enemy level scalingLast thing to mention, game has quite a fairytale vibe to it, though it's still much darker than, say, Fable. It's a game that you'll either like or you won't. The game is nevertheless very much worth purchasing if you're fond of DA, Fable, Divinity, GW2, and alike.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												Pros:-So much to do-GREAT music-Quite a few interesting characters-A lot of different and diverse quests*-You can reset your skills and perks any time-Loot adapts to your class to a certain extent and always to your level-Huge world-Interesting combat for all classes-Story might not be the greatest of all time but it feels consistent and hasn't let me down-Steady and rewarding progression level-wise-Mixing different class skill trees gives awesome results (supported by the free class system)*Although there are a lot of "Go kill X" and fetch quests the great atmosphere and world design makes largely up for thoseSome cons:-Balancing, late game criticals just face-roll everything, while for example slow warriors are helpless and slow-Humans look like clay dolls; especially facial expressions are just awful-Some funny depth of field and lightning effects sometimes when out in the woods-Level cap at 40 feels a bit low with the steady progression, hybrid jobs cannot reach the highest skill tier-A lot of skills are just worthless in their normal class and become only slightly useful for hybrid builds-Your inventory is gonna get clogged like your toilet after that one chili-taco-chipotle evening (AND THE STORAGE DOES NOT HELP)-Some areas feel awfully empty-Most ruins and caves look the same-A few bugs with NPC interactionsOverall 9/10 I love it

content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												Playthrough length of main world: 115 hours THE BAD...-Bugs-Crashes-(Beautifully) Overpowered crafting system-World barely changes through your actions.-Sound system cannot handle too many sounds in certain areas. An epic, sweeping music track starts to play in a city, only for it to suddenly be cut off by the burning of braziers. (e.g. Mel Senshir)-Stealth kinda sucks. Both ways. In the sense that you can be caught pilfering through a chest by someone who's sleeping, and in the sense that you can totally avoid being detected by someone walking right past you.THE MIXED...-It's easy, even on Hard.-Epicness of art style, environments, and story/lore is marred by technical limits and desire for smoother gameplay.-One of the few times the epic scale of the world is shown unimpeded, the pre-final stretch ended up a repetitive chore of killing numerous squads of enemies in an overly large location.-Ending is... ehhhh. Without spoiling much, it's okay, but I hate keeping secrets. At least I can tell the secret-keeper-wanter-fella to SOD OFF.THE GREAT...-Despite the limitations, the epicness of the art style and lore still shine. Mostly.-Music-Fluid combat-Easy multiclassing and stat resetting-The journey of going through the world and questing, the ADVENTURE, was really fun for me. Like someone on vacation, I had many opportunities to take a picture and just admire at how far I had come.OVERALLA good game that could have been made great with patches and fine-tuning, were it not for the demise of the company that made it.8.3/10

Posted: March 20, 2016
												I've tried several times to get into this game but it just isn't happening.Pros: Looks gorgeous. Runs smoothly at (or close to) 60 FPS. Colorful, imaginative designs. You can reroll your character on the fly and try out multiple builds on one character. Combat is simple, but not awful. Reminds me of a combination of the good parts of Fable and an Elder Scrolls game. Lots of side quests and dialog options (if you want that). Fast travel AND a decent run speed make exploring not a chore.Cons: Story is incredibly bland. Yet another "chosen one with no memories please save the world" snooze-fest. Every quest is a fetch quest or a "go here and activate 4 different towers and come back, thanks" deal. Random battles, as in enemies will just appear out of nowhere and attack you. That last one would be bad, but there are a lot of enemies that can fly and cast magic, so they spend most of the time hovering just outside your attack range spaming magic blasts. The menus are a slog to get through. Lore books everywhere filled with really boring, needless notes. Some of the worst fantasy names this side of Dungeon Siege 3.If you can grab the complete edition for ~$5 and you really, really want to play another Elder Scrolls inspired game it's not a bad deal, but be warned that it is aggressivly dull underneath the pretty paintjob.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												This is a really good Fantasy RPG.The character progression, both in equipment and in skills, is very well designed, you constantly have a significant goal in sight that motivates you. One feature worth explaining is your chosen destiny card, depicted as similar to tarot cards ("The Warrior", "The Seer" etc.), that do not only give you specific stat bonusses, but also help you identify with your role for the time being. I put it like this because after every level-up, you can choose a new destiny card. Those are unlocked with higher levels and perk points in one of the three classical RPG playstyles (Might, Finesse and Sorcery), and as you can respec at any time (by visitting a Fateweaver), one and the same character can be a soldier, a magician, a thief or even a hybrid class during his playthrough. As far as I know, this version of a flexible class system is unique to Kingdoms of Amalur, and I find it to be very creative.Main questline(s), faction questlines, sidequests, exploration are all written and scripted according to high standards of quality and never feel like a dull grind. Some are a bit stereotypical, some voice actors sound a little boring (e.g. the final enemy in the Warsworn questline), your dialogue options are typically quite limited - but this only takes away very little from the epicness and entertainment potential of your adventures.The world is enormous and colourful, many natural sights are real beauties. People and structures look a little too cartoonish for my taste, reminding you that this game is half a decade old - but you get used to it. Magical objects and plants glow and sparkle, which creates the vibe of a fairy tale. Immortal Faes (Elves) left ruins in the "enchanted forest" (that's not its name, but it feels like it) that impress by their style and their size, castles and dungeons are very spacious as well. If I am not mistaken, this world is much larger than Skyrim. The combat system is definitely better than Skyrim's. It is very fluent and tactically varied, due to dodging, parrying, swift standard attacks, special moves and abilities you learn by spending skill points (which means that your fighting technique, as opposed to mere stats, developes while levelling up). Even my heavily armoured warrior rolled and killed like a Ninja swordsman, it just felt awesome. A very small annoying thing are the constant reminders of the option to "fateshift" (a special killing ability), something that was OK in the tutorial, but becomes really unnecessary after you have done it a few dozen times - and it covers an important part of the screen while the combat continues. I believe that this could have been fixed very easily, but then, nothing is perfect.A weak point of this game is the lore. I  am not able to put my finger on a certain reason, but it does not appeal to me. Perhaps it is the way in which the lore is presented: "Lorestones" are inexplicably distributed throughout the land, and after you activate them, a part of a myth is narrated in voices that tend to be as weird as the worst of the NPC voice actors. After you activated all Lorestones in a region, you receive a stat bonus...very technical and quite unimmersive in my opinion.Nevertheless, this game was absolutely worth the full price, and now that you can have it on sale, it is definitely a must-buy. It receives a solid 8/10 from me!

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												This is a sprawling, epic action RPG. There are three classes to choose from, might (fighter), finesse (rogue) and sorcery (wizard). It is extremely easy to create a pure character or a hybrid. Respec'ing your character is easy and you will find yourself doing this several times, if not for anything but to be able to purchase skills from an earlier trainer. I started with a pure melee character and took him to level 36. I played around with a hybrid melee/sorcerer/rogue, but didn't have fun. In the end I settled with a powerful rogue/melee hybrid that could barrage enemies with arrows from afar and mop up with blades afterward.Combat is a mixed bag. It is essentially a click fest like many action RPGs. Even still it is rewarding. Loot is the end game and trying to find the right equipment will keep you going. Unfortunately, as with most ARPGs by the time you get a complete set of armor you have better non-set stuff. However, sometimes the bonuses gained with a full set overrides the slight decrease in protection.Side quests can be annoying. Many are of the FedEx variety. It can be extremely frustrating to move from place to place delivering goods, or killing X number of beasts to collect your reward. There is a fast travel system that allows you to move from location to location as long as you have been there on foot at least once. This does cut down on travel time, but these FedEx quests are tedious. Since this is likely the only time I will play, I finished the majority of side quests. I did get bugged out of two and couldn't complete them. And a couple others I didn't do early and never went back to finish them. The quest system is easy to navigate and helpful markers show up pointing the way to your next objective.In the end, I was finally glad to get through the game. The last levels are mobs after mobs standing in your way of the final battle. I did enjoy this game and can recommend it to anyone who is looking for a good action RPG. There isn't a lot of depth in character development, but what is here is good.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												I bought the game even though I've never even heard about it. It was on sale, I like RPGs so I thought I'd give it a shot. The first thing I've noticed or rather heard were the familiar voices from other RPGs. It was great to hear Canderous Ordo from SW: Knights of the Old Republic who gave voice to Agarth. Also you can hear Cullen's voice from DA: Origins. I've figured out more names when I was playing it but I've forgotten most of them now, it was a nice surprise though.I like the open world, and man it's huge! I've played ~100h and I still haven't discovered every location. Also, each location has different environment which is good because it doesn't get boring (well maybe except caves which are all similar). The story isn't the best point in the game, the beginning is enough to get you intrigued about it but when I found out the truth I was a bit disappointed. However, a good thing was that I enjoyed every moment that led me to finishing the story. The gameplay is very good, I found it easier to play using controller, but sometimes I found it frustrating that you can only map 4 skills. However, if  you have a good feel of your character and combat it shouldn't be a big problem. Another thing that I absolutely loved about it is the possibility of mixing the skills from all trees which allows to make some interesting hybrids. It's a feature that isn't very common in RPGs. I've found some things that were frustrating for me, for example sometimes when you have a boss fight the camera behaves weirdly, and you don't see the enemy. You just have to move your character to an open space but it's annoying if it happens often. Another things is that, you have to go everywhere on foot. Yes, there is fast travel, but the areas are pretty big and sometimes I wish they've added some mounts. Sometimes it seemed to me I've spent more time walking than fighting...And, one other thing - MORE ALYN SHIR!!! I mean seriously, she was the most interesting character out of all of them and you only interact with her a few times...such a shame. Don't get me wrong, Agarth was quite cool too but...ALYN SHIR!! What can I say, I just love her voice. When it's on sale again, don't think twice about it, just buy it!Edit (June 2015): I've just started to play this game again and man, the camera really sucks. You'll die more times because of it than because of your skill, it can get really annoying.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												I think it's time I finally gave this gem of a game a review. Unfortunately this game didn't do well on its release because games like Mass Effect 3, and Black Ops 2 were stealing the hype of players, and Skyrim had just come out four months before - thus this game went unnoticed. 38 Studios went bankrupt shortly after the game was released completely destroying any hope for a sequel.   So, why should you buy this game?  It's definitely not an Elder Scrolls game, which is why I have enjoyed it so much. The game offers:200+ hours of gameplay. (Excluding DLC) Extremely comfortable and convenient fighting and spell casting controls. (100% Controller Compatible)Countless armor and weapons to build, collect, and upgrade.Stunning visuals and graphics and so much more!Todd McFarlane was the graphic artist on the game, which gives it a breathtaking and also somewhat cartoonish feel of the game. Each area of the game is distinctly different and absolutely beautiful, whereas with other RPGs you get the feeling you are in the same area the entire game. If you're still skeptical of purchasing, go ahead and download the demo and see for yourself. The game is more than worth its full price of $20, so if it's on sale go ahead and grab it. You won't regret it!9.5/10

												Possibly one of the greastest RPGs I've played but not for the story reason.The game itself is very fluid, everything feels so casual yet serious at the sametime, it's very easy to pick up and put down and comeback to it later and still get a great experiance if you like games that are a bit grindy at times but if you enjoy lots of quests and items then you'd love this game. Seriously there is so much to do.The areas that the game introduces I think are very for lack of a better word: Pretty, it's not like jaw dropping but it's very pleasing to the eye at least and fits in nicely with the games setting. Combat is very enjoyable, you can build whatever class you want to fit your combat playstyle and it's fairly easy to change it again if you don't like it, each class you build  gain a set of bonuses too which can affect the way you dodge along with certain stats too. there are also plenty of intreasting weapon types to get to grips with as well. I think it really offers a lot on the ways of customization one of it's high points to be sure! However there are some downsides The main story itself feels a bit... forced. I'm sure a lot of people enjoyed it but me it just felt... thrusted onto me. I really didn't like the main enemy much although I really enjoyed the concept of it all! it just felt... rushed.  I think it really comes down to taste on that one and it certainly wasn't mine. Another thing to consider is that this game uses a EA account to log in and play! I've had a bit of trouble with it before not accepting my email before for no reason to the point I had to go to the EA Origin support to correct this. (Kingdom Of Amalur Support is done through Origin support!!) thankfully it was corrected and I gotta admit the Origin support team were amazing.

number of helpful: 74 of 130 people (57%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												TL;DR: It's an alright game if you're just looking for something to scratch a third-person action itch for twenty hours or so, but there's really nothing that makes it stand out as anything special.Combat itself is entertaining enough, but there's absolutely no depth to it - you have one basic attack per weapon type that can be chained together to a limited extent, and a couple of active abilities that scale so terribly you'll hardly bother using them. And since unlocking additional weapon moves is locked in to progress down the ability trees, you spend half the game without access to the more varied attacks, meaning that most of the time you'll just be hitting your attack button and blocking/dodging occasionally.The combat balance is almost non-existent, enemies are almost universally completely trivial other than the occasional one who is an annoying damage sponge and does hilariously disproportionate damage, and there's only about a dozen different enemies who are palette swapped and recycled throughout the course of the game. The most challenging part of the combat is dealing with the abysmal camera, which has a mind of its own and loves to zoom right in on you when you're surrounded by enemies, only stopping to clip through the scenery and get stuck under the floor occasionally.There's a variety of non-combat skills to choose from (lockpicking, stealth, persuasion and so on) which are generally either absolutely bloody useless, or hilariously overpowered. Depending on which ones you choose you can end up completely trivialising the game without even trying, but with a little care you can max out almost all of the skills anyway which makes any sense of choice completely redundant.The ability trees are probably the highlight of the game, there's a lot of different abilities to choose from, and thankfully you can respec your character at any time to try different things out. Depending on how you want to play, you can either go deep into one of the trees (magic, might, or finesse, which broadly correspond to the standard mage/warrior/rogue archetypes) or split your points across two or even all three trees. Putting enough points into one tree or a combination of trees unlocks "destinies" which give you added stats and bonus abilities and can make different ability builds feel very different from each other. Ultimately, however, it's still limited by the shallow nature of the combat system, and however you build your character you'll inevitably end up spamming the same basic attacks over and over again.The real issue is with the pacing of the game. Every single town you come across is chock full of completely forgettable NPCs who will bury you up to your eyeballs in fetch quests and kill quests which give no real rewards but make you slog all over the place anyway. Either you try and do everything out of an obsessive sense of completionism, or you get bored of that by the second or third town, rush through the main quests, and realise there's really not that much game under all that padding. There are half a dozen factions with their own sidequest chains that have a bit more structure to them, but none of them really add much to the game, and aside from some minor stat boosts it makes absolutely no difference to anything whether you do them or not.Overall it's a thoroughly mediocre experience through and through, which never manages to be amazingly good or offensively bad. If you like third-person action RPG games it ticks pretty much all of the boxes, it does everything more or less adequately without ever really impressing, it all looks nice enough and there's a whole bunch of lore if you can be bothered to pay attention to it. Pick it up in a sale and it'll give you a good thirty hours or so of moderate entertainment, but it's a mostly unremarkable experience with next to no replay value.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												One of the most underrated games of all time. It has all the great elements of a great Action RPG.First really colorful and smooth graphics (which are designed by Todd McFarlane, creator of Spawn). World is really beautiful, characters and enemies are well animated. Graphics are well-combined with the action. You feel like you are in a feary tale. It has a big world with lots of exploring to do. Various things to collect, many side quest to complete. So world never gets boring. Different kinds of enemies, also each town has different touches. RPG elements are satisfying and not too complicated to give you a headache. There are lots of combinations you can do with your character. Weapons and armors are fun and nice to look at. Crafting is easy to understand and your options are really wide. Especially naming your weapons are fun and makes you feel like a real hero. Combat system is brilliant, which takes you in to action. What are the cons? Well main story is not the greatest. Game is not that hard (it is not a con for me but seems like it is for the most people :) ). There are not mounts so travelling gets a little boring after awhile. In the end; if you are looking for a great, rich world with colorful enemies, cool action with great graphics, this game is for you. It is basicly a great MMORPG but single player (just as I like). It is a shame developer bankrupted. Wish they could make a sequel..

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												Kingdoms of Amalur:  Reckoning  is a western rpg, meaning when you get out of the tutorial area, the game goes "okay, the main plot is over there, sidequests are over here... go nuts."Overall, the game starts out with you dying, and you're brought back by the Well of Souls, an experimental form of resurrection.  So far, you're the only success.  You have no knowledge of your past life, and you seem to be unbound from the threads of Fate, meaning all your actions will have unknown effects on everyone else, for good or ill.  People destined to fail may succeed, those who were supposed to live may die, etc.The game has a fair number of good points for it - you get a good range of emotions from quests and character dialog; even minor characters have been fleshed out and given personality.  The combat system is fairly simple but engaging, so it doesn't take too long to learn, but for the most part remains interesting throughout the game.  Most enemies who die in motion will drop a treasure bag, so if the body falls off the edge of a cliff or becomes inaccessible, you can still get the loot.  There are a number of quests which your decisions will actually have an overall effect on the area, as well.  More than once, someone you're sent after will go "uh hey, I have no beef with you, just those guys.  How about you leave me alone?" and you can actually work for them instead, or leave them alone.  Most of the escort quests aren't too much of a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ either.  The graphics are quite nice as well; the game is very beautiful, and the character models are done well.The game definitely has its flaws, however.  A number of fluff items are tagged as essential, meaning if you pick them up, you cannot get rid of them or even leave them in your stash.  A number of quest items also remain after their use is expended, making them clog up your inventory list (or in rare cases, take up actual carrying space ).  There's no way to drop quests, and some quests are repeatable, so you'll always have their markers on your map after you've stopped caring about it.  The questflow is a bit odd as well - one branch of the main questline, and all of the faction questlines (along with a fair number of regular quests) point you to a city called Rathir fairly early (a place which marked somewhere around two-thirds to three-quarters of the game through for me), while only the other branch of the main questline went to an area called Detyre, which is much lower level than Rathir.  This wouldn't be as much of a problem is you received the Detyre quest first, but you receive it the same time as the one pointing you to Rathir, and if you've been working on any of the faction quests, you're going to be getting a huge push to go there as well.  The crafting and skill system could have used some more work as well; the lockpicking is a joke as most of the time you don't even need to move the pick, money becomes a nonissue quickly, making mercantile pointless; sagecrafting, alchemy, and blacksmithing all feel kinda useless until you max out their points.  Also, after a certain point in the game, all of the health and mana potions seem to drop back to lesser for some reason, even though the others are at the correct level... until even later in the game, when any non-health or mana potion drops are all just greater damaging.Sadly, given what... happened to the company, most of the bugs will never be patched, and no sequels will be made, which is a shame 'cause despite its flaws it really is a good game.  It's definitely worth $20, and any sale price it goes to is an absolute steal.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Kingdoms of Amalur confuses me.It is a game I couldn't imagine *anyone* asking for. Not in 2012, anyway, it is not a game to enter the Dragon Age and Skyrim league: Its art design is tepid and barely par for course, the story is not really that good, the UI is a consolized mess, there is no stat sheet (!!!), mod support is ZERO, there is very few skills and combat can be overly easy at times.Now, with that out of the way, this is one of the best action RPGs I've ever played, and one I've certainly played way, way past the point where I should have stopped. The best comparison I could draw with a similar game would be Fable, really, since there's a lot of elements in common with it: Quick, flashy combat, three skilltrees you can invest points in (finesse, might, sorcery), two weapons you can switch between on the fly, a few magic spells (2, until a bit further on), you'll be on your own most of the time, and combat is strictly real time. The only part the game looks a bit more developed is on the skills category, where you can find several ways to improve your adventuring and crafting abilities. The greatest achievement of this game over Fable however, is that while Fable lost itself dillydallying over customization and tattoos and farting in the face of villagers, Kingdoms of Amalur disregards all that in favor of an incredibly tight gameplay and a very flexible, if not perfect, skill tree and progression, which provides an open-ended freeform progression to the player while at the same time opening new abilities and overall feeling way meatier than Skyrim's, whose progression was more of a polite indicator that you were getting better at shooting with a bow by way of shooting more with a bow.Now, this review will be based on my 50-odd ingame hours so far. I have played with a ranged/daggers rogue complemented with some magic spells and Might talents. As you can see, I'm a kinda indecisive player, and chosen a class that's been historically looked down upon on RPGs. One, or both of those choices would have made it very difficult for me in other games: being spread too thin in Skyrim, or playing an archer on Dragon Age would make things exceedingly difficult for me. Not with KoA. There is a class that favors all-rounding. Specializing in bows doesn't mean you can't put points in swords. Or magic. And if you choose straight combat, you can utterly annihilate anything with basic combat. You can respec a pretty good number of times, too, and clever players will be able to squeeze every profession in order to get the most of them and the best equipment. But I must admit, reaching that conclusion required a bit of patience from me. The game starts very insipid and generic, and as I said, none of the first impressions I got was really that enticing, but if one can look past that, beneath the apparent simplicity and half-assedness there is an incredibly strong and extense base material: graphics are more than competent, the soundtrack is perfectly functional with moments of greatness, quests are pretty interesting if you decide to listen to them and finally, at the center of it all, the delicious, chocolatey core of it and its main driving force for me: the gameplay, and specifically, the combat.Combat is fast and flowing, camera never gets in the way and animations and attacks are very well done. All abilities have a place on it, and a lot of approaches are viable. They might say it's a game designed with a controller in mind, but I've found the keyboard layout extremely confortable (unlike in, say, Devil May Cry), and since it's way more actiony and mobile than other games', it is also extremely satisfying: even if you are decimating groups of wolves in 5 seconds flat, you'll feel like a badass doing so instead of getting bored because it's too easy. Yes, my character has 4 active offensive skills and 2 sustained ones, but I can kick so much♥♥♥♥♥in so many different ways between them and my ultra-powerful handcrafted equipment that it never feels old or boring. And besides, it's better to never let your guard down: it's as easy to lose half your life as leaving your guard down for a moment.To sum it up, if you are a fan of exploring places and killing monsters I'm not just going to ask you to buy it, but to get all its DLC (especially on sale) and to be a bit patient with it. Empty your mind, shed your preconceptions and have a bit of fun with it, start doing the first missions, you don't even need to pay a lot of attention to it. Play the game for a bit, and you most assuredly will get a satisfying experience out of it. If you ever got excited about Fable, or if you are in the mood for having a good time whacking critters over the head with weapons of incredible power, pick it up without a doubt.8.5/10

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												I wanted to love it, I really did but it's just so boring. It's not all bad though the game is very pretty and ran very well on my machine. The combat is good, there's better combat out there it's not compelling enough to be entertaining more than a few hours. This is where the bad starts to come in. The plot was very bland and unremarkable for such a well crafted world they should have had a much more compelling plot but they didn't manage to make me care in 7 or so hours and at that point I am never going to care. The never ending fetch quests got boring very quickly, it helps move you along to new locations but it all starts to feel stale after awhile. I feel like there is some promise here and maybe when the franchise is sold to another company they can pare away all of the unnecessary nonsense, but for now there are better rpg experiences out there that you should consider way before this one. Overall I would not recommend this.Rating: 2/5 Stars
