content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												Underdog detected :)PROS- Truly HUGE world.- An amazing amount of quests, a lot to do- Three classes with that play very differently because of their skills- High polish and optimisationCONS - Weird to say but the game is so huge that sometimes it can be discouraging :) But this is not really a con, mostly we have been playing short games for so long that we lost the attention span required to play a game for weeks.- Some of the lore can be boring sometimes. I find the fae to be a boring race for exemple, bunch of broken record playing the same songs again and again. But it fits the story and the world setting, i just wish there were more diversity in the culture of the world.REVIEWThis is a huge game and deserves a long review, but lacking the time suffice to say that it is an excelent RPG, and fairly unique in the way it tastes like an MMO because of its scale.I am not sure why this title didn't do better, I can't recall but i think at the time it came out there were 3-4 big titles coming out also and they completely overshadowed this game. I guess most people didn't have the budget or the gaming time for another 60$ title. I only grabbed this recently because it went on sale, and certeinly don't regret it. I got about 90 hours out of it already after finishing it (not a full clear mind you, a lot of quests and some exploration still left over), and I still have the DLCs set aside.Some advice : If you get slightly bored in your play, respecialize as another class. I went through all the 3 classes in my single playthrough, and it helped keep things fresh. The game certeinly doesn't warrant a playthrough with each class as it would be too repetitive, so might as well experience all classes on the same go.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												Ever wanted to play a MMO completely solo?  Imagine this:  The feel of World of Warcraft, except that actions you take have final repercussions.  Combine this with a frantic combat system not unlike God of War, a quest system as rich as Skyrim and a loot table that puts Diablo to shame.KoA:Reckoning is all that.  You play the role of the Fateless one, a being who, through story events have been removed from the grand tapestry of fate.  What you become is entirely up to you, the class and skill system is absolutely limitless.The soundtrack is spotless, the music is great and greatly enhances the mood.  The voices are a mixed bunch; most of them are very well done but a few NPCs here and there make you want to reach and punch them.  Graphics are another issue that could annoy some people; the world and environment are absolutely gorgeous and involving, but the character textures could be better, looking somewhat dated.  Nevertheless, you'll find the originality of the world design to be quite unique and vastly apart from the usual elf/dwarf/orc/dragon fantasy games.As for the single biggest flaw this game has: it's entirely too easy.  Even on hard mode, a well built mage will steamroll against pretty much everything.  It didn't bother me mind you, once in a while it's fun to just go around, watching my cute little dokkalfar owning everything as I cackle like a maniac.  I may or may not be taking pills for that.Grab it during the summer sale and play it.  It's a gem.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												It's a pretty average game. The Graphics and world building are top notch. The combat and balancing was unique but not fully engaging. It became monotonous and I just ran past most of the fights towards the end. I suggest this game to people who really like RPGs. If you don't like RPGs, I don't think there's much here you'll enjoy.The story and writing is a bit inconsistent. The sidequests are written brilliantly while the main story is rather dry. The combat isn't bad, but it's not good. It was never balanced properly. So your character will be OP for about 90% of the game no matter what you pick. Combat is more of a pacing mechanic than a  meaty gameplay element. You'll find yourself simply running past enemies to fulfill quests since enemies become time sinks rather than challenges.It was the quintessential mediocre RPG. Not too good, not too bad, with proper pacing so you never get stuck doing something you don't want to do.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												A very fun game. Rich lore, interesting storyline, various unique creatures and weapons. There are 3 main playstyles that vary considerably. If you want you can focus on one of the 3 or you can split it up between. There are so many possibilities, cool moves and useful spells. It has a solid blacksmithing and alchemy component to it, as well as something called sagecrafting where you can create gems that will power up your items. Because most people are going to know what its like compared to Skyrim I guess I'll have to talk about that. In my opinion the combat is more rich. There's dodging, and blocking with sheilds is actually worth it and plays into your attacks if timed right. Also it feels way less hack and slash than Skyrim, there a different moves that when applied correctly can turn the tide of what might have seemed an unwinnable fight. The game auto-aims for you, but that doesn't detract from the fighting experience at all. The spells are also more interesting than Skyrim's. Skyrim might have more spells but they end up all feeling the same while KoA:R's are all unique and have very powerful uses in certain situations. Kingdoms has an amazing world to explore. It is a bit small compared to Skyrim and doesn't allow for as much freedom (for example you can only jump down from cliffs and walls at certain points on the map) but it is something you get used to and it helps with where the game really excels: combat, because you are channelled towards groups of enemies. The graphics are fairly decent and the game runs smoothly. I did run into a bug where you get stuck and cannot move at all and have to fast travel to get out of the place and the general pop in distance for enemies could be a bit longer, perhaps there is a way to change this in the .ini files or something, I'll have to check. The lipsyncing of characters is sometimes off and occassionally they make really awkward movements when speaking, which are a bit immersion breaking. The voice acting is quite good though like all RPGs I really wish they could have used a greater variety of voice actors. Overall its a great experience and I'm quite addicted to it so far. There are so many choices and I feel as if I will do a bunch of playthroughs with vastly differing character builds to get the whole experience. Oh that brings me to one last thing. You can "unbind your fate" for a relatively cheap gold cost to reset your points. This means if partway through a playthrough you got sick of smashing people with giant swords you could pay a bit of gold and change your character into a stealthy assassin or a flashy mage.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												Great Fun! The characters are pretty wooden, although they try to add some humor, that said the most humor I have is smashing down anyone, yes you can smash down almost every character. This can detriment the game a little, I smashed some people in a market and missed the chance at an inventory, but at the same time I smashed some blind followers on an island and got good armor.I found one breaking bug on the Dead Kel DLC, didn't bother me too much cause the game is so fun, also take it of full screen mode but keep the native resolution to reduce the frame rate issues, it doesn't actually take it out of full screen  but solves issues. What I like is that it doesn't try to be realistic or serious, like ahmm, oh no there's a big dragon. You've got dialogue choices where you can belittle characters for taking themselves too seriously, more fun. I have a sword that's bigger than me and ancient frisbies.As I said it's fun and funny, the beasts look incredible and they're diverse, the combat makes you feel like a megalith, you can become very overpowered very quickly, but you can challenge yourself by resetting your class and reassigning points or mixing your class up.I really enjoy this game, it's fantasy, colorful, full of loot and funny. It constantly reminds you, that you are in a fantasy world and absolutely rips into it if you want.I disagree it's anything like an MMORPG, it laughs at itself, it laughs at RPG's and then say's cause it's fun and that's the way it's meant to be. If you're looking for a game that's bright, energetic, fun and funny, doesn't take itself to seriously, I find that it is a bit like the Borderlands of the fantasy realm with more dialogue choice and I love borderlands.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												EDIT: After playing more, I can safely say I do really enjoy this game. It's very charming in its own way and the world is pretty big. At the time of this review I've played about 30 hours and I'm only level 10 and still in the starting land!There are some bugs, the camera angle can be annoying at times, auto target is a bit wonky, I really dislike the short render distance (it was ported from consoles so the textures pop in at short distances... just annoying) But overall this is an "underrated" game if I ever saw one. It's a slightly flawed gem that should have gotten more attention. I was very sad to learn the studios went bankrupt after making this game because it didn't sell enough copies :( If it had gotten more attention it would have been given the love it deserves. The guy who made this game put all his savings and time into it and it "failed." So sad.PROS:-Pretty big world with about 10,000 years of backstory/lore (literally)-Graphics actually look pretty nice-"Cartoony" look sort of like Fable or Torchlight-Pretty good voice acting-SOOOO many quests and stuff to do! -Nice easy to learn skill system and flexible for any type of playstyle-Works 100% with a gamepad or controller (I myself use an XBOX controller)-RPG elements like a dialogue wheel and choices that affect quests/story-Unique story with a fairly interesting plot-Celtic mythology and lore which you don't see in many games(I myself am Irish so maybe I'm biased...)CONS:-Short render distance so textures pop in obviously all the time-Kind of weird camera angle FOV but there is a mod which fixes that-Some dialogue is a bit cheesy or repetitive now and then... but I find it hilarous :)-Silent main character... this is a con for me because it's quite awkward to have your character just stare at people during dialogue-Combat is a bit tricky.. sometimes it's difficult and sometimes too easy... Basic wolves and other "fodder" are the most annoying enemy in the game, while single bosses are easy peasy-Pehaps a bit too much reading, VERY dialogue and text heavy at timesI would still give it about an 8/10. If you like Skyrim, Fable, and Celtic mythology you would definitely enjoy this game :)

content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												Just finished with both add-on`s. Took me about 190 hours of decent fun. Sorry for my English - not my main. Beware of small spoilers.Game is HUGE. World is very interesting yet main storyline seems like "I did that few times already". I mean, for example, Fae (naming them just Amalur`s Elves does not give justice to their concept) and their life cycle. How they preserve history and traditions by repeating battles and happenings from long gone past, making them to reappear in endless cycle. Unable to reach for something new. Great and tragic at the same time. House of Ballads storyline is extraordinary. While main quest, tho has its moments, drives us to meat final Great Evil like so many before. Don`t get me wrong - it`s fine but nothing as extraordinary as some other parts of the game.I like fighting system. Played melee fighter. You can really create Your own style. And while most enemies can hit hard at the beginning of the game, all of them can be killed. When I died it was always because of my own fault. Problem is, later on there are no real challenges. The only achievement I didn`t get through normal playthrough was the one to kill enemy 4 levels higher then me. Thanks to scalling system I haven`t found one. On the other hand main hero is somewhat unique figure in the world of Amalur so maybe it was intended by devs to make god-like impression.Can`t say something about magic - haven`t been using that at all. I really liked minigames of picking locks and dispelling. Crafting is very usefull tho crafted items make game even more easy. So up to after Mel Senshir I used Alchemy to craft potions only. Then I made final tier crafts and my charactered trippeled its stats. So whoever wishes to make game more of a .... hmm no, not challenge.... rather more humanlike - do not craft. Whoever wishes to become one man army+++ please do.To sum up. I spend with this game 190 hours and I`m not masochist. So it means i like it pretty much. For World created, for Lore (mostly unused), for Fae storyline, for Dead Kel, for fighting. for many small things making it great rpg experience. And being god-like figure is not so bad after all ;)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												Good graphics, nice music, varying enemy types, entertaining quest dialogue, nice skill tree and class/job system. It can get very dull after long periods of play in my opinion, I just thought it was slow paced at times. I found it hard to stay invested and interested in the story of the main questline or side quests. Combat is fun and somewhat simple and can get repetetive sometimes, but at the time I write this review I went full might skill tree, Warlord, so I have yet to experience the finesse and sorcery skill trees enough to adequately judge all combat styles in this game as a whole.PROS:Graphics.Gameplay.Good music.Varied environments.Large game map.Simple and easy ui (quest log, game map, inventory, junk tab, etc.).Lots of loot to dig through, if that's your thing (I know it's mine)."You are what you play" class system. You can go full warrior, rogue, mage, or do a bit of all 3, or a bit of two. It's all up to you. Not to mention there's a lore based method to reskill your character; you don't have to make a new character to switch up your playstyle.varied quest objectives, be they personally engaging with the quest NPCs or having you run to the end of a cave and retrieve an heirloom (chances are you know the kind).CONS:Slow paced.Gets dull after extended play sessions (at least in my opinion).You can't abandon quests once you get them; once they're in your quest log, you're stuck with it.It's WAY too easy to get filthy rich in this game. Just loot every little thing you come across that you don't want and pawn it. Before you know it you'll be rich. Like, Bill Gates rich.If this game is on sale, definitely get it. I picked it up when it was on sale for just 5 bucks, and it feels like a steal.I'm no video game journalist, just a gamer. I would give this an 8/10.Replay value: moderately high.Hours played at the time of this review: 107 hours.

												Got this game for under $10 on special and what a bargain!I’ve bought other games for more and been finished in 6 hours or less, so this really gives value for money.If you enjoy games like the Witcher or Gothic series, then you'll enjoy this as it has a similar feel but also has some unique features like the “Reckoning Mode”.Had read some posts about bugs, but after 140hrs of game play only came across one bug and that was the Eathe mission where I spoke with her too early and she got stuck in the Cistern, making another quest unachievable. (but no big deal as I ended up with over 240 completed quests anyway)In the end I maxed out on level 40 about 6 hours before the end of the game, so pretty well spot on. Some of the side quests drag on a bit, but you can miss these altogether if you want to.Found the game to be addictive at times and was easy to spend all day/night playing. Would totally recommend this one.Get the whole bundle and have some fun...

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												Wow, Kingdoms of Amalur was a GOOD game. From beging to end i never felt that this game really deserved the bad rap that it got. However I do understand that this game has its issues and there are far more polished and more sophistcated RPG titles out there. But i blieve the late 38 studios did a great job with this title, with this being its first and now only ever game the company has produced i blieve it deserves the cult status it has slowly achieved. The story, the lore and the characters is were this game really shines, its ingossing and it makes you feel like you are a part of the world, and i am truely hoping that one day a studio, perhaps Obsedian, will save the franchise and make a much wanted sequal. Now, there are areas that may turn people away, the combat is invigorating at first but quickly becomes quite repedative, and many of the side quests feel like you are just visting the same dungeon and the doing the  same objective over and over again. Although if you just stick to the main quest, you shouldnt come across this problem. The crafting system is also very limited and is pretty forgettable with the game's competitors blowing it out of the park. But that said it isn't bad either. With the fast leveling up, it feels like the crafting becomes more of a novelty in the late game. So in conclusion, 38 studios, now gone will not be forgotten with this hidden gem in Amalur. I blieve the narrative of the game alone is enough to warrent interest from a new studio to give this ip another chance. Over all a good game, with some sub par RPG elements but with an amazing story and lore. Well worth buying during a steam sale. Score: 7.5

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
												An under the cover game, dwarfed by other releases such as the Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, this game should be viewed in greater light and strength. An addictive expansive world fuelled by a real fantastical scenario and setting, Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning brings strong RPG elements to an otherwise uncomplicated genre. Though this game is stuck between an MMO and a traditional RPG, its combat, crafting and magical elements make this game a strong condendor for anyone looking to play an addictive, massive world game. The downsides to this game may be considerable for some: the purely linear main campaign, the massive open world with no fast travel and lack of considerable and ultimately interesting quests. Nevertheless, it makes up for these pitfalls in interesting dialogue that is both well tohugh out and witty. It is a real blast for any gamer. 8/10

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												I never understood why I never heard of this game and no one seemed to play it.  (According to RPS commenters, it had a crappy outsourced demo, was overpriced, came out same time as skyrim.: http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2013/02/26/why-didnt-everyone-play-kingdoms-of-amalur/#comments )Anyways, I absolutely loved this game.  While I only put 12 hours on my steam copy so far, I probably played ~100 on a different account, and it was some of the most enjoyable gaming I've ever done.Maybe I'm just weird but I love single-player games, and don't really touch multiplayer - I put hundreds of hours into Diablo 1-2-3 offline.  I hear there are a lot of bugs, but I don't remember any.  It was polished, smooth, visually gorgeous and vibrant, and addictive as hell.Combat was just badass.  Seriously, I just saw some of the screenshots on the steam page, and I forgot how amazingly fun combat was, especially with the more unusual weapons like chakras.  This game had one of the most satisfying combat systems I've ever seen.Looks like it's no longer expensive, it's easily worth anything under $20 if you enjoy ARPGs at all, I liken it to Diablo/Torchlight mixed with something like Devil May Cry or fast-paced fluid combat systems.  It's no Elder Scrolls game, but if you play it casually and just expect to grind through a bunch of enemies surrounded by lovely scenery and have fun for a while, it's totally worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												Just got done beating this game, its DLC and numerous side quests.  It's the most fun I've had with a game in quite a while and highly recommend it.  I'm a fan of action RPG games like Diablo, Skyrim, etc. but not too much of a fan of Witcher (too many lengthy story pauses) and Dragon Age (clunky keyboard/mouse combat).This game has a great story woven throughout, and the excellent keyboard/mouse controls coupled with so many places to explore really won me over.   The level designs are excellent and each region of the game world really feels unique.  I also loved the reckoning mode which slows everything down and allows you to perform special kills which were very satisfying.  The character voice narratives are excellently done too.  Quest markers were easy to follow, and didn't experience a single crash during my entire playthrough, unlike with the Gothic and Sacred games which disappointed me in this regard.If I had to give "slight" complaints, I would say the overabundance of purple unique items.  Making it more rarer to obtain these unique items would have given a greater sense of excitement when finding one.  Also, you will want to increase the difficulty which is not a usual practice of mine as I typically play games on Casual or Don't Hurt Me mode.  The easiest difficult option in this game is just way to easy.Overall, an outstanding game for those PC gamers who want a great exploratory experience and fun combat to boot.  I work for a living and don't want to be overly challenged when I find some time to game, and this game really hit the mark.  I give this game a 10 out of 10.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2013
												For 20 hours, I wanted to like this and tried as well. Eventually it became too hard to do so. The world is interesting, but there is too much lore and not enough drama and characterization. The choice of graphical style was very poor and is a complete mismatch to the fairly serious tone. Combat system, skill trees and many other things work well enough, but all collapses in face of the difficulty, or lack of it. It is simply impossible to fail in Amalur, and extremely hard to fall in combat. Crafting is so overpowered that loot becomes inessential and it is easy to kill everything with single clicks. Amalur is not moddable either. There is a difficulty mod, but it actually requires CheatEngine to use!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												So I bought this game a few months ago, not expecting much.  Honestly, I was expecting it to be one of those games I play for a couple of days and then lose interest in.  I was very wrong on that account.  This is actually one of the best, if not the best, RPGs that I have ever played.  There were a few cons of course, but I will get to that in a little bit.  Because The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion was the last RPG I played before this game, I could not help but to make comparisons during my entire time playing this.  In terms of graphics, I found Amalur to be far superior than Oblivion.  When you are walking in caves and you see all of the flora just come to life as you walk past, it is just captivating.  In terms of story line, I would say that they are about equal, but then again, I have not gotten all that far in Oblivion's storyline (I spend most of my time doing the side quests, build my character up some for the really tough bosses).  If I compared Amalur to Morrowind however, I would pick Amalur's storyline anytime.  Because unlike Morrowind, in which the storyline has you do all of these tasks to the point that it feels crazy, Amalur is fairly straightforward.  Voice-acting, I don't really care for.  But from what I can tell, the voice of the characters in Amalur tends to have this almost...ghostly quality?  Almost like you are hearing someone in another room rather than them talking right next to you.  I guess you will either love it or hate, but for me?  I was indifferent.  There are plenty of side quests to take part in, just like in Oblivion.  Like Oblivion, you can take part in faction quests.  Like if you want to be the head of a Mage's guild in Oblivion, then you can do the same for Amalur.  However, while it it can take a few days or so to finish a faction quest in Oblivion, you can knock them out in Amalur in like, a day because the quests are so much easier and there are fewer actual quests to complete for the faction.  There is a huge variety of character customization.  Do you want to play a male or female character?  Go ahead.  Do you want to play as an Elf or a Human?  Go ahead.  If memory serves me right, then I think there are four races to select in Amalur, but the building of the skill-set does not occur until you actually start game play.  Like you do not decide immediately if you want to make your character a mage.  You can decide where you want to place your character's skill alignment later on and even then, you are fully able to go back and change your character's style whenever you want.  If you decide you want a hammer wielding mage, but decide later that you want to have a magic wielding thief or warrior, then you can do that.  I guess now I can get into the overall pro's and con's.Pro's-Absolutely amazing graphics- Wide skill-set available-You can change your skill-set whenever you want with no consequences other than what your character can or cannot wear or what they can do in combat.-Game play tends to be fluid and smooth, particularly with the combat.  You can dodge-roll or teleport out of the way of an attack and the game is not in first-person so you can see more.   I will get to con's later-Once the main storyline is complete, you can still continue on side-quests-Items will not weigh more than others.  While some weapons will impact attack speed, they will still only occupy one item slot in your backpack.  For example, your hammer, while slower in combat than your daggers, will still occupy the same space in your backpack as the daggers.  -There is a hide-helmet option so that even if your character wears a hood or helmet, you will not see it in game play yet you will still have the effects.  I personally loved this feature.-Easier than Oblivion, but the boss fights can still crush you if you are not ready-Good enough that it deserves a sequel-My overall verdict?  I enjoy this game way more than Oblivion.Con's-Camera angles tend to lag every once in a while, to the point where you might have difficulty seeing an enemy-Character may freeze while running.  As in your character will just stop moving while running.  This can be overcome by rolling or teleporting, but it can be troublesome to freeze in the middle of a fight.  Also, this freezing will occur A LOT, and as such you will be rolling or teleporting almost all the time.  It took a couple of days for this to occur to me though.-Voice-acting is so-so.  -From what I have heard, you can only reach level 41.  That is it.  But you can still reset your skill points later on.  Keep in mind though that this means you will not be able to completely max out all skills and abilities.  -I have had difficulty completing a side-quest because every time I try, the game shuts down.  I do need to give it another try though.-Last I checked, the company that developed this game went bankrupt.  So do not expect a sequel or any patches.Overall, I say check this out.  I got it for $9.99 and this game was most definitely worth the price.  It is fun, beautiful, and the ability to change your skill-set helps to take away the pressure of having to stick with one field.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
												So, I missed some things in my previous review. I'm going to break this into parts: Presentation, Story, and Gameplay.Graphically and artistically the game is fine. Nothing about the monsters stand out, but nothing seems phoned in. There are no slow downs. Sound design is fine and the voice acting isn't too bad but........The cutscenes have that dreaded eagle-eye stare. It's like Oblivion except worse. Additionally, the music is fine until you start fighting people. The combat music is exactly the same for every encounter, even the nobody stuff that you can one hit. The only two times I've seen the music change is when you are fighting the Tuatha or a boss. The two other songs are better and actually have some love put into them.The biggest and most glaring problem is the camera. I'll discuss it below with gameplay.The story is about.. um... The elves-I mean Fae! The Fae are broken up into factions and they are timeless, ageless.. yadda yadda. One group, the Winter Fae, has broken off into a new group, the Tuatha, who believe they are bringing a new god into the world. You, the player, are killed and brought back to live by the Well of Souls.Here's where the game gets interesting story wise: Since you were brought back to life, you are no longer tied to the shackels of fate. You can choose your own destiny and change the fate of the... Wait a second, this sounds a lot like Raziel from the Legacy of Kain series. In fact, the concept is exactly the same. With real free will, your character is supposed to change the world. This works really well in the world, and it plays nice.However, the gameplay is flawed. This game was clearly rushed out because a lot of it has zero consideration. Polish wise, everything functions, but there are a lot of things that are out of place. It's really, really easy to gain gold, to the point that you can respect everything into crafting abilities to make new gear, then respec back to your combat stuff. Don't bother with the warrior or mage trees at all, just make a finese character because the dual weapons + bow and arrows are literally the best weapons in the game. By 10 hours in, you'll have so much gold you can easily respect to fit your builds.Now, developers, I have a question for you: Does making the game world bigger make it better? Lemme answer for you.. NO!!!! Reckoning has a low run speed.. But so did Skyrim! But here's the thing... Every time you enter a new area, there are 3~5 new quests to do and they are all the same. Unlike Skyrim, there's no reason to explore areas UNLESS you have a quest. Since everything gives you XP (literally, everything does), you'll run into a problem where everything gets too easy too quickly. I highly recommend playing the game on hard, otherwise it will be too easy. You'll also encounter a problem where you discover an entirely new area that has more quests in it but... everyuthing in the area has a gray name because you were over leveled by the previous area.The big areas are worse with the mini-map and the camera. The Minimap has that problem Final Fantasy XIV had where the only areas you can run are drawn or emphasises. Since there are invisible walls around the edges, the big massive world turns into whatever is pictured on the minimap. The camera only makes this worse because you have to manually aim up to see how vast everything is. It auto-levels to a downward angle of the player whenever you move.Technically speaking, Reckoning is also a Fable clone for combat. You can hit stuff, shoot stuff. It works just fine. But as I have stated above, there's only one real viable option: The finese route. You can mix and choose, like I did for my original 30hours on Origin, but you will HAVE to use the finese armor and skills because they simply do so much output.If you can withstand, avoiding some quests so you can focus on the main quests, the game isn't that bad. Combat can be fun when it isn't insulting easy; and the MAIN story quests and the FACTION quests are worth the time. Just only pay $10~15. Be sure to get the DLC for the quests; but not those extra weapons because they will be replaced within your first two hours of play.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												It's like a linear version of Elder Scrolls if you've ever played one of them. Fully voiced, lots of lore, decent story, quests occasionally have options to alter the outcome, graphics are crisp, animations are mostly clean, there's detail in level design, lootz, crafting (optional) and a "double layered" level up system (able to tech into multiple trees and choose one passive perk). In a nutshell it's a dungeon crawler in 3rd person instead of top-down.Perhaps my favorite part about Amalur aside from above is the feeling of not being tethered to the game in order to notice progression. I can play for just 15 minutes and actually accomplish something.On a minor negative note, Amalur does not give the full freedom other games allow. The player can not jump and the player can not decide to step off a cliff on whim; there are set locations to allow dropping into water or down a cliff-side. Fortunately these limitations do not or hinder gameplay.Combat is straight forward and fairly rewarding. Left click to continue swinging, instill a pause or hold the click to start a special attack. The player can also mix in magic or swap weapons on the fly to make some interesting combos and setups. Though combat may seem too basic the AI does its job in finding those holes in defenses and can manage to really take a chunk of health. While left clicking is easy, positioning amongst groups of enemies is where the player needs to maintain control even though the AI isn't the smartest.I would recommend Amalur to anybody who likes leveling up and combining classes. The game actually feels like a dungeon crawler but from a behind the shoulder perspective.I would also highly recommend downloading the YSA mod which balances the game to make Hard mode actually hard and Normal not such an cakewalk.Additional Thought: It would be nice if Amalur was coop multiplayer though it does a great job as a singleplayer game. If War in the North mixed with Amalur...

												Even a few years after the release I still think that this game is among the best RPGs ever created for console and computer. The graphics plus characters are lovely and the world is as many-sided as it is dangerous. You can do a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of sidequests which sometimes makes you forget what you are supposed to do, but personally, I love that about my openworld RPGs. After 20 hours of playing this game (yet again since I started it when I came out but started over again here on steam) and completing all sidequests so far, I can say that this game is totally underrated and has a lot to offer.Personally I don't share the opinion that this was crappily adapted from the consoles. I've seen far worse adaptions over the years and it's really easy to get along with this one; of course, sometimes you might encounter situations in the menue where you definitely clicked on "Load" instead of "Save" but who the hell cares about that anyway. Go back and make sure you click the right one xD I haven't encountered any bugs or problems with the game so far; not now and not when I played it back when it was released for the computer.So anybody who likes RPGs and open-world and a ridiculously interesting story: You should really buy this!

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												One of the most enjoyable RPG's I have every played, whilst not as visually attractive as games such as Skyrim, The Witcher and Dragon age, it offers a colourful environment which is very pleasing and interesting to view. Kingdoms of Amalur does the mechanics so well with easy to use menus to filter through armour, weapons and other items. Combat is fantastic, it is simple yet there are so many options available to you, with so many different types of weapons. Any 2 weapons can be equipped at one time and mapped to a single button, however this doesn't mean you have to choose between one hulking big hammer as your primary and a piddly dagger as your secondary, you can choose whatever you wish; two handed great sword and a warhammer sure thing! No waiting until the end of the game to unlock cool armour as its readily available from the start, and you will always find yourself picking up new and interesting weapons and armour pieces which makes you feel like you are always progressing. You can change your characters build pretty much when you want for a small fee and aren't restricted to certain weapons for a certain class. Everyhting is down to you and you can make the came play how you want. In addition the game is massive with so many places to explore and quests to complete, they are very samey however they never feel repetative due to the how well the rest of the game plays. Overall 9/10 my only real problem is the fact you can't instantly jump between your map and the quest log. Menus load fast and are super responsive and saving the game can be done in seconds and your back playing (useful when your saving every 5 minutes like me)

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
This is what I wished Fable II and III wereA huge world filled with quests and monsters kill. The game really does appeal to almost every sense of a great fantasy game: combat, exploration, interaction, etc. The camera could be a bit tricky as it did tend to fling around easily, but later in my playing I found that to be beneficial and detrimental to me in combat as pushing a key in the direction you want to attack and not the way the camera faced could be confusing at times, but I adapted. The greatsword is by far the most fun weapon to play with in my opinion. I love games where they truly allow a greatsword to shine- where, when the blade hits something, it hits something. Striking multiple enemies and moving between them all in between swings feels extremely satisfying and really does give you a feel for that fanstical combat with monsters. The animations for many of the weapons are strong indeed, the only weapon I truly disliked were the hammers. Slow, clunky and short range. Staves, chakrams, and faeblades all look and feel very cool to use. Attacking and switching between weapons cancelled combo's and would allow you to be much more variable in combat.The only things that I felt lacked were indepth, meaningful conversation with people, romance and how empty and underused many towns were. Now, no romance isn't necessarally a bad thing, but for rpg's it should be a given- everyone likes it and if you don't, well, you're wrong. Might is right.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												A review for this game may be pointless now. But I feel I need to praise this game for the immense enjoyment I got out of it since purchase. I will say three very positive things about this game.1 Combat balance: While it is true this game is super easy past level 20 or so, the "balance" I am talking about here is the balance between warrior/mage/rogue play styles. Unlike many other fantasy type games I've played, where your mage character usually gets much less choice in equipment compared to warrior/rogue types, here in this game, mages have the equal amount of variety in both weapon and armor selection, and some of the mage weapons are the most interesting ones I have ever played in any game. Reversely, in many other fantasy games, while warrior and rogue characters got more choices in equipment, they got shafted in spells they can use, this is again not true for this game. The rogue and warrior have a lot of interesting abilities they can cast around just like mages. This balanced playing style makes all three schools and any combination of the three feel refreshed and extremely fun for the majority of the game. And if you are like me who feel mages should have as much choice in equipment as other characters you are certainly going to love this game.2 Art style: Kingdoms of Amalur is probably the most gorgeous game I have seen for a very long time. While many mordern games may have better "graphics", they don't necessarily look any prettier. I am in the camp that firmly believes a good art design and style is more important than graphics and constantly find games from 1990s look better than games released in the past 10 years. And while the very particular bright and colorful art style of this game may not be for everyone, it is definitely the preferred style for me. And the game maps is carefully designed so you end up in many majestic positions in game to appreciate the view. Each major city in the game is grand and elegantly beautiful, each region has its own unique charm while all look amazingly appeasing all the time. In summary I think the art style is perfect in this game, if you love it at first sight you will love it for the remainder of the game.3 Sound track: While not many of the soundtracks stand out on their own, the magic thing here is that each of them goes along perfectly with the scenary. Good soundtrack in video games enhances the atmosphere and by that standard each music piece in this game is considered superb. Whether if it is charm, grandeur, danger or mystery the music in this game brings the mood out perfectly.To sum up, this is one of the most fun and beautiful game I have played in a long time. I hope whoever read this review can enjoy it as much as I do with this piece of epic gem.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												A main storyline playthrough of the game itself is only 26 or so hours. Why the ♥♥♥♥ would I say ONLY? The game has a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (200+ hours) of content in sidequests and other content. 200 HOURS!! That's right, crazy. So you're sold on the amount of content, right? But what of the QUALITY. Well, I can confirm each quest, especially a ton of the side quests, has an interesting and unique story that fits into the huge ammount content in this lore filled world. Many of the side quests I've seen allow for alternate rewards and task changing interaction through fully voice-acted dialogue based around your pursuasion (charisma in other games) skill. (Making tue skill actually useful, unlike some games.) The character destiny cards systems encourages awesome hyhbrids of different combat styles and abilities from the three main branches where you can invest ability points. These cards are unlocked based on what trees you invest your AP to add bonus stats and even complete changes to your abilities to make yourself into the exact blend of abilities and strengths you desire.The combat itself introduces a number of skill based fighting mechanics that never seem to lose their weighty and epic feel. This is only added to in the fact that you can make any number of crazy class combinations to tailor your combat experience. Not to mention the weapon and gear options that are also complimented by the epic skills system.The complexity and depth added in the alchemy, blacksmithing, detect hidden, dispelling, lockpicking, mercantile, pursuasion, sagecraft, and stealth skills furthurs the great sense of benefit you get from investing in one skill each level. Each skill builds to greater perks as you invest furthur along in one particular skill, but the gut wrenching decisions you face in deciding where to invest next are what makes you realize the importance of each skill, and the role they serve.The progression of the game overall is at pretty much whatever pace you play at. If you want to rush to train for that next ability, do it. You will be fine, although you might want to bring some extra potions. If instead you want to do some side quests and join guilds for added benefits and rewards, do it. In fact, you can maintain a balance of both. The only qualm (not even that) I have is that if you progress to a furthur area and return to do some quests, they can in some cases seem too easy after becoming more powerful. Which, I don't see it really as a game flaw, because it is just the nature of the RPG genre. For example: after having defeated a dragon and then returning to kill some slimes of any typical rpg would be a walk in the park.I've been through just the tip of the iceberg, and there lies a journey of trials and triumph awaiting you. So,please buy this game, not for me, but yourself. You'll be glad you did.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Essentially, this game is an EA verison of Elder Scrolls and just as incredible. I've only just begun playing this  game and I'm already taken in by it. From it's immersible gameplay to it's unrivaled scenery, the game is perfect, to say nothing of the epic weaponry. There are four races to choose from with each having it's own unique attributes and the choice of a deity to allign onself with or not at all. There are perks to choosing a deity. Also, like in the Elder Scrolls franchise, you may design your own character down to the facial tattoo, though the designs are less numerous than those in Elder Scrolls, meaning you can't adjust the eye width or scowl lines or anything of that nature. You can, however, choose your own destiny as either a Rogue, an Acolyte, or a Brawler. Overall, the game is an unbeatable 10/10 with it's amount of quests and side-quests. I'm only at Level 3 and I've already found three unbelieveable suits of armour, shields, and weapons. This game is well worth it's cost.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Definitely one of the best ARPGs that came out recently.The combat system is really well done. Not only the control feels smooth, you are also given so much freedom to find your own play style. You can equip any two weapons and four spells at a time, and you can mix them however you want in combat. Not to mention the weapon crafting system and the gem crafting/socketing system that further enchance the customzation. Either you want to be Gandalf or Geralt of Rivia, it's all up to you. There are also classes, or Destinies, for you to choose and change at any time.One thing I don't like is the dodging. It's hard to find the right timing to dodge an incoming attack, at least for me. I think it is caused by the slight delay before your character makes a dodge, or I just suck at dodging. Hey, guess what, I can also block with my shield and it doesn't take a weapon slot.The blend of sword and magic and the stylish art style remind me of the Fable series. As far as combat goes, KOA:R definitely does it better than the Fable series. However I don't find KOA:R's story is intriguing enough for me. "Wow your fate is blank" "You'll save the world" blah blah blah. I still enjoy the gameplay, at least.One last thing, you can hide your helmet!! 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Kingdoms of Amalur is a "should buy" for anyone into fantasy CRPGs. Why not a must buy? It is a game and apparently a game franchise with no future. It plays far better with a controller than it does with a mouse and keyboard. What about the good stuff? If you don't like crafting, you need not engage in it; but, if you are into crafting, there are opportunities to build some crazy good gear. Potions are kind of hit and miss, but you won't regret being able to make health regeneration and healing potions. Overall, crafted gear is not as critical as it can be Skyrim; and potions are definitely more useful. I really liked the combat system with its combos and different types of attacks working better/worse for different foes. There are opportunities to crank up the difficulty and win by thinking your way to victory. Alternately, you can reduce difficulty and just button mash your way through . . . should you fear the joystick and the nuances to combat. Each of the three major types of character archetypes yields a different playing experience. The story and RP aspects of the game? Given the pedigree of those involved, this was actually little disappointing. The story arc isn't bad, but it is not as rewarding as, say, Dragon Age:  Origins or the first installment of Mass Effect.  The DLC is actually pretty good if you can forgive the grindiness of Naros and the silly in Dead Kel (some will find the silly endearing . . . others not so much). Some of the faction quest lines are actually good to very good; but the relationships you build with the factions comes to crashing end when the faction quests end. At the very least, this is a missed opportunity.I have no regrets buying this game when it was on sale.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												Underdog detected :)PROS- Truly HUGE world.- An amazing amount of quests, a lot to do- Three classes with that play very differently because of their skills- High polish and optimisationCONS - Weird to say but the game is so huge that sometimes it can be discouraging :) But this is not really a con, mostly we have been playing short games for so long that we lost the attention span required to play a game for weeks.- Some of the lore can be boring sometimes. I find the fae to be a boring race for exemple, bunch of broken record playing the same songs again and again. But it fits the story and the world setting, i just wish there were more diversity in the culture of the world.REVIEWThis is a huge game and deserves a long review, but lacking the time suffice to say that it is an excelent RPG, and fairly unique in the way it tastes like an MMO because of its scale.I am not sure why this title didn't do better, I can't recall but i think at the time it came out there were 3-4 big titles coming out also and they completely overshadowed this game. I guess most people didn't have the budget or the gaming time for another 60$ title. I only grabbed this recently because it went on sale, and certeinly don't regret it. I got about 90 hours out of it already after finishing it (not a full clear mind you, a lot of quests and some exploration still left over), and I still have the DLCs set aside.Some advice : If you get slightly bored in your play, respecialize as another class. I went through all the 3 classes in my single playthrough, and it helped keep things fresh. The game certeinly doesn't warrant a playthrough with each class as it would be too repetitive, so might as well experience all classes on the same go.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
												Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is this astounding combination of open world RPG along with the hack & slash style, yet it also encompasses this unique theme which I have never experienced in any video game: Fate. The story makes you realize how people live their lives knowing their end, their fate, their imminent demise or wonderous growth. The storyline itself is immpecable and is one of the best I have ever played through. You can play your character the way you want, you can choose your own destiny and you have absolute control over other people's destinies, as it is revealed to you. Gives you the feeling of a demi-god, so to say !As far as any shortcomings go, there are only a couple. Owing to the fact that it's an open world game, so the amount of resources and items present are uncountable, so if there was a steady offline guide, telling you about each of said items, that would have been fantastic. Some might say that would spoil the experience of figuring out things, but that's my opinion. The other shortcoming is that the amount of running around that you have to do initially, can really tire someone in real life(Don't worry, your character won't be tired though!) and it becomes quite the task running around from one place to another. That said, the running around gives you an ample opportunity to explore Amalur and deviate from quests, thus making the experience very non-linear. Since there are, in fact, as I quote SSoHPKC, "a butt-ton of quests", you will never be short of them and will always have something or the other to do as you progress through the game.In conclusion, you have to play this game for the experience and the gameplay that you honestly, will not find anywhere else.  I regret not playing it when it came out, but you should buy it while it's still on sale ! It is definitely worth the small amount.

This game apperently came out around the same time as Skyrim and because Elder Scrolls always gets so much hype, people forgot about it I guess.Here's the thing though. Then I think this game is a good choice.I'm a bit of a loot snob and I prefer elder scrolls series for a few things, total customization, wide world map (this game has walls, lots of guiding walls like Fable does and like Elder Scrolls does not) and HEY, if that guy i just killed was carrying two sword a crossbow and chainmail armor, I want all of that, whatever he was saving for lunch, and the gold in his pocket.Because I am a looter.  Fable doesn't give you that much loot.  This game doesn't give you that much loot.(but hey, the gear is pretty wicked.)TL:DR, This game compares far more to fable then it does to elderscrolls. you like fable style games? buy this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												Game Name: Kingdoms of Amalur: ReckoningDeveloper: 38 Studios / Big Huge GamesGenre: Role Playing / RPG History: I first played Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning on the xbox 360 2 years ago about 6 months after it's debute. I loved it! I saw it on sale on here and picked it up. I had a blast playing though it a second time.Story: You are the "Fateless One" you start the game off as a dead body. You are dumped down onto a pile of bodies in what seems to be an incinerator room. Shortly after you wake up and find the place you are at under attack. As you progress though the story you find out how you came to be, and that you have no "fate" and are able to change the fates of those around you. This leads you on a quest to stop the evil  Tuatha Deohn, their King Gadflow and  their God  Tirnoch all of whom want you dead a second time.Game play: This is where is game shines and also falls short. You can chose from any combination of three classes Warrior, Rogue, or Mage. You have many skills and a very well done progession tree. You can also redo your toon anytime you want at a fatewaver for a price. This is very well done to me it allows us the players never to be tired down to one class. If you want to be a mage and use a greatsword as your main weapon do it!! You also have a unique power to fateshift enemies. This grats an experience bonus and each enemy has a different fateshift death all of them are really cool. The monsters in the games quests level with you but, on the open world map they have set levels. This ensures that you can't get too far ahead as enemies will start to one shot you before too long. As for the games difficulty it's a very easy game. They made it way to easy to make your toon unkillable ( Unlike in skyrim where there is an armor cap making heary armor useless accpet for looks as you can never get past 80% damage reduction ) In this game there is no cap at all on armor or resistance. I had made my toon almost unkillable by about 20 hours into the game. That's where is falls short the first time. You should never have a "no cap on armor or resistance" always cap them at least 80%. This also made to me all the sets of armor pretty useless. None of them could come close to what I could make just by socketing a few gems into dropped armors. This also sets the game up for you to have a lot of fun making your perfect unkillable toon though. By the end of the game when you have access to flawless blacksmithing you can in fact make a toon that cannot be killed. I had a great time making my unkillable mage with -100% mana costs. I had a blast just slinging spells left and right completely obliterating all that opposed my demigod powers!Where is game really falls short is making the people and stories interesting. After the first few hours of gameplay I found myself skipping all the dialogue and just following the yellow circles on the map. The people are boring and the way they talk in that monotone voice set put me to sleep. Only a few of the main assist charactors have thier own unique models it. Everyone else in the entire game pretty much looks the same. I found this to be very boring. They could have used more soundbites as well... I hated running though adessa every single gnome says "What!!" as you walk past and all the humans say "yes, aye" just one trip made me mute the sound till I left the city. If they had made the toons more unique and added more soundbites it would have been so much better.This game is still soild in the gameplay field 7/10 Graphics: The graphics are nothing special they seem to be really basic to me. They are cartoonish and fun. They don't try to make you go ohhhh wow..... they just do their job. That's really the best way I can describe them again just solid 6/10Audio: This game is fully voiced although sometimes you mite find yourself muting the volume. The tones are so boring no emotion, everyone is like a robot. The soundtrack is decient The battle themes and town themes fit where you are and what you have doing. It's all really average. 6/10Pro’s/Con’s: ProsWonderful combat systemVery well done skill treesYou can fateshift enemies killing them in amazing ways.many armors and weapons to chose fromyou can make your own armor and weapons (to Godly Standards if you want)many, many quests!!there are some funny moments with glitchs in the game, like people walking though or getting stuck in walls that'll make you laugh.Cons I can sum up the only real con with this game. I will not remeber anything about it other than combat after awhile. Everything not related to combat was boring!! Compare this to Skyrim where I can tell you the whole story and recall most of the peoples names even after having not played it for so long. With this game that I beat just latenight I cannot recall the names of any of the people accpet Gadflow, Tirnoch, Agarth and Alyn Shir. Everyone else I have forgot as it just didn't hold my interest at all. Overall:  This is a wonderful game to play just to pass the time. If you are looking for a game with a Story and Characters you can really sink your teeth into to me it's not this game. If you are looking for a game where you can kill all that oppose you or protect all the weak with your godlike powers this is perfect. To really sum it up this game has amazing combat and that's really it, everything else is just average. I give this game a 7/10 I had a wonderful time killing each and every enemy with my fateshifting powers.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												Great Fun! The characters are pretty wooden, although they try to add some humor, that said the most humor I have is smashing down anyone, yes you can smash down almost every character. This can detriment the game a little, I smashed some people in a market and missed the chance at an inventory, but at the same time I smashed some blind followers on an island and got good armor.I found one breaking bug on the Dead Kel DLC, didn't bother me too much cause the game is so fun, also take it of full screen mode but keep the native resolution to reduce the frame rate issues, it doesn't actually take it out of full screen  but solves issues. What I like is that it doesn't try to be realistic or serious, like ahmm, oh no there's a big dragon. You've got dialogue choices where you can belittle characters for taking themselves too seriously, more fun. I have a sword that's bigger than me and ancient frisbies.As I said it's fun and funny, the beasts look incredible and they're diverse, the combat makes you feel like a megalith, you can become very overpowered very quickly, but you can challenge yourself by resetting your class and reassigning points or mixing your class up.I really enjoy this game, it's fantasy, colorful, full of loot and funny. It constantly reminds you, that you are in a fantasy world and absolutely rips into it if you want.I disagree it's anything like an MMORPG, it laughs at itself, it laughs at RPG's and then say's cause it's fun and that's the way it's meant to be. If you're looking for a game that's bright, energetic, fun and funny, doesn't take itself to seriously, I find that it is a bit like the Borderlands of the fantasy realm with more dialogue choice and I love borderlands.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												Great game, i have this game in my library pretty much since it was released and never got to try it out, but a few weeks ago i found a documentary about the downfall of 38 studios and found that this game was some kind of test for much bigger tittle that never come to see the light of day (one thing is certain, if it was better that this one, its a shame that never got completed).Im doing this review now bc the game is on sale right now, im at 104 hour in game and didnt completed the game yet (but i usually do every side quest, look every rock and that kind of stuff but didnt touch in any of the dlc story yet, so my money is already worth while).This game is kind of the Fable Lost Chapter with few diferent combat mechanics, many side quests to do, tasks, some story choices that turn things out for good vs evil, and a very well scattered Lore behind all life in Amalur, and believe me, so much Lore, backstory, insane amount of dialogs that you could build another story just was much was rich was this one.The combat is satisfying but there are a few things to keep in mind and avoid to ruin the experience, never enter dungeons before any task told you to, to keep enemy at your level and avoid overpowered character early in game, you cant really do nothing outside of them bc after while, doesnt matter where, enemys are much lower level that you, but dungeons, always bring enemys to your current level.Tasks are a good way to get money or materials since they never end and you can always get the reward for completing them since the moment you accept them.There are so much information to be found in the world, that if you like this kind of background story like me, you have so many hours to get entertainement out of it, and even that the combat sometimes get a bit repetitive, it doesnt really detach you from trying to know more about everything.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Kingdoms of Amalur can be too easy, its camera is horrible with a controller and the controls are worse with a keyboard, its quests have a "quantity over quality" feel to them, it has the kind of game progression that would be best suited for an MMO, some of the most interesting parts of its world are often told bland and confusingly instead of shown and its story commits a giant sin by being about choice and freedom while offering little of either. Also, its level cap is quite low.Why am I recommending this game, then? Did my finger slip, making me click "yes" by accident?Well, this is one of those games where no matter how many annoying or bad points I see, in the end I find myself enjoying it immenselly. It has all those bad things I mentioned, sure, but the timing-focused hacky\slashy\dodgy combat is super enjoyable, the region based world is both easy on the eyes and enourmous without feeling empty, and the characters that inhabit it are mostly interesting even if the game's way of presenting them isn't.Yeah, it's still a hell of a lot of negatives coupled with a few positives, but... well, I still really enjoy it. I think this might be the kind of game that, like Skyrim\Fallout 3 or any other of Bethesda's recent titles (mods aside), is worth way more than the sum of its parts.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												Kingdoms of Amalur is your typical fantasy open-world RPG. Its fantastic combat system has you pulling badass moves right from the start, rewards player use of variety and offers a well thought out skill progression. The level scaling unfortunately makes the game too easy later on. The environments are lush and visually spectacular with a huge amount of variety. Despite this, its populace are cookie-cutter NPCs and you’ll fatigue from the hundreds of quests constantly being thrown in your face. The resulting little characterisation makes it hard to get invested into this game. Combat and exploration are its saving factors.

												A very good game that somehow slipped past me before. If you like Singleplayer RPG's with questing, leveling, crafting and learn new abilities every new level, but also like some action as well then this is a game to look into. When fighting mobs you need to learn how to dodge fast, or use your skills to outsmart them. Also your healthbar doesn't go up by itself when cowering away in a corner for a few seconds, so you need to use potions or level up or even visit a Healer in town to heal you and the healer can get also rid off curses that you have on you.There are loads of quests to do, and quests can even have a different outcome sometimes on if one of the smaller stories end well yes or no. You can follow the path of a warrior, rogue, mage or anything in between while you level. Loot, buy, steal or craft your new gear yourself, brew potions. You get loads of playtime for the price of this game.The story is very well done and the graphics are good as well, and the animations of the monsters are great, and they have some very cool moves they use against you. Only downsides I noticed in graphics was that when in cutscenes/talking to NPC's the camera is zoomed in and weapons on your back may be in front of the face of the person your talking to and the weapons aren't too detailed up close.One last notice is that this game is best played with a XBox360 Controller. Mouse and keyboard works as well right away, but I  used my controller after a few minutes because the game seems to be made for it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												A really enjoyable ARPG with open-world feeling, crafting, and console-like combat. It would be easy for this game to fall into the trap of not doing anything well, but it's a lot of fun. There's some great voice acting with a pretty good story for immersion, satisfying combat and a decent amount of challenge. A ton of quests to do means you'll set off in one direction and get entwined in a town's story when you were intending to do something else, and that's a good thing. This is also the case with "shinies" on the ground - alchemical ingredients and loot chests. My path through the game makes me look like a drunken bumblebee.I highly recommend using a controller for this game - trying to use a keyboard gave me an epic frowny-face until I looked up whether it had controller support. It's much more intuitive that way, though you'll still need to glance at the controls listing from time to time when starting out.I received a bunch of OP-feeling gear when starting out, I think due to the complete DLC pack, but I happily received some upgrades fairly early on. Leveling occurs at a decent pace - enough to keep you feeling like you're getting somewhere, but not so fast you don't have time to stop and smell the roses.I almost feel guilty having gotten this game at 75% off during the Steam Summer Sale. This is a rare game that feels worth the retail price (especially since it was only $20 to begin with).

content:
Posted: March 2
												Okay, as of now I am 16.8 hours into that game and my impression up to now is that this is definitely a hidden gem! With almost all of the games coming out nowadays that focus on realistic graphics, I was a bit sceptical when I saw this. The trailer looked okay as well but it didn't look quite that impressive either.And oh boy, I was wrong to doubt this game! The graphics turned out to be one of the pleasing aspects of this game, making it feel quite unique. It has a comic look to it and the landscapes are very colorful but that doesn't stop the stories of the questline from being dark and even gruesome at times. It's just the artstyle of this fantasy world and I love it!The combat takes some getting used to at first but ends up being extremely fun. I also did not expect much of the story either but until now the quests seem fun, interesting and there are many choices to be made! Great voice-acting! I'm still getting into the lore but from what I've seen/heard/read it seems very good as well.I haven't encountered any glitches yet and I hope it stays this way. I am indeed considering buying the dlc's.To anyone pondering on whether to buy this or not: I can only say I definitely recommend this game for anyone that loves a good fantasy rpg, and if you happen to catch this on sale it's a must have! (remember I am only 16 hours into the game but you'll spend more money and less time in a pub for the same amount of fun. Unless...)The trailers do not do this game justice!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												I would HIGHLY recommend this criminally underrated game. I haven't played as much as I would have liked on the PC version, but I played this game to death on the 360. I'm hard-pressed to think of any major complaints about Amalur. It's got a big world to explore, tons of quests and factions to join, a great crafting system, fantastic combat, and a superb character progression/skill system. I've got to go into detail about the skill system because it's one of the best I've ever used in an RPG. Amalur's skill/progression system lets you seamlessly blend together aspects of different builds effectively. All talents are broken down into Might (warrior), Finesse (rogue), and Sorcery (mage), and you can focus on one, mix the two, or even build into all three. If you focus on one, you'll be able to reach the higher-tier abilities faster. Whereas if you divide your build you'll have more variety and options in combat, but it will take longer to reach those endgame skills. You can mix as many or as few skills as you'd like; there are no wrong choices. Not only that, but as you build through the trees you get "Destinies" that you can change at any time. If you focus on Might abilities, you'll get Destinies that boost your Might abilities. If you mix together, say, Finesse and Sorcery, you'll unlock Destinies that compliment both of those styles. Each combination of skills has a corresponding Destiny branch, and each branch has its own unique feel that subtly changes your passive buffs/abilities. And on top of it all, if at any time you'd like to respec your character and start from scratch, you can do that for a small in-game fee (albeit one that grows slightly more expensive each time you do it, with the first one being free).In addition to your main talents/abilities, you get specific skills (think things like crafting, lockpicking, persuasion, etc.) that further define your character.The combat is also some of, if not the very best combat I've played in an RPG. Each class archetype (might, sorcery, and finesse) has three different weapon types to spec into. Each weapon type really does feel completely distinct from one another, having their own unique combos, timing, feel, and weight. A warhammer may seem similar to a greatsword on the surface, but when you actually have them in your hands, they feel quite different. You can have any two weapons equipped at the same time, and switching between them is as simple as pressing one of the two attack buttons. Primary weapons go on one, and secondary on the other. You can be mid-combo with a greatsword, and press the secondary attack button to immediately switch and attack with a bow.This game is filled to the brim with content. Places to see, people to meet, dungeons to explore, and loot to plunder. Great combat, great RPG mechanics, and a ton of variety and options.I truly feel like this is one of the most underrated games of its time and I would encourage anybody who is a fan of RPGs to give this game a shot.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												I had heard a lot of crap about this game before I played it, and only bought it because it was 7 bucks with all the DLC included and because I had tried a demo of the game on the 360 a while back and it seemed decent enough. That 7 bucks brought me roughly 77 or so hours of content. I consider this to be a pretty decent deal. The main complaint I hear is that the game is repetetive - which RPG isn't? I also hear it compared to MMORPG games a bit, but the quests do actually have you going to places and doing various tasks rather than your traditional MMO routine of "kill 5 rats." It does have the Dragon Age 2 issue of all of the dungeons looking roughly the same, but that was the only real negative I could think of while playing through the game. The story is interesting enough, the combat while a bit easy at times is variable depending on how you spec your character (one of three styles: warrior, thief, mage ..essentially). You can also mix them up a bit.If you can find the game for as cheap as I did I say grab it. For 60 bucks? I don't think I'd have been♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥I spent the money and got this in return, but I'm not sure I'd buy this over something like Skyrim for the same amount.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												Decent story - relatively satisfying conclusion - and enjoyable gameplay with gorgeous scenery throughout. Immense customization is available and the combat is fast paced, intuitive, and rewarding. It is easy to change your "fate" and try a different play style at any point in the game - I switched back and forth from magic and finesse more times than I can count - and the different unlockable options for combat are really enjoyable. More than just a hack-and-slash, this game encourages you to consider particular approaches for particular enemies based on their weapon type and behavior. At the upper levels you have four or five different moves for any given weapon, all executed through a simple interface - click, pause click, click while dodging, click while blocking, click after parrying. Combined with a wide variety of spells and special abilities, you have numerous options for engaging with a particular enemy, or multiple enemies at once.It was hard to really get a feel for my character, though, since it is clear that in order to complete quests and gain experience, there is a very particular sort of person your character is supposed to be. More options for how to complete certain quests would have been nice. Overall though, it was a great experience and my first playthrough lasted 78 hours. And I'm thinking about playing through it again because I know I missed so much and never even gave the "might" skill tree a chance! 8/10 would recommend.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
This is what I wished Fable II and III wereA huge world filled with quests and monsters kill. The game really does appeal to almost every sense of a great fantasy game: combat, exploration, interaction, etc. The camera could be a bit tricky as it did tend to fling around easily, but later in my playing I found that to be beneficial and detrimental to me in combat as pushing a key in the direction you want to attack and not the way the camera faced could be confusing at times, but I adapted. The greatsword is by far the most fun weapon to play with in my opinion. I love games where they truly allow a greatsword to shine- where, when the blade hits something, it hits something. Striking multiple enemies and moving between them all in between swings feels extremely satisfying and really does give you a feel for that fanstical combat with monsters. The animations for many of the weapons are strong indeed, the only weapon I truly disliked were the hammers. Slow, clunky and short range. Staves, chakrams, and faeblades all look and feel very cool to use. Attacking and switching between weapons cancelled combo's and would allow you to be much more variable in combat.The only things that I felt lacked were indepth, meaningful conversation with people, romance and how empty and underused many towns were. Now, no romance isn't necessarally a bad thing, but for rpg's it should be a given- everyone likes it and if you don't, well, you're wrong. Might is right.
