number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												KINGDOMS OF AMALUR HERE IT COMES THE RECKONINGKingdoms of Amalur was a surprisingly good fantasy game. It has a fluid and fun combat system. It has a generic but decent storyline. But best of all, it has good side quests. Some of them are even more interesting then the main storyline at times.What I liked most about Kingdoms of Amalur, personally... was how you could build your character in whatever way you wanted. You were not tied down to any restricted class. But you could cross-class between three different trees. Don't like what you ended up doing? No problem. You can re-spec your character at any time during the game. Gold is no object, as there seems to be an over abundance of it in the game. I finished the game with over 6 million pieces of dosh. If that gives you any idea how much money you can make in this.The story goes like this. Your character gets killed doing something he or she shouldn't have been. You come back to life by some mysterious means... and you have the ability to control fate. Now it's time for you to go off and save the world. So yeah that's cool and all. We've heard this kind of plot before. But what is best about the game is the journey through it and the quests you undertake throughout. This game has good beefy side quests with rich story and characters. You wont be wasting your time like with a certain other game that just recently came out.. something with Dragons. Dragon Day I think it was called. Anyway, you'll find that there is a ton to do in this game. If you're a nut about completion this'll take you a good 100 + hours to complete. SO clear you calender, ya dig?Weapons are cool. Each weapon has its own unique style and use. I suggest dicking around with all of them and seeing what you like best. I personally enjoyed the chakrams cause you don't see them much in games, and the daggers because they're the only weapons you can do killmoves with on a sneak attack.The game has a big flaw however and this is one I don't usually complain about with games.. but it was too easy. At level 20... 40 being the max.. I was nigh invincible. It's too easy! I played on normal difficulty, so I recommend maybe playing on Hard if you're not new to RPG's and third person action games in general.The DLCs were both great. Teeth of Narnia & Dead Kenan & Kel had a great storyline and plenty of extra and new content. I'd totally recommend picking up the complete package when it's on sale!So am I missing something? Probably. If you have any questions regarding the game, let me know and i'll answer them post haste.Finale Verdict: (4.4 out of 5)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												At time of writing it is 2:40 a.m. so I'm rantingBUT WHAT A GAME HOLY ****Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a gigantic map of living, breathing npcs woven together by a glossy art style and quirky, sarcastic tones for every serious moment. It prides itself for having a wide selection of combat and adventuring styles, from a measly peasant to a brutal war-mage. You'll find loot for days and a fighting system that delivers satisfying crunches with every impact. I picked up six different builds before I settled on one that fit a medium-range capacity with all the abilities to deal with enemies of every calibre. The game punishes as much as it rains down riches upon you, the player. Keep your eyes peeled and your hands on your keyboard or controller, 'cause there's plenty of things to do from killing to talking to throwing out junk to getting blown up by that one annoying trap to crafting MORE gems to discovering an ancient ruin of a city to getting rejected by that one hottie of an elf. Don't ever trust the game to hold your hand; take what you get and give nothing back.Copious praise aside, there were a few factors which tripped over and otherwise pleasant gameplay experience.There were bugs galore, from broken quests to broken npcs to missing items to items stuck in your inventory. A few of the colour palettes used were neon-nized to the point of frying the rods and cones in your eyeballs. There was so much story in the form of books that if you were to read all that AND read the npc dialogue AND run around looking for treasure, you'd be in the space age before you finished. The skill slotting menu and subsequent settings metres were broken in that they wouldn't move when dragged. Lastly, THERE WERE ONLY 2 DLCS ;_______________;I first got this game when I saw Youtuber @SSoHpkc playing it and it looked fun as hellIt really was fun as hell.BUY IT

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												EDIT: After playing more, I can safely say I do really enjoy this game. It's very charming in its own way and the world is pretty big. At the time of this review I've played about 30 hours and I'm only level 10 and still in the starting land!There are some bugs, the camera angle can be annoying at times, auto target is a bit wonky, I really dislike the short render distance (it was ported from consoles so the textures pop in at short distances... just annoying) But overall this is an "underrated" game if I ever saw one. It's a slightly flawed gem that should have gotten more attention. I was very sad to learn the studios went bankrupt after making this game because it didn't sell enough copies :( If it had gotten more attention it would have been given the love it deserves. The guy who made this game put all his savings and time into it and it "failed." So sad.PROS:-Pretty big world with about 10,000 years of backstory/lore (literally)-Graphics actually look pretty nice-"Cartoony" look sort of like Fable or Torchlight-Pretty good voice acting-SOOOO many quests and stuff to do! -Nice easy to learn skill system and flexible for any type of playstyle-Works 100% with a gamepad or controller (I myself use an XBOX controller)-RPG elements like a dialogue wheel and choices that affect quests/story-Unique story with a fairly interesting plot-Celtic mythology and lore which you don't see in many games(I myself am Irish so maybe I'm biased...)CONS:-Short render distance so textures pop in obviously all the time-Kind of weird camera angle FOV but there is a mod which fixes that-Some dialogue is a bit cheesy or repetitive now and then... but I find it hilarous :)-Silent main character... this is a con for me because it's quite awkward to have your character just stare at people during dialogue-Combat is a bit tricky.. sometimes it's difficult and sometimes too easy... Basic wolves and other "fodder" are the most annoying enemy in the game, while single bosses are easy peasy-Pehaps a bit too much reading, VERY dialogue and text heavy at timesI would still give it about an 8/10. If you like Skyrim, Fable, and Celtic mythology you would definitely enjoy this game :)

content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												A main storyline playthrough of the game itself is only 26 or so hours. Why the ♥♥♥♥ would I say ONLY? The game has a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (200+ hours) of content in sidequests and other content. 200 HOURS!! That's right, crazy. So you're sold on the amount of content, right? But what of the QUALITY. Well, I can confirm each quest, especially a ton of the side quests, has an interesting and unique story that fits into the huge ammount content in this lore filled world. Many of the side quests I've seen allow for alternate rewards and task changing interaction through fully voice-acted dialogue based around your pursuasion (charisma in other games) skill. (Making tue skill actually useful, unlike some games.) The character destiny cards systems encourages awesome hyhbrids of different combat styles and abilities from the three main branches where you can invest ability points. These cards are unlocked based on what trees you invest your AP to add bonus stats and even complete changes to your abilities to make yourself into the exact blend of abilities and strengths you desire.The combat itself introduces a number of skill based fighting mechanics that never seem to lose their weighty and epic feel. This is only added to in the fact that you can make any number of crazy class combinations to tailor your combat experience. Not to mention the weapon and gear options that are also complimented by the epic skills system.The complexity and depth added in the alchemy, blacksmithing, detect hidden, dispelling, lockpicking, mercantile, pursuasion, sagecraft, and stealth skills furthurs the great sense of benefit you get from investing in one skill each level. Each skill builds to greater perks as you invest furthur along in one particular skill, but the gut wrenching decisions you face in deciding where to invest next are what makes you realize the importance of each skill, and the role they serve.The progression of the game overall is at pretty much whatever pace you play at. If you want to rush to train for that next ability, do it. You will be fine, although you might want to bring some extra potions. If instead you want to do some side quests and join guilds for added benefits and rewards, do it. In fact, you can maintain a balance of both. The only qualm (not even that) I have is that if you progress to a furthur area and return to do some quests, they can in some cases seem too easy after becoming more powerful. Which, I don't see it really as a game flaw, because it is just the nature of the RPG genre. For example: after having defeated a dragon and then returning to kill some slimes of any typical rpg would be a walk in the park.I've been through just the tip of the iceberg, and there lies a journey of trials and triumph awaiting you. So,please buy this game, not for me, but yourself. You'll be glad you did.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												Essentially, this game is an EA verison of Elder Scrolls and just as incredible. I've only just begun playing this  game and I'm already taken in by it. From it's immersible gameplay to it's unrivaled scenery, the game is perfect, to say nothing of the epic weaponry. There are four races to choose from with each having it's own unique attributes and the choice of a deity to allign onself with or not at all. There are perks to choosing a deity. Also, like in the Elder Scrolls franchise, you may design your own character down to the facial tattoo, though the designs are less numerous than those in Elder Scrolls, meaning you can't adjust the eye width or scowl lines or anything of that nature. You can, however, choose your own destiny as either a Rogue, an Acolyte, or a Brawler. Overall, the game is an unbeatable 10/10 with it's amount of quests and side-quests. I'm only at Level 3 and I've already found three unbelieveable suits of armour, shields, and weapons. This game is well worth it's cost.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2013
												For 20 hours, I wanted to like this and tried as well. Eventually it became too hard to do so. The world is interesting, but there is too much lore and not enough drama and characterization. The choice of graphical style was very poor and is a complete mismatch to the fairly serious tone. Combat system, skill trees and many other things work well enough, but all collapses in face of the difficulty, or lack of it. It is simply impossible to fail in Amalur, and extremely hard to fall in combat. Crafting is so overpowered that loot becomes inessential and it is easy to kill everything with single clicks. Amalur is not moddable either. There is a difficulty mod, but it actually requires CheatEngine to use!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Kingdoms of Amalur can be too easy, its camera is horrible with a controller and the controls are worse with a keyboard, its quests have a "quantity over quality" feel to them, it has the kind of game progression that would be best suited for an MMO, some of the most interesting parts of its world are often told bland and confusingly instead of shown and its story commits a giant sin by being about choice and freedom while offering little of either. Also, its level cap is quite low.Why am I recommending this game, then? Did my finger slip, making me click "yes" by accident?Well, this is one of those games where no matter how many annoying or bad points I see, in the end I find myself enjoying it immenselly. It has all those bad things I mentioned, sure, but the timing-focused hacky\slashy\dodgy combat is super enjoyable, the region based world is both easy on the eyes and enourmous without feeling empty, and the characters that inhabit it are mostly interesting even if the game's way of presenting them isn't.Yeah, it's still a hell of a lot of negatives coupled with a few positives, but... well, I still really enjoy it. I think this might be the kind of game that, like Skyrim\Fallout 3 or any other of Bethesda's recent titles (mods aside), is worth way more than the sum of its parts.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												Great game, i have this game in my library pretty much since it was released and never got to try it out, but a few weeks ago i found a documentary about the downfall of 38 studios and found that this game was some kind of test for much bigger tittle that never come to see the light of day (one thing is certain, if it was better that this one, its a shame that never got completed).Im doing this review now bc the game is on sale right now, im at 104 hour in game and didnt completed the game yet (but i usually do every side quest, look every rock and that kind of stuff but didnt touch in any of the dlc story yet, so my money is already worth while).This game is kind of the Fable Lost Chapter with few diferent combat mechanics, many side quests to do, tasks, some story choices that turn things out for good vs evil, and a very well scattered Lore behind all life in Amalur, and believe me, so much Lore, backstory, insane amount of dialogs that you could build another story just was much was rich was this one.The combat is satisfying but there are a few things to keep in mind and avoid to ruin the experience, never enter dungeons before any task told you to, to keep enemy at your level and avoid overpowered character early in game, you cant really do nothing outside of them bc after while, doesnt matter where, enemys are much lower level that you, but dungeons, always bring enemys to your current level.Tasks are a good way to get money or materials since they never end and you can always get the reward for completing them since the moment you accept them.There are so much information to be found in the world, that if you like this kind of background story like me, you have so many hours to get entertainement out of it, and even that the combat sometimes get a bit repetitive, it doesnt really detach you from trying to know more about everything.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Kingdoms of Amalur Reckoning is your typical fantasy rpg with a few key differences.Firstly the game is structured much more like an online MMORPG with craftable loot , degredation system and wide expansive areas. HOWEVER they is one key difference:The Combat is amazing. It feels smooth and you can feel the impact of your blows on the enemies;moreover, its also quite forgiving  and only really ges hard if you rush ahead of the areas.The games level system is based on a 3 section upgrade system focusing on MIGHT(melee)  FINNESE(ranged and stealth)SORCERY(magic)These skill tress can be mixed in any combination you like which can lead to intresting combinations of abilities and strategies.It also looks pretty good if you into pretty things but the ccamera angle does not do justice to how beatiful and expansive the game is.On the content side of things they is a massive amount of stuff to do in the game and you could sink hundreds of hours into this(I also played this game for like 200 hours on XBOX).Overall would cautiosly reccomend at full price and whole-heartadly reccomend on sale!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												I would heartily recommend this game for anyone who enjoys RPGs and high fantasy games without too many ttropes that have been trod upon one too many times.At first I thought it was going to be like Skyrim, only less engaging and more cartoony.  It is indeed more cartoony, but if you like helping people out, or are a student of Fae lore, then I think you'll find this game quite engaging.  True, I've put about half the time into it as I've put into Skyrim (and I don't have the DLC for this game), but I ended up enjoying the hell out of myself anyway.There's lots of memorable characters; the voice acting is really well done by a proliferation of actors; and at almost all times you'll feel as if you're really in a magical world.  I thought that part was really well done.And to top it all off, it ran really well on my mid-spec machine.

Product received for free
												I had this game on on my wishlist and my good friend bought it for me.  This game start out as a good adventure in a new fantasy world and I was really excited to finally get started playing it.  The first 20 or so hours were really enjoyable trip of collecting quests, beating down some monsters, and reading all of the lore.  I made a point of finishing every quest. Hour 20 - 40, I had had enough of killing the same monsters so I tended to run through dungeons and monsters just so I could finish quests as fast as possible but I was still finishing every quest.  The last 20 hours I was done with the game, I skipped everything that was related to an achievement or the main story and just slammed it home.ProsStory is really goodCombat is pretty fun but there isn't a lot of variability. 5 or 6 moves per weapon.ConsI played on hard and the game was really easy.You will fight the same enemies all game.A lot of quests and items of note in the game are complete rips off of other games but only done half way.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
												An enjoyable single character RPG, with a slightly more arcadey feel to the combat than say Skyrim, but just as fun all the same  (unlike Witcher 2 where I found the combat system very frustrating, fiddly and irritating ;) ). I guess everyone has their preferences though. I particularly like how easy it is to use the advanced moves as you progress, they really hit the mark on how they implement this. Think along the lines of Tekken but much much simpler in terms of move combos.For me the lore lacks a little compared to Dragon Age: Origins.There are loads of quests all of which don't seem to provide too much of a challenge, but they do give you a purpose to explore the game world. The fast travel system allows you to avoid the respawns if that annoys you.Not had any problems running this on Windows 10, only slight issue I have is that it will "flash" out of the game window and into W10 once every time I load the save game, but then immediately returns to the game without an issue. Probably this is where people would experience the problem with crashes. My system is a few years old and is probably mid-range, probably indicating any issues will be local rather than with the game itself. I also have the flashing into windows 10 on other older games from time to time so no big deal.Game bugs? I did get stuck in the floor of one cave system when running during combat, nothing unusual after getting stuck in things in both Skyrim and other RPGs loool, just go back to last save/autosave and sorted.Good crafting system in place, if anything too many options and took me a while to start to get to grips with all the aspects/menus etc, as the manual is lacking in detail and there is not much in game explanation of features, but in the end it is sort of intuitive and works well.Usually I am a keyboard and mouse guy for RPGs, but this works very well with an Xbox360 controller, and made it easier to pick up the aspects of the game - feels like too many keys otherwise :DWhat else to say? Think I picked it up for under £10 with all DLCs and it certainly looks worth the money - graphics and music are fine as well. If you don't want the money based grind of the current MMOs around, and prefer a single player experience, this is well worth a try.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												I had been playing this game on the Xbox 360 for a number of months now and I really enjoyed playing the game. Today, I decided to move up to the PC version, as well as get all of the DLC packs for the game too. It's a shame this game isn't more popular than it is. The story of the game isn't the best I've ever seen (but that doesn't mean it's bad, it's still good) but combat works really well - it's fast, fluid and very responsive. I prefer playing the game with the Xbox 360 controller simply because it allows you to be more efficient (or I just haven't gotten used to keyboard controls yet) but between the controller and keyboard combat is really good. Dare I say it's superior to Skyrim's combat?That's not to mention the really large world to explore with endless objects to collect and many quests to complete - side, story and faction, interesting and challenging enemies to fight, deep lore and really nicely crafted worldspaces - and that doesn't even include the DLC packs. Conversation works similar to how it does in Mass Effect and Dragon Age: Inquisition - you have a wheel to choose various conversation options, which of course affect how a character views you and can dictate the outcome of a quest or even the storyline. I'm a little disappointed that the player character (which you can customize, though not quite to the extent of how you can in Skyrim, Dragon Age or even Mass effect) isn't voice-acted, but then again, the player character in Skyrim isn't voice-acted either, and look at how well-regarded that game is. The game's graphics are pretty good. Obviously for a game that's about 4 years old at the time of this review, they aren't cutting-edge but I am quite happy with how the game looks and how well-optimized it appears to be. I've got the game running with the graphics settings cranked to the max on my laptop that wasn't even super high-end when it was new and it maintains a very consistent and steady framerate well above 45-50 frames per second.It truly is disappointing that this game's developer went out of business and there'll probably not be any follow-up games to Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning (a title which is probably intended to foreshadow future titles, I might add) because it is a universe I wouldn't mind exploring in even greater detail. This game is absolutely worth the $20CAD price ($40CAD for the Collection), and I would recommend the DLC packs as well, even though the base game is very feature-rich as it is, which is something I can't say about most new games released today.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Spent 40 hours in the demo before release (replayed it several times over to try the different playstyles, and used cheats to see everything the demo offered-- it turns out, most of the abilities in the game!), and many more when I owned it on Origin. Of course, the DLC never went on sale on Origin, so during the 2016 winter sale I picked up KoA and both expansions for only $10, the cost of ONE of the expansions on Origin. This game is not without its flaws. It can feel like a single player MMO at times. The story can be a bit predictable at times. And at times, especially the late game, it's rather unbalanced, but thankfully, in favor of the player. Ultimately, though? I had fun. A lot of it. It may feel like a single player MMO at times, but KoA doesn't insist on making you look like some impoverished peasant when you first start the game, so there's that.Gameplay wise, as you level up you put ability points into either Might, Finesse, or  Sorcery. The combination of points invested therein allows you to choose various "Destinies", which are character specializations with various ability prerequisites. You can change Destinies on the fly, though honestly I can't remember for sure if you can respec your Might, Finesse, and Sorcery investments. Each tree represents an RPG archetype. Might the warrior, Finesse the rogue, and Sorcery the mage. Each archetype has multiple weapon types, such as onehanded and shield or two handed for Might builds, Daggers or Faeblades for Finesse builds, and Staves or Chakrams for Sorcery builds. There are a few more, as I recall wands and some kind of throwing knives but It's been a while so I don't remember the details. In addition, your character has a bow with unlimited arrows, but it features a recharging "magazine" mechanic: you have a maximum number of arrows, and if you stop shooting for a few seconds, they will begin to quickly regnerate. I don't remember if Might or Sorcery have any major skills related to the bow, but Finesse users can turn the bow into a veritable weapon of destruction.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												I heard allot of good stuff about this game. It was kind of like the epidemic of everyone telling you over and over again to watch Breaking Bad. "You don't watch Breaking Bad!!! YOU HAVE TO WATCH IT!" and from 100 different people each week until you finally just give in and watch it and realise what the heck you was missing! This game was like that. Every corner I turn I was hearing "Have you played Reckoning yet??" "Dude you have to play Reckoning, Seriously!" So I finally said heck with it and bought it. And there has not been one single shred of regret. You may know how it is to have a ton of games you have purchased in your steam library and you play one for a while and get bored and go to the next for a while. And with so many games you can't fully get into one certain game. And kind of wish you was stuck with just one game so you would be forced to enjoy it without feeling like you are missing out somewhere else. Well this game here has pretty much did that for me. Because there is no other game out there right now comparable to this so my Steam library might as well only have reckoning on the list. One of those games where you are thinking about it constantly when you are out of the house and soon as you walk in the door you push the button on the computer to get it prepped for some playage. If you are an RPG and or Hack and Slash fan this game will be your best friend. You will be buying the T-Shirts and watching youtube videos and drinking out of a reckoning coffee cup you purchased from china off ebay. It really is a great game. So stop reading this right now and purchase it so you can go ahead and get the download started. I love you...er...where did that come from...sorry..

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
7/10As RPG's go, this one is sticks to a classic mold but mixes things up enough to make it worthwhile.The Good: Being able to mix and match between warrior, rogue and mage archetypes is probably the best part of the game. Few other games (outside of Skyrim, because that's in a league of its own) can deliver this well, if at all. Even the storyline plays into this aspect of the game which I found to be pretty damn clever. Plus, if you don't like your current skill set, you can pay some gold and change it. And the gold amount needed is relatively small considering your resetting your skills.The Bad: The voice acting is painfully bad in some cases which can be really annoying. Also, while the mixing and matching I mentioned above is great, combining classes (i.e. rogue and mage) can be a nuisance since it takes an excessive amount of time to get to the next skill tier. There is such a thing a TOO MUCH balance.The Ugly: I found the crafting system to be borderline pathetic. Minimal depth to it and using a skill doesn't improve it at all but merely gives miniscule generic experience. On another note, the quests often spread themselves out too much forcing you to traverse half the map to complete many quests rather early in the game.Long story short, if you want a fun, easy to play RPG with some unique quirks (good ones at that), then pick this game up!

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												The game is well-paced as an action RPG. But, because it was formerly an MMO in development, the whole structure suffers, somewhat, from a multitude of bland quests. Later in the game I've noticed some botched up voice acting too. However, these are just the flaws put up front, the game itself is glorious in it's features. The storyline also happens to be quite good, although the end is totally expected yet not disappointing in terms of combat. All things considered, the game is a long trek for completionists, one which I hope you will find enjoyable too. Have fun!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												The best way I could describe this game is World of Warcraft meets Skyrim.Amalur has a lot going for it in the way of efficient dialogue, skilled voice actors, spectacular combat animations, and masterful music.Amalur falters, however, in inheriting the problems of WoW and Skyrim: frustrating inventory system (at the beginning of the game when you don't have a Stash yet), tedious quests, repetitive fights, very long travel distances, and not the most engaging plotline I've followed.  The game kind of feels like it's trying to be too much for too many people; the way instructions are worded makes one think this were an introductory RPG (as compared to much more detail-oriented games like Divinity).  This irked me, strangely.I still recommend the game.  It's not "bad" per se, but falls short on too many levels to keep it from holding more profound players.  It's a 60-hour hack'n'slash with some great role-playing bits (not in terms of the story, ironically, but in how you want to approach combat) that you might like in spite of the amount of running you do.  Suggest picking it up on a sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19
												BEST. FANTASY. GAME.EVER. I prefer it to Skyrim, I had a serious injury and was housebound for a long time. I started with WoW which was cool an novel, but it never really grabbed me and pulled me in. On a whim I bought Kingdoms of Amarlur, hoping to have it deliver a WoW like single player experience.  KoA:R did all that and then some! I'd say it's my favorite RPG/Comnat game by a pretty wide margin. The stories are amazing, the harvesting of alchemical reagents isn't too hard (like in WoW when you'd have to circle one zone for hours just to get the mats for one potion) but it isn't a total gimmee either. The combat is real time, meaning that you actively block, dodge, pary, and counterattack as you get more used to the controls. The story could EASILY be made into a movie. The graphics are great by 2012 standards, and certainly no worse than WoW, and the non-linear progression of the story is amazing. If you get the Teeth of Naros and Dead Kel extension packs you can get a stupid amount of playtime out of it; both first time through and replay. I spent a lot of time tweaking out my main character into a God in the game, and wound up spending 244 hours on that one toon. I alo have several other character since I wanted to try all the different combinations of  Warrior/Mage/Ranger/Assasing and various mixes of them. You have total control over the developmet of your character, but be aware that if you kill an NPC, dude is GONE, so ne sure to preeditate, becaue some of the decisions you make have far reaching consequences.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												I had been playing this game on the Xbox 360 for a number of months now and I really enjoyed playing the game. Today, I decided to move up to the PC version, as well as get all of the DLC packs for the game too. It's a shame this game isn't more popular than it is. The story of the game isn't the best I've ever seen (but that doesn't mean it's bad, it's still good) but combat works really well - it's fast, fluid and very responsive. I prefer playing the game with the Xbox 360 controller simply because it allows you to be more efficient (or I just haven't gotten used to keyboard controls yet) but between the controller and keyboard combat is really good. Dare I say it's superior to Skyrim's combat?That's not to mention the really large world to explore with endless objects to collect and many quests to complete - side, story and faction, interesting and challenging enemies to fight, deep lore and really nicely crafted worldspaces - and that doesn't even include the DLC packs. Conversation works similar to how it does in Mass Effect and Dragon Age: Inquisition - you have a wheel to choose various conversation options, which of course affect how a character views you and can dictate the outcome of a quest or even the storyline. I'm a little disappointed that the player character (which you can customize, though not quite to the extent of how you can in Skyrim, Dragon Age or even Mass effect) isn't voice-acted, but then again, the player character in Skyrim isn't voice-acted either, and look at how well-regarded that game is. The game's graphics are pretty good. Obviously for a game that's about 4 years old at the time of this review, they aren't cutting-edge but I am quite happy with how the game looks and how well-optimized it appears to be. I've got the game running with the graphics settings cranked to the max on my laptop that wasn't even super high-end when it was new and it maintains a very consistent and steady framerate well above 45-50 frames per second.It truly is disappointing that this game's developer went out of business and there'll probably not be any follow-up games to Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning (a title which is probably intended to foreshadow future titles, I might add) because it is a universe I wouldn't mind exploring in even greater detail. This game is absolutely worth the $20CAD price ($40CAD for the Collection), and I would recommend the DLC packs as well, even though the base game is very feature-rich as it is, which is something I can't say about most new games released today.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Spent 40 hours in the demo before release (replayed it several times over to try the different playstyles, and used cheats to see everything the demo offered-- it turns out, most of the abilities in the game!), and many more when I owned it on Origin. Of course, the DLC never went on sale on Origin, so during the 2016 winter sale I picked up KoA and both expansions for only $10, the cost of ONE of the expansions on Origin. This game is not without its flaws. It can feel like a single player MMO at times. The story can be a bit predictable at times. And at times, especially the late game, it's rather unbalanced, but thankfully, in favor of the player. Ultimately, though? I had fun. A lot of it. It may feel like a single player MMO at times, but KoA doesn't insist on making you look like some impoverished peasant when you first start the game, so there's that.Gameplay wise, as you level up you put ability points into either Might, Finesse, or  Sorcery. The combination of points invested therein allows you to choose various "Destinies", which are character specializations with various ability prerequisites. You can change Destinies on the fly, though honestly I can't remember for sure if you can respec your Might, Finesse, and Sorcery investments. Each tree represents an RPG archetype. Might the warrior, Finesse the rogue, and Sorcery the mage. Each archetype has multiple weapon types, such as onehanded and shield or two handed for Might builds, Daggers or Faeblades for Finesse builds, and Staves or Chakrams for Sorcery builds. There are a few more, as I recall wands and some kind of throwing knives but It's been a while so I don't remember the details. In addition, your character has a bow with unlimited arrows, but it features a recharging "magazine" mechanic: you have a maximum number of arrows, and if you stop shooting for a few seconds, they will begin to quickly regnerate. I don't remember if Might or Sorcery have any major skills related to the bow, but Finesse users can turn the bow into a veritable weapon of destruction.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												Kingdoms of Amalur manages to combine an interesting number of gameplay elements. To me at least, it seems to have a similar feel to an older, single-player computer RPG, like Gothic or Die by the Sword - yet at the same time, it contains many modern gameplay features and conventions. The combat is fairly button-combo heavy and is fairly similar to Fable - even the character progression paths (Warrior, Rogue, Wizard) follow the same lines. Each area is filled with NPCs who will offer various main or side quests, and tasks, all courtesy of the glowy exclamation points floating over their heads, as is the trend for seemingly every RPG nowadays (not just MMOs anymore, it seems!) The main quest is fairly good, but it is even easier to get lured off by the sheer amount of side quests and faction storylines to follow. The faction quest lines serve to drive you from one area to the next just as much as the main storyline does, so I suppose that in theory, you could ignore the main quest completely and just play the additional content - there is certainly enough of it to reach the level cap well before the game ends.The game world itself is huge; it's easy to tell that this was designed as a prototype for an MMO, even though it still feels like a single-player map - the way much of it is designed, it's doubtful that it could've accomodated a large number of players. The areas are sprawling, however, though they can be traversed fairly easily on foot, in my opinion, without them feeling like a slog. Even the smallest area map has a number of small nooks and crannies off the beaten path that will yield treasure, lore, or crafting materials - although many of these cannot be acquired without the proper skills to unlock them. While in theory this provides an incentive to return to older areas later on when a character is more skilled, more often than not the treasure is not worth the effort. However, each area is dotted with a variety of runestones that provide you with lore and passive bonuses if you manage to find them all, which encourages full exploration. The game has a robust crafting system that is based upon breaking down items into components that can then be used to forge new weapons and armor, depending on the type. Additional components can be added, if available, to make the final product better, and gems can be added to slotted gear to add extra magical effects (gems, too, can be combined to make more potent versions). While some fairly good gear can be purchased, the best items are rare, expensive, and hard to find - more often than not, by the mid-game, the best equipment you will end up with is stuff that you make yourself. A fairly good alchemy system also exists, with the standard gathering of plants and combining them to discover different effects, then using them to brew useful potions.The game suffers from some bugs, namely in the inventory and quest system. Many quest or plot-related items remain in your inventory indefinitely, and whether or not they take up physical space in your collection seems to be an arbitrary distinction. While the ability to expand your inventory exists, these upgrades are fairly scarce, external storage is limited, and most quest items cannot even be stored - you're stuck carrying them forever. The lack of companions to carry excess items, combined with a limited inventory size, can make loot runs back into town frustratingly frequent. There is also no way to remove unwanted or incomplete quests from your journal, which can develop some annoying glitches once your total number of active quests tops a certain number. The simple gathering tasks you acquire in each town can be helpful to do once or twice, but having one from a place you visited four towns and twenty levels ago stuck in your quest list for the rest of the game can be irritating. While the progression trees are fairly straightforwards and each contain some impressive abilities, the skill system is somewhat cumbersome. So many of the skills are so useful (arguably essential) that you really want, if not need, all of them - and yet skill progression, compared to level and ability gain, is painfully slow. You can pay certain NPCs to train you in a skill, giving you an extra point; however, the catch is that you can only receive this training if your skill is still below a certain rank. Early in the game, this is too expensive to pay for; by the time you can afford the training and return, chances are you will be too skilled to get the training, forcing you to repeatedly re-spec and travel backwards step by step, hunting for each trainer in the order that you found them in, if you want to acquire every skill point available (unless of course you choose to follow the Rogue's path).Sadly, the collapse of the development studio and the lack of any further support for the game makes the chances of getting patches or other updates very remote. This is definitely a game that would benefit from some bug-fixes and mods. The fact that neither of the two DLC expansions bothered to increase the level cap means that even without using experience boosts, you will likely reach max level well before you finish the game (though I suppose it depends on how much of a completionist you are). The inclusion of ten to twenty more levels and some sort of alternate advancement/fourth ability tree would have made a nice addition to the extra content. All in all, I think that KOA:R is an enjoyable game that is well worth picking up for the price. It has a fair amount of replay value and certainly has more than enough content to spare for anyone looking for a good fantasy adventure. The main story, while perhaps not quite original, is compelling enough, and the setting unique enough that it doesn't feel quite as cliched as some of the more standard fantasy RPG fare. While I do not think that it is for everyone, depending on your own personal taste, the gameplay is solid and the game itself quite enjoyable if you can get past the interface/game system bugs.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												It's hard to explain what is so enjoyable about this game. Whilst the map feels vastly underpopulated and it is obvious from the design of the surroundings that this was intended to be a MMORPG, I think that adds a certain charm. Feeling tiny in a world so huge is part of the experience. It did take me a while to get fully into the lore, and I wouldn't say I'm quite there yet, but you can certainly play the game without understanding the fuss about these 'Fae' or why everyone argues over this 'Mitharu' fellow. The DLCs are absolutely fantastic and expand what is already a vast, multi-faceted world. The creativity behind this game is evident in every last corner. Though the character customisation is limited, that is probably a good thing, as I like to spend hours upon hours getting my hero's eyebrows JUST RIGHT. It's also worth mentioning that the customisation extends into gameplay; the class system is, in my opinion, without fault. It's user-friendly, it enables users to play whatever combination of skillsets they choose, and it has a system of specialisation that other RPGs, I felt, were missing.All in all, buy the game. Just buy it. Now.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Similar to Skyrim (and other Elder Scrolls games), but with an "over-the-shoulder" fixed camera system that makes for highly intense combat situations. There are lots of options regarding weapons and moves; and the skill tree adds a layer of customization and flexibility to make the gaming experience a bit more personal. One of the reasons for the comparison to Skyrim is because, just like in Skyrim, you may buy your own home(s) to use as a sort of "home base" on your adventures. My only complaint is that I wish there was a High Resolution Texture Pack (or mod) for this game because the graphics, while decent enough, have been directly ported over from the console(s), as far as I know. It would have been nice to have seen some PC-centric graphics options for this game. Overall, an epic adventure worthy of a fantasy lover's time!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												I find it difficult to find an RPG that I can continuously come back to without getting bored of, and I have played Skyrim. In comparison to KoA, Skyrim is similar, but a little less immersive. The world of KoA is beautiful. The lore and the main story are well-written, and make the playing even more enjoyable. And the combat is fluid, and fun.Let's judge.(COMBAT)The primary and secondary weapon system makes it so much easier to transition from a long-range to close-range weapon, or a slow weapon to a fast, or any sort of pairing one can think of. The different types of weapon (Chakrams, Greatsword, Hammer, Longsword, Daggers, Staves, Scepters, Faeblades, and Bows) provide much entertainment in battle.No complexity nonsense with the controls. Movements are fluid and there are only 2 buttons. Mashing doesn't always work-- dodging is a necessity, making it less lifeless and more active. I suppose it is a little repetitive, but I find it fun, personally. (I might be wrong.)Also, the whole "you choose your own fate" idea makes it easy to go down whatever path you want to, whether it be finesse, sorcery, or might. You can even have hybrid combinations.Cool note: your dodge, if you take the finesse/sorcery route, can be replaced by a short-range teleport, which can later deal poison damage if you teleport through enemies. (LORE)You have what I call "lorestones" scattered all over the world. The loading screens give you tidbits, and the cutscenes are, if nothing else, pretty. Dialogue with NPCs allow you to delve deeper into the story if you want to.I love the whole fantasy-world-in-danger spin.Also, you are "fateless".  You're bound by nothing at all. And you have an uber-super-cool special kill mode.(GRAPHICS)I love games with beautiful graphics. Some pixelated games, too, work well, but KoA is far from pixelated. The faces are smooth, the armor and weapons are pretty, and the world is vivid. Walking through the forests or the swamps or the cities is an immersive experience in itself.(CRAFTING SYSTEM)You can salvage items you don't feel like selling for components, which can then be used to forge the weapon of your dreams. Weapon customization at its finest. You can use gems as supplements, and (this is a small thing, but it's great) you can name your carefully crafted weapon, or armor. Name your longsword "Bootybuster" or something. Not that I would.(THE FINAL VERDICT)Yo, buy this. I was looking for a good RPG for a long while. I bought this along with The Last Remnant (which I also HIGHLY recommend) and found that I loved it.10/10 <3

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												Do you want a game that could be compared as the arcade feeling The Elder Scrolls with with too many side quests to deal with? Then this game is right for you. At the start, you were a dead person, and resurrected by a gnome. Eventually you will be fated to be three archetypes: Warrior (representing Might), a Rogue (representing Finesse), or a Sorcerer (representing Sorcery). During your time, you may swap points around any, or all three of these fields to get a nice mix-match of what kind of character you want to build. Sounds great at the start, but sadly the further you go to see a pattern of go to this region and do mindless side-quests that may get you so sidetracked that you may forget what you were meant to be doing with the main storyline. Especially in my case when I took a year long break because of said mindless sidequests.Combat system is not that bad, but it is not that great either. You are allowed to hold two weapons at a time, yet both, or any of the weapons do have a limiting combo system. Best way to describe is just pressing X X X or B B B with a hint of X "pause" X "pause" X. Catch my drift. Too bad the baddies in the game do not hold up in the variety party. Could be a good thing when you do not have to remember how enemies attack, and can anticipate any attacks.After the combat comes the spoils, and it feels like the loot got spoiled. In the beginning, when you have nothing to use everything is great loot. By the time you come around your twenties or thiry levels the look; much like any dungeon crawler, can be sparse in quality. Even the armor sets could not hold a candle to some of the blue or even green armors that I had been picking up which makes you wonder if picking the lock of an average or higher difficult chest is worth the trouble.Speaking of lock picking; there are skills you can either pick up from leveling or some NPCs that you meet along the way. Most of these NPCs may only teach you so much in skill levels that it can be hard to find ones that can teach you further deep into the high ranks; even at areas where it should be level appropriate. Otherwise, most of the skills can you help you further into your adventure especially one to find all the hidden goodies. I did wish the crafting skills could make armor that would of been your end all to be all armor or weapons.Pros:+ You got PLENTY to do+ Though limiting archetypes, but you can mix them up+ Gorgeous world even at this point of the review it still holds up well.+ Decent skill system with worth while skills to achieveCons:- Too many side quests, but it is up to you if you want to bother- Lackluster loot at the end, and crafting weapon and armor is not much worth it. Shame...- Not much variety of enemies, and not much variety of a combat systemEven though I said a fair share of gripes with this game, but I did played through to the end, even if it was a bit painful if you are one that wants to finish all the quests. Without a middle recommendation, I am still going to recommend, but during a sale.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
												The best way I could describe this game is World of Warcraft meets Skyrim.Amalur has a lot going for it in the way of efficient dialogue, skilled voice actors, spectacular combat animations, and masterful music.Amalur falters, however, in inheriting the problems of WoW and Skyrim: frustrating inventory system (at the beginning of the game when you don't have a Stash yet), tedious quests, repetitive fights, very long travel distances, and not the most engaging plotline I've followed.  The game kind of feels like it's trying to be too much for too many people; the way instructions are worded makes one think this were an introductory RPG (as compared to much more detail-oriented games like Divinity).  This irked me, strangely.I still recommend the game.  It's not "bad" per se, but falls short on too many levels to keep it from holding more profound players.  It's a 60-hour hack'n'slash with some great role-playing bits (not in terms of the story, ironically, but in how you want to approach combat) that you might like in spite of the amount of running you do.  Suggest picking it up on a sale.

Posted: April 21, 2015
												A surprisingly well made game. The graphics is not spectacular (though the combat animations and spell effects are good) and the game does not bring anything really new to the genre, the combat is excellent and the possibilities to progress your characters are many - want to be a rogue with chakrams and combat magic? No problem. Want to be a warrior in heavy armor, wielding huge warhammer and summoning skeletons to help you in fight? Go for it.There is plenty of side quests, usually involving finding something/killing somebody/stealing something. There is not much variety, but the quests lead you through the areas and into loads of combat, so you do not really care as long as you can slaughter some boggarts and brownies (yes, you heard me).The world is quite huge and open, if you want, you can just explore and roam and kill stuff, though do not expect Skyrim here.The game also offers a straightforward crafting system including weapons, armor, potions and socketable gems.8/10Worth your money, worth your time.

content:
Posted: December 9, 2016
												An enjoyable single character RPG, with a slightly more arcadey feel to the combat than say Skyrim, but just as fun all the same  (unlike Witcher 2 where I found the combat system very frustrating, fiddly and irritating ;) ). I guess everyone has their preferences though. I particularly like how easy it is to use the advanced moves as you progress, they really hit the mark on how they implement this. Think along the lines of Tekken but much much simpler in terms of move combos.For me the lore lacks a little compared to Dragon Age: Origins.There are loads of quests all of which don't seem to provide too much of a challenge, but they do give you a purpose to explore the game world. The fast travel system allows you to avoid the respawns if that annoys you.Not had any problems running this on Windows 10, only slight issue I have is that it will "flash" out of the game window and into W10 once every time I load the save game, but then immediately returns to the game without an issue. Probably this is where people would experience the problem with crashes. My system is a few years old and is probably mid-range, probably indicating any issues will be local rather than with the game itself. I also have the flashing into windows 10 on other older games from time to time so no big deal.Game bugs? I did get stuck in the floor of one cave system when running during combat, nothing unusual after getting stuck in things in both Skyrim and other RPGs loool, just go back to last save/autosave and sorted.Good crafting system in place, if anything too many options and took me a while to start to get to grips with all the aspects/menus etc, as the manual is lacking in detail and there is not much in game explanation of features, but in the end it is sort of intuitive and works well.Usually I am a keyboard and mouse guy for RPGs, but this works very well with an Xbox360 controller, and made it easier to pick up the aspects of the game - feels like too many keys otherwise :DWhat else to say? Think I picked it up for under £10 with all DLCs and it certainly looks worth the money - graphics and music are fine as well. If you don't want the money based grind of the current MMOs around, and prefer a single player experience, this is well worth a try.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												I had been playing this game on the Xbox 360 for a number of months now and I really enjoyed playing the game. Today, I decided to move up to the PC version, as well as get all of the DLC packs for the game too. It's a shame this game isn't more popular than it is. The story of the game isn't the best I've ever seen (but that doesn't mean it's bad, it's still good) but combat works really well - it's fast, fluid and very responsive. I prefer playing the game with the Xbox 360 controller simply because it allows you to be more efficient (or I just haven't gotten used to keyboard controls yet) but between the controller and keyboard combat is really good. Dare I say it's superior to Skyrim's combat?That's not to mention the really large world to explore with endless objects to collect and many quests to complete - side, story and faction, interesting and challenging enemies to fight, deep lore and really nicely crafted worldspaces - and that doesn't even include the DLC packs. Conversation works similar to how it does in Mass Effect and Dragon Age: Inquisition - you have a wheel to choose various conversation options, which of course affect how a character views you and can dictate the outcome of a quest or even the storyline. I'm a little disappointed that the player character (which you can customize, though not quite to the extent of how you can in Skyrim, Dragon Age or even Mass effect) isn't voice-acted, but then again, the player character in Skyrim isn't voice-acted either, and look at how well-regarded that game is. The game's graphics are pretty good. Obviously for a game that's about 4 years old at the time of this review, they aren't cutting-edge but I am quite happy with how the game looks and how well-optimized it appears to be. I've got the game running with the graphics settings cranked to the max on my laptop that wasn't even super high-end when it was new and it maintains a very consistent and steady framerate well above 45-50 frames per second.It truly is disappointing that this game's developer went out of business and there'll probably not be any follow-up games to Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning (a title which is probably intended to foreshadow future titles, I might add) because it is a universe I wouldn't mind exploring in even greater detail. This game is absolutely worth the $20CAD price ($40CAD for the Collection), and I would recommend the DLC packs as well, even though the base game is very feature-rich as it is, which is something I can't say about most new games released today.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Spent 40 hours in the demo before release (replayed it several times over to try the different playstyles, and used cheats to see everything the demo offered-- it turns out, most of the abilities in the game!), and many more when I owned it on Origin. Of course, the DLC never went on sale on Origin, so during the 2016 winter sale I picked up KoA and both expansions for only $10, the cost of ONE of the expansions on Origin. This game is not without its flaws. It can feel like a single player MMO at times. The story can be a bit predictable at times. And at times, especially the late game, it's rather unbalanced, but thankfully, in favor of the player. Ultimately, though? I had fun. A lot of it. It may feel like a single player MMO at times, but KoA doesn't insist on making you look like some impoverished peasant when you first start the game, so there's that.Gameplay wise, as you level up you put ability points into either Might, Finesse, or  Sorcery. The combination of points invested therein allows you to choose various "Destinies", which are character specializations with various ability prerequisites. You can change Destinies on the fly, though honestly I can't remember for sure if you can respec your Might, Finesse, and Sorcery investments. Each tree represents an RPG archetype. Might the warrior, Finesse the rogue, and Sorcery the mage. Each archetype has multiple weapon types, such as onehanded and shield or two handed for Might builds, Daggers or Faeblades for Finesse builds, and Staves or Chakrams for Sorcery builds. There are a few more, as I recall wands and some kind of throwing knives but It's been a while so I don't remember the details. In addition, your character has a bow with unlimited arrows, but it features a recharging "magazine" mechanic: you have a maximum number of arrows, and if you stop shooting for a few seconds, they will begin to quickly regnerate. I don't remember if Might or Sorcery have any major skills related to the bow, but Finesse users can turn the bow into a veritable weapon of destruction.

Posted: February 20
 Currently at the time of reviewing this game it is on sale for $5 and all of its DLC $6. 	This game is definitely worth the price because of two reasons:1. The Combat2. The time it takes for completion  $5 = atleast 5 hours but in this case you get 200PROS +AMAZING COMBAT - Its combat is truly amazing it has great fluidity and just overall is extremly fun without getting boring. I just wish there were more skills for me to try.GRAPHICS - Although this game was released in 2012 its graphics still look good with a really colourful environment.OPENWORLD - Just a really nice touch for an rpg.LOOT - One thing that has always attracted me to rpg's is the loot/ special items you can find in them. KOA Reckoning does a phenominal job with having tons of  rare accessories, weapon and armor sets.TIME PLAYED - You can play this game for hours because of the sheer amount of quests and the size of its world.FACTIONS - You recieve special stuff when working with factions. The idea of factions is really cool and even though I like how you can work with all of them there isnt much story for them.REQUIREMENTS - Works great and doesnt require a top end gpu.CONS -STORY - Its story.... well all I can say is that it has one. The story is pretty lack luster and generic in my opinion and the npc's aren't really memorable either.CAMERA - You miss out on a lot of the beautiful environment because the camera angle is facing downwards on your character.RNG/BUGS - I've played through this game so many times looking for all armor sets but due to some unlucky bugs that make chests impossible to open I always quit halfway through due to frustration.BOSSES & Difficulty - The bosses in this game aren't really different from the monsters you fight regularily while playing through the game and the game itself is too easy even on the hardest difficulty._______________________________________________________________________________Overall this game is just great and  really fun to mess around in! I just wish that somehow, someway they can make a sequel to this game.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												Don't let my low game hours fool you. I played this game for over 100 hours on my xbox before I wiped it.[Slight Spoilers]Pros:+This game lets you play whatever build you want to do.     -> Do you want to be a Mage and surprise people by slamming them to the ground with a massive warhammer? Do you want to play a Rogue who uses Daggers for assassinations but can hold her own in normal combat by wielding a Longsword? Do you want to play a Warrior who's only goal is to destroy people in insane combos with a sword that's twice their size? If you answered yes to any of these, please keep reading.    -> Each class has a set of weapons and armour associated with it, as well as abilities. A Rogue, for example, is built on skill points invested into Finesse and uses light/medium armour that gives bonus critical hit damage. Rogue weapons are the Bow, Daggers, and Faeblades. Their abilities are varied between sustaining mana to apply poison damage to all of their weapons to raining arrows from the sky.    -> The Warrior class is built on skill points invested into Brutality and can use Longswords, Greatswords, and Hammers with the heaviest armour that improves damage resistence and blocking ability. Their abilities vary from an adrenaline surge to deal massive damage when close to death to lifting all surrounding enemies into the air and slamming them all down.    -> The Mage class is built on skill points invested into Magic and can use Staves, Septres, and Chakrams with Robes for armour that help improve mana regeneration. Their abilities can vary from chaining lighting to summoning a meteor to crash down on enemies.+Gives the middle finger to restricted builds with the Destiny system.    -> You are not set to one way of playing the game. Just purchase a reset from a Fateweaver and suddenly, you can rebuild your character in their entirety! Go from a Mage in robes with a Staff and Septre to a hybrid Warrior/Rogue who uses a Hammer and Faeblades! (Keep in mind that there are many abilities to each class and you can do more than one class, or even all of them at once if you wanted. When you level up, read up on everything in your abilities tab and decide how the game should work for you.)+Super satisfying stealth gameplay.    -> Say you were spotted by a Jottun (a reverse Dwarf as I like to call them.) You can teleport through them, throw a smoke bomb down, jump on their back from stealth, and stab their neck to oblivion only to backflip off as you watch them bleed out. It's not just the massive enemies that are satisfying to stealth kill! You can sneak up on a Bandit and in quick succession you can trip them, making them land on their back only for your character to cover their mouth and stab their chest. The sneaking mechanic itself is a little bit wonky but oh my gosh it's still amazing to assassinate half of a Tuatha scout party and have the last few left♥♥♥♥♥♥talk you only to get torn to bits by open combat; speaking of which, my next point is close to this one.+Fluid combat system.    -> My favourite build was on my character named "Lorabella." She was a Warrior/Rogue hybrid that used a Longsword and Daggers. In the span of a minute, she can roll behind an enemy in stealth, backstab them, and immediately turn to the other enemies that spotted her afterwards. From here she can toss a smoke bomb or use an invisibility potion to get more stealth kills, or she can hold a weapon's attack (you can only equip two weapons at a time) and use the charge ability to launch herself at the nearest enemy, starting an attack combo which kills them quickly. After that, she can block with her shield at the right moment to deflect an enemy's attack and turn it into a combo to kill them quickly. I could go on and on about how many different ways you can play the same game and still be satisfied, but I will spare you from that.+Fateshifting.    -> In a tight spot? Too many enemies and you just want to go to the next area quickly? Want to get bonus XP for doing what you already do to kill enemies? Just do it™+Fast Travel!!!    -> Seriously who doesn't like this feature?Some cons: -The game can feel very repetitive.    -> Bandits, Fae, some Gnomes here and there, Jottun, Etten, Spiders, Kobolds, and so on. There's not much for diversity in enemies to face, some are just slightly different reskins of the base creature that does something different. See: Kobold Savages are Kobolds that throw their spears instead of try to poke you with them.    -> A lot of the game's quests are a variation of "go here and kill these things for me" and while the combat system is very fun, there's only so much that can be done before it feels like a chore. -Short story.    -> Excluding the time spent running to the new locations, the Faction quests as well as the main quests feel a little short compared to the size of the world given to the player.(Overall, I would say this game is absolutely worth buying. I haven't gotten to the DLCs yet though I do look forward to it! I hope this review helped!)-KEM

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I highly recommend this game. I have a hard time just trying to stop playing when i must!This game is a single player RPG in the likes of skyrim and fable. More like fable than skyrim actually because the choice you make in conversation change the way the world see you.Now where to start, mmmmm well the rpg element is very well done. You actually grow you character the way you like it. There are roughly 3 paths to put skill points in, warrior/rogue/sorcerer. You can put points anyway you want to. You can use any weapon and armor at first, then later on you need to have enough points in the proper class to use a weapon or armor. Still it leaves you with a loooooot of freedom in experimenting with the weapon you like. The questing is similar to what you've seen before, but it somehow is far more interesting. I don't know if it's the way it is written or what. Also, the npc are much more realistic than in any other rpg i've played. They make mistakes, they have goal, they are sad when something bad happen to the one they love. I think because when you talk to them, their lips actually move to the exact words they say make it more real somehow. But there are no animation in the faces for their emotion, which is ok i guess. We still have a way to go to make THAT happen in games. There is an overall story with a buttload of side quests and do it if you want quests where you're probably going to spend most of your time there, like i do. I come back to the main quest once in a blue moon!Professions: You got a boatload of professions: Alchemy, blacksmith, lockpicking/pickpocket, sagesmith, stealth, detect hidden, dispel aura, etc. With alchemy you can find more herbs in the field and blacksmith you can create customized weapons of all kind and armor. They are the most usefull profession, but they are not necessary to play the game. They also take more time and you get less gold with those. Eventually, it might be better to just sell everything you find and buy only the weapons and armor from the merchant. You get 1 new point to invest in profession each level. Also, for at least 2 professions, i found 2 trainers that asked for a lot of gold to raise your profession by 1 point.Battle: The battle is where you will spend the most time in. It's very well made. Very similar to Monster Hunter 3 on the wii and with similar weapons (The greatsword handle almost identically to monster hunter). As you put more skill points in your class, you will gain new moves with the weapon you put skill points in and it will also do a lot more damage. The weapons are: long sword, greatsword, great hammer, bow, fae blade, daggers, chakram, scepter, staff. Some are better for magician oriented individual, some are better for rogue and some are better for warriors, but honestly you can choose your fight style as you wish. Sometime you find a new weapon of a class that you never use, but it's sooooo much better than the one you use that you change (I'm particularly fond of greatsword, but now i'm weilding a freaking hammer!). Also, the neat thing is that you can equip 2 weapons at the same time and use any of the two at anytime in battle! This makes for amazing strategy.The battle itself is very fluid with lots of dodging, blocking and counter-attacks. The ennemy is pretty good, it encircle you most of the time and you have to deal with it. I play on normal level difficulty and i don't remember getting killed ever, but with the easy healing potions and mana, i guess its hard to die. Still, i got close a few times. I never get bored of the battle in this game, it's just THAT GOOD!Stealth: With daggers or fae blades equipped, you can try to do a silent kill on your opponent. You can only approach them when they turn their back on you and it's difficult unless you put some points into the stealth profession. You also need to put some points into backstabbing, because after a few levels, the ennemy won't go down with one hit anymore! I try to use it as much as i can, but honestly there aren't THAT many times that ennemies are showing me their back. Still, the backstabbing should be pretty usefull in battle against big monster that are slow to turn like trolls, golems and ettin. The daggers and fae blade do very fast attacks.Stealing: There are a lot of things to steal in this game. In fact, pretty much in every house. Getting caught can send you to prison or you can bribe your way through. Can be costly. Haven't explored that side of the game, too much honest i guess.Magic: There are spells that you can get by putting enough points in the sorcerer class. You can equip 4 abilities/spells at a time. They are almost all AWESOME. The first spell that you get is lightning bolt. At the moment, i got a freaking earthquake ability that actually show a big earthquake when i use it. I can use it 3 times in a row and the earthquake gets bigger and do more damage. It's fantastic! You can't spam spells tought. There is a small cooldown on each one, something like 3 seconds i think. Also, if you equip mage armor you get far more mana and mana regeneration which is important if you want to use spells often. They are costly. If that's your style of play, then scepters and staff are going to be your weapons of choice. Scepter shoot ranged fire/electricity/frost and staff is for close combat monsters. The staff animation is pretty awesome actually. Imagine that! A mage that is actually fun to play at close combat range too!The graphic are pretty good. The sound and music is good too. The world is vast and there is a looooooooooooot to explore. There are hidden things everywhere, so investing in the detect hidden profession for at least 2 points is pretty important. There is supposed to be hidden doors and i never even found one! But then my detect hidden prof is not high enough i guess. Oh by the way, this game play waaaaay better with a controller than a keyboard. The battle is just made for a controller. I wouldn't want to touch a keyboard for that. It's all in 3D.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												I am extremely impressed with this game, in spite of it's one major flaw which is that it can be easy to "Overlevel" your character quickly. I am somewhat disappointed that there is a level cap, unlike Skyrim, but I believe this could be remedied if any new DLC decided to scale enemies to the character's level, rather than hard lock them by regions explored. At that point, a level cap becomes moot, since enemies would always scale to the character's level and thus keep the challenge high (or at least higher than what is current.The game reminds me of Skyrim in it's use of combat and quests, but the story is deep and complex, and there are literally hours of exploration for those who take the time to do so.It is the story and the versatility of character development which really drew me in. The parallels to Skyrim are quite high, and I believe that Amalur actually was developed concurrently but released about eight months prior to that other great game.All in all, you cannot go wrong with this game. Especially at $20.00 or even lower during weekend or mid-week madness specials. (I picked up Amalur and all DLC content for $9.99 during one such special). It is easily work twice as much in terms of content and play time. (Heck, just look at my hours played! :) )If you haven't seen the hundred+ other positive reviews and decided to buy this one, the let this review be your impetus! BUY THIS GAME! It's awesome :)

												-PRO--satisfying combat.-good story.-character customization.-wide range of weapons.-big maps (with 2 smaller DLC maps but still kinda big).-magics and other skills are useful in many situations.-can change play style whenever you want.-beautiful world.-graphics still looks good.-cool weapons and magics effects.-many many of uniqe weapons and armor sets.-great ai both goes for friendly ai and hostile ai.-many kinds of enemies.-you got your own castle with all the things you need (DLC).-decent main quest play time.-a lot of siad quests.-some enemies with lower levels run away from you.-ai run faster than you in quests that you need to follow them and wait if they got too far which is pretty nice.-CON--some bugs issue.-inventory size is a bit small.-a lot of the side quests are a delivery quests.-some side quests can be pretty boring.-maps can be confusing sometimes.-annoying sprites are pretty hard to hit.-bow combat is pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥overall 8/10  good game

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a game that is well known for its customization, while this is its most strong point, I would like to take the time to point out some of the other incredible things about this game.While the story is kind of lacking in tying into the Lore of the world of Amalur, it does a fantastic job of being a gripping story. You will grow to love each and every character that you meet in the storyline, but there are some you will grow to hate as well. The Voice-Acting is superb, but the level designs are very hit or miss, some landscapes are beautifully crafted and are visually stunning, but there are some that are very much so lacking in beauty and are very poorly designed, that you'll have to empty out your vomit bag after you clear the area. HOWEVER, this are minor setbacks compared to what this game can offer for only 19.99$, I personally rate it as an 8/10, with it also being one of my favorite games of all times.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												The game feels like a more modern version of the first Fable game, and is really what they should have evolved into. The story is fairly straightforward, but does offer the player choices, and while many choices are one off events, your actions do change how NPCs at least talk to you or initiate conversations with you. The game does also have some interesting new fantasy ideas, like the Fae, an elf like race that lives by the stories they tell and are destined to repeat throughout their multiple lives.   Combat maintains a nice balance, with different playstyles being perfectly viable, and some fights will require preperation to have a fair chance of getting through them, but there's no major difficulty spikes. Basic crafting trees like alchemy and blacksmithing are included, and blacksmithing has a nice touch where you break down loot to make into other weapons and armor. The world is large and about as open as Oblivion, with only cities and dungeons having their own instances. And lastly, the graphics have a very WoW like feel to them, but far more technically advanced and nicer looking.
