content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												     This is a single player action RPG. (Kinda like Fable) Kingdoms of Amalur features five distinct regions and four playble races. Almain (Civilized Humans), the Dokkalfar (Dark Elves), the Ljosalfar (Light Elves), and the Varani (Nomadic Humans. The combat includes a 'Fate' system which allows the player to accumulate 'fate points' and enter Reckoning Mode. Which is a slow motion mode that allows you to quickly kill enemies and do brutal finishing moves. The world is very big and lots of side quest. No jumping which is kinda sad, (There is only predesignated spots to jump down from) but there is swimming and you can find some cool spots and side quests.  You have ability to buy homes and upgrade them (A lot like Fable) and you can communicate with , rob or kill NPCs. Which have their own consequences. In all this is a great Action RPG 9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												I love this game a truly underestimated RPG that I discovered by just trying out the demo and a worthy purchase too because the full game has a lot to do with the extra DLC as well it definitely gives you over 100+ like most RPG's. But though the story can be a little confusing at times and especially some of the side quest stories it didn't stop me playing and just listening to everything, The world of KoA is very well thought out the forests at the start as vibrant and colourful to the plain barren deserts it's got just about everything, characters of the world are various from Faries to Thieves to Knights there's a lot of variety in the world. The voice acting is ok not the best but sometimes a game doesn't have to have the best voice acting to be enjoyable. But one thing that makes this game great is the combat system I found it fresh and seriously I never got bored in going into combat not once, because of the different style from swords, great swords, bows, daggers, faeblades and charkhams you can switch to many different styles on the fly because you can use 2 different weapons in battle for 1 button on your controller or mouse if you wish too. Fighting with a great sword to switch to a bow or faeblades to a Great sword is just cool in my book the game does has a stealth system so you can try a Stealth build if you wish in fact you can have a Stealth, Mage, Great Sword Tank or Sword build or a mixture of any it's that well thought out. Magic is also in the game you can use sceptres etc and have different kinds of magic like the usual fire, ice, thunder and poison to your weapons. Magic combat is ok it can be a little slow but again you can mix it up from a bow attack to ice or fire it's your choice to make it different, sceptres make magic a little better by adding charge moves in fact every weapon has unique moves sets that can be unlocked and you can add them into the attacks which makes it even more awesome when going into battle.The PC version does have a camera glitch were the FoV behind your character doesn't seem right in fact a little closer than it should be but there is a fix for it, I would recommend in getting the widescreen fixer mod,  this can be found in the guides section.I would also recommend playing the game on HARD mode from the start for a decent challenge it's not HARD but it gives a better experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning succeeds in some important ways, but in my opinion inevitably falls flat on its face for anyone who has played RPGs before. It really depends on why you play RPGs.KoA has a story that is at times refreshing and inspired, like with almost everything surrounding the Fae and their interactions with your character.  At other times, it is cliche and groan-inducing; just about anything having to do with the "Fate" concept in the game was at best predictable and at worst actually insulting in its lameness. The dialogue outside of story missions was also trite and felt written around a quest that had already been programmed into the game without a justification. This is extra egregious in a game that advertises how a famous fantasy author developed the story.It has an art style that screams in vivid colors and exaggerated animations, which I personally love as a longtime ex-player of World of Warcraft. However, if you're a fan of dark and gritty, you won't really find it here. And honestly, most problematically, the game has a huge difficulty curve problem: it's way too easy. By halfway through the game, I had broken it even on "hard" difficulty. My warrior character, built in an extremely obvious fashion (and avoiding the bugged Last Stand talent), was nigh-invincible and two-shotting everything except bosses, and that's before stacking over 100% damage and several layers of mitigation in potions. The fundamental axis of interaction in KoA is combat; when it becomes so trivial as to be boring, the game falls apart unless you were happy playing on easy anyway.Overall, I really, really wish I could recommend KoA. . . but I think for most people that would read a Steam review, it's just not going to be the right choice.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Of the many action-RPGs around these days, this is one of the more colorful.  Its idyllic fields, rocky heights, and stinking caves are very pretty, in a cartoonish sort of way.  So are the expressive NPCs, viscious beasts and so forth.  Of course, no game has an infinite array of palates and textures, so those stinking caves get very familiar, very quickly.Compensation for "same-old-dungeon-itis" comes from the combat system.  As you level up, you gain new combos you can use in different situations.  Different weapons gain different powers, and you have the freedom to use your skill points to get more than one weapon to maximum level if you want.  Experiment with saving, then using your skill points so you can reload if you don't like what you find a skill doing.  A sufficient number of upgradable magic powers and weapon skills keeps you moving from feral wolves to monolithic demons, with everything in between you'd expect from a fantasy game with any depth.  And this is one deep RPG.  Without trying, you're going to run into nine miles of lore.  If you don't like subtitles in your movies . . .85% - A couple small notes doesn't stop this RPGer from enjoying the RPG in this ARPG.

While Skyrim did the same thing, but Skyrim entices people to do its main quest, giving players thuums and others, doing the main quest in KoA was not quite rewarding.The Art/Graphic/Drawing is beautiful! it is so beautiful i dont need to mention other things to sugarcoat it. Not a highend graphic, but beautifully drawn with its cartoonish but serious pictures.Overall, 8.5/10 Recommending this to RPG players who loves character/skill progression and gameplay rather than highend graphics.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												I love this game a truly underestimated RPG that I discovered by just trying out the demo and a worthy purchase too because the full game has a lot to do with the extra DLC as well it definitely gives you over 100+ like most RPG's. But though the story can be a little confusing at times and especially some of the side quest stories it didn't stop me playing and just listening to everything, The world of KoA is very well thought out the forests at the start as vibrant and colourful to the plain barren deserts it's got just about everything, characters of the world are various from Faries to Thieves to Knights there's a lot of variety in the world. The voice acting is ok not the best but sometimes a game doesn't have to have the best voice acting to be enjoyable. But one thing that makes this game great is the combat system I found it fresh and seriously I never got bored in going into combat not once, because of the different style from swords, great swords, bows, daggers, faeblades and charkhams you can switch to many different styles on the fly because you can use 2 different weapons in battle for 1 button on your controller or mouse if you wish too. Fighting with a great sword to switch to a bow or faeblades to a Great sword is just cool in my book the game does has a stealth system so you can try a Stealth build if you wish in fact you can have a Stealth, Mage, Great Sword Tank or Sword build or a mixture of any it's that well thought out. Magic is also in the game you can use sceptres etc and have different kinds of magic like the usual fire, ice, thunder and poison to your weapons. Magic combat is ok it can be a little slow but again you can mix it up from a bow attack to ice or fire it's your choice to make it different, sceptres make magic a little better by adding charge moves in fact every weapon has unique moves sets that can be unlocked and you can add them into the attacks which makes it even more awesome when going into battle.The PC version does have a camera glitch were the FoV behind your character doesn't seem right in fact a little closer than it should be but there is a fix for it, I would recommend in getting the widescreen fixer mod,  this can be found in the guides section.I would also recommend playing the game on HARD mode from the start for a decent challenge it's not HARD but it gives a better experience.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning succeeds in some important ways, but in my opinion inevitably falls flat on its face for anyone who has played RPGs before. It really depends on why you play RPGs.KoA has a story that is at times refreshing and inspired, like with almost everything surrounding the Fae and their interactions with your character.  At other times, it is cliche and groan-inducing; just about anything having to do with the "Fate" concept in the game was at best predictable and at worst actually insulting in its lameness. The dialogue outside of story missions was also trite and felt written around a quest that had already been programmed into the game without a justification. This is extra egregious in a game that advertises how a famous fantasy author developed the story.It has an art style that screams in vivid colors and exaggerated animations, which I personally love as a longtime ex-player of World of Warcraft. However, if you're a fan of dark and gritty, you won't really find it here. And honestly, most problematically, the game has a huge difficulty curve problem: it's way too easy. By halfway through the game, I had broken it even on "hard" difficulty. My warrior character, built in an extremely obvious fashion (and avoiding the bugged Last Stand talent), was nigh-invincible and two-shotting everything except bosses, and that's before stacking over 100% damage and several layers of mitigation in potions. The fundamental axis of interaction in KoA is combat; when it becomes so trivial as to be boring, the game falls apart unless you were happy playing on easy anyway.Overall, I really, really wish I could recommend KoA. . . but I think for most people that would read a Steam review, it's just not going to be the right choice.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												So bad, but so good. The story, characters, and lore of the game are at best forgettable, and at worst utterly nonsensical and irritating. The questing is SO BORING, almost everything is copy pasted with SLIGHT changes in who you get to face smash. The enemy variety is quite low, I don't think there are more than 15 different enemies that fight uniquely outside of the bosses, most of the enemy variety are just skin changes with better stats. The NPCs are very bland and uninteresting. Also, I don't know if it was just me, dispelling was super bugged. I literally could not unlock spelled containers with the dispelling game because it was so bugged, I had to crank dispelling so I could auto-unlock them.On the other hand, the combat is SO GOOD. Admittedly, their archery doesn't make a lot of sense(THATS NOT HOW QUIVER WORK) but it is still really fun. You get magic, archery, and melee talent trees with different special abilities liberally sprinkled throughout (including Scorpion's signature move). The weapon augment system is kind of interesting, unless you get and finish the Legend of Dead Kel expansion and then you can just use your diplomat to farm the best augments and call it GG.Overall, I would only lightly recommend this if you are looking for a good hack and slash game.6/10 would Fate Shift that lone Boggart again.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2013
												KoA is going to be remembered not for the game, but for the complete collapse of the studio and the fallout from that. Which is a shame, because KoA is a decent game. Right away I'd like to point out, it's essentially Fable + MMO, all single player. Combat is generally quick and easy, quests are your standard fetch and kill fare, and the world is generic high fantasy. That said, it's also lovingly crafted and just flat out fun to play. Even on the hardest setting the game is easy, and as quick as I am to decry games being dumbed down, it can be incredibly satisfying at times to just tear through hordes of enemies. The skill system has some decent depth to it, as does the gear. The world is beautiful and the sound design is solid. The game can feel grindy, again, it's basically a single player MMO, but it's also fun if you're into that sort of thing. If nothing else, pick it up cheap for some awesome chakram action.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2012
												Sadly Kingdoms Of Amalur: Reckoning kinda flew under the radar for allot of people until the reviews started popping up. This was mainly because of the terrible advertising that made this brilliant game come across as mediocre. To put KOAR simply it’s a Fable-like MMO style action RPG with rich lore, unique creature designs, an interesting story & faction stories & a brilliant character development system that encourages multi-classing. A little FYI a Ranger type Rouge with defensive & buff Mage skills is pretty much unbeatable. It’s a very colourful game which is a nice change from the very dull & dark designs of most games today & if you are OCD about exploration & completing every side quest this is a game that’ll take quite a while to complete, I have not even finished it yet & as of this recommendation I have stacked up about 103 hours of game time. I recommend this to all fans of RPGs, exploration & a good story & I hope to see more from this franchise in time to come.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												Since I am bored at work And I'm tired of viewing screenshots from my friends, I decided to just review pretty much all the games I own ;D Yes... I am that bored...Alright then, Kingdoms of Amalur:Reckoning is an RPG single player only, while you play you will get the feeling that since the world is so expansive, filled with life and Npc's it should have had an online mode or it should have been a FREE Online game.To Describe this game in few words they would be: Immersive World, Quests, Magic, Fate, Medieval Style, Monsters and Hitting deers into space.Ok, with that being sed you can picture what the game is like!Let's start with the story, I was hyped about this game I remember seeing the trailers, how it had a guy who worked on the story of The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion, so the game showed great promise.The game starts with the Story of the World, what's going on and HOW YOU DIED in the War the people of Amalur fought.You wake up in a pile of decaying corpses and make your way up from underground to the Tower, you then realize that the tower is under attack by the Tuatha Dehon ( The bad guys) who are immortal.As you go along you discover that you were revived by the well of souls and hence forth you are sent from quest to quest to find out what's going on.The story telling in this game is average, the story itself is also average but the best by far in this game is the Combat System, fighting multiple units at once, with a fast paced system ranging from Bow, Hammer, Sword, Great Swords, Wands and the longer Wands XD. One of the best features in this game is The Fate power you get early on, which allows you to slow down Time and beat the crap out of your enemies and finish them off with an Epic and Awesome animations.Since you died and were revived, you can now change your fate and that of those around you. Example: By killing the Monster X they will not have the children X they were supposed to have. That enables to player to change the world around him.The Side quests are repetitive and meh, The Devs sed that to complete the game fully it would take about 300 hours. I object to that! I am 50 something hours in and and I have done every boring and repetitive side quest there is to do, and I'm almost done with it. :)There are also interesting and vast Faction Quest Lines with alternate endings but in the End they just get repetitive as the side quests do.I get the feeling that this game could have been more than what it was, too bad the company went broke from debt but there is still hope for the KOA Trade mark!! Also a pretty huge part in this game is that, IT IS TOO EASY!! you'll realize this like 2-3 hours in, you destroy everything in your way pretty much without dying. I can even challenge myself into Not even dying once while playing through this entire game.Thanks to the modding community there is a mod out there that makes the game harder to beat.You can also craft armor, The skill system is quite vast, and there should have been Mounts in this game, I got tired of walking after a while.And there you have it, my review for Kingdoms of Amalur:Reckoning if you are a person that loves RPG like I do you'll get over the fact that it's single player online and immerse yourself in the mythos like I did.

												There’s a game you probably didn’t play. It came out 2 years ago, it’s a genuine epic, a vast, elaborate RPG with a sprawling story and vast numbers of sidequests. It features superbly in-depth combat, has huge variety in character design and levelling, and lets you instantly wander from the main plot and explore its enormous world to your own entertainment. It’s Kingdoms Of Amalur: Reckoning. By John Walker

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												Big Huge Games’s recent multiplatform ARPG release Kingdoms of Amalur writes a pretty big check by boldly laying out the names of its creative team, which includes such nerd luminaries as Todd McFarlane (of Spider-Man and Spawn fame) and R.A. Salvatore (if you’ve never read a Salvatore book or heard of Drizzt Do’Urden, you may not actually be a geek)–a check which does not bounce.A number of narrative elements in this game are generic fantasy and CRPG tropes: the nameless hero with no memory of his past, the racial groups (blank-slate humans, noble elves, mysterious dark elves, and clever but clumsy and often scatterbrained gnomes), the world-imperiling threat that only your hero can defeat. It’s the way these things are packaged that makes the game better than the sum of its parts. You begin as a recently-deceased individual on a corpse pile and you quickly learn that you are the first and only success of a group of gnome scholars attempting to master the science of resurrecting the dead. Your “undead” status also has an additional benefit: in a world where all creatures are bound to a web of Fate and their lives and deaths are predestined, you have no written fate and you can influence the fates of others. Your recollection of your previous life is non-existent but two NPCs, a human fateweaver (a person who uses cards to “read” the fates of others) and former soldier named Agarth and a beautiful and cryptic Dokkalfar (dark-elven) rogue named Alyn Shir, guide you on a journey to assist the free peoples of Amalur in defeating the Tuatha, a race of immortals bent on destroying all mortal life with the aid of their new god, Tirnoch.Combat in KoA starts out quite Diablo-like, but once you invest some points in special attack skills with your weapon of choice, it gets much better. As shown in the image above, you have a primary weapon, mapped to the left mouse button, and a set of spells or special moves selected by using the number keys and triggered with the right mouse button. You also assign a secondary weapon and can rapidly switch between them using the mousewheel. Dodging is accomplished by using the WASD keys in conjunction with the spacebar. Weapons range from very fast melee (daggers and faeblades) to slow melee (greatswords) and ranged (longbow). Combining movement, weapon attacks, and spell-like abilities in a fluid way makes for a fast-paced and generally enjoyable experience. Probably the biggest issue with the system is that the game will automatically retarget the last enemy to strike your avatar, which can be a nuisance if you’re attacking a particular enemy (spellcaster or really tough opponent) on purpose.Levelling up grants you a bonus to health and mana pools, along with one point to allocate toward a skill as well as three points to invest in abilities. Skills include lockpicking, dispelling, stealth, persuasion,  detect hidden,  mercantile, blacksmithing, sagecraft,  and alchemy. The latter three skills are tied to the game’s crafting system, which I’ll discuss a bit later. Dispelling is essentially a kind of magical lockpicking. Both skills are linked to minigames that allow the player to open containers found throughout the gameworld, but lockpicking is much less useful as the minigame really requires some trial-and-error but nothing in the way of user skill. Personally, I never could get the hang of the ward-dispelling minigame so I tended to ignore warded chests (these have a violet glow). Detect hidden allows you to “find” more gold on the bodies of dead enemies and on rare occasions will provide you with additional dialogue options.Crafting is bog-standard for the genre, with potion-mixing (alchemy), gem creation for socketed equipment (sagecraft), and weapon- and armor-creation (blacksmithing). Having more skillpoints in the related areas allows the player to create better gear, gems, or potions. This is not the sort of thing I usually spend a lot of time fiddling with in my role-playing games, but I would definitely recommend blacksmithing over the other two skills on the basis of my playthrough. This is partly because the loot system is pretty awful. Aside from starting equipment, I used only a few different pieces or sets of armor and only five or six different weapons throughout the game. For the length of my roughly 70-hour playthrough, I encountered zero arms or armor with sockets that will accept the highest craftable tier of gems, making my investment of points in that skill rather meaningless. The equipment drops you find in containers and from looting corpses are very rarely better than what you are using; store inventories are also rarely worth purchasing, so the best gear you’ll find are quest rewards and items crafted from scratch (and for those you must invest in blacksmithing).Pathfinding is pretty easy, thanks to a useful minimap and world and local map screens. Your avatar’s level of detect hidden will determine what items besides NPCs and towns appear on the maps (including, curiously, enemies), and upgrading your detect hidden skill will allow you to see enemy facing directions, treasures, traps, and lorestones. Lorestones are KoA‘s collectibles, stone monuments with magically-recorded bits of lore about the area in which they are found; locating and activating all of the stones in a set provides you with a small bonus such as +4% health.Throughout the course of the game, you will acquire several personal houses which contain a handy “stash” chest that can hold 155 items. Having multiple houses is actually a bit pointless as the fast-travel system is sufficiently well-implemented that you can easily jump to your first acquired property at Canneroc from anywhere else on the map and back again with a few clicks.This brings us to the questing. Put simply Kingdoms of Amalur and Skyrim are the two games that had some people questioning whether there can indeed be too much of a good thing, like these people and this site. Playing through every side quest KoA has to offer and hunting down every lorestone in addition to the main quest will probably clock in around 90 – 100 hours. Almost every NPC you meet will have at least one quest for you to do for him/her, and while many are typical FedEx or “Kill X of Monster” quests, some are unique and interesting and all of them include well-written backstories. There are six different factions to complete quest chains for (I only did five) and these are very detailed and lengthy endeavors. Some critics have questioned how memorable the story is, but I suggest that this has more to do with the nigh-overwhelming number of side quests present in the game than any flaw in the writing of the main storyline.On the whole I think Big Huge’s first foray into the RPG arena is a successful one, and I would be interested in seeing whether the developer is going to push the series forward with more single-player entries before the inevitable MMO iteration appears on the market.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												20 hours on record now and not disapointed. If you like a RPG game with a deep lore, love maximising your char (even overpowered maybe), then this is your game.Pro:-This game rewards you if you tend to stay and upgrade a bit (sidequest, explore/exploit game mechanics) before going to the next area. Doing some research in the fighting mechanics will pay off, same for searching for clues how to maximise your char early on. -This game doesn't punish you for being intelligent and leaves the balance (and thus difficulty) in your hands.-Decent graphics.-Deep storyline. Troughout the world you get to know the lore even better with lorestones and sidequests.-Upgrade your char. A lot. With good (but not game changing) upgrades.-Change your character to another playstyle anytime you want. (This ability is very well integrated in the storyline: it is there for a reason. Thumbs up for the writers!)-Fast travel.-Many unique items. Item sets. All with unique abilities not found on equal 'normal' items.Con:-Content is repeated a lot. Especially the indoor environment build system is flawed.-Combat is a bit thin. Just get a big mana regen or health regen and change weapons often. On the contrary, don't get that regen / upgrade and you experience a steep difficulty increase.-Repeating sidequests. Fetch this, kill that.-Crafting is there but no need for it. Just buy/find another better item.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												I really wish Steam had a "maybe" recommendation, because this game fits into that. I usually give RPGs about 10 hours to get me hooked, and I gave this one 20 because I heard the story was great and compelling but the story didn't go anywhere during the 20 hours I played. If I hear "you have to put 40 in to like it" then I say go play an MMO if you're into that.Overall, the combat is fun. I really liked it, but that might be because you never actually get to use it. You get some new gear and upgrade a few skill points and you're 1-hitting anything your level. Bosses are challenging, until you go into the superpower mode and kill each and every one. Quests aren't very compelling and the talking goes on forever without much reason for me to care about anybody. Not only that but one of the DLC's storylines about giants, which I was interested in, had a glitch that prevented me from finishing it without restarting completely. Awesome.The graphics are cool and you know what, I wish this game had multiplayer. If it had 2 or even 4 player co-op, it would be awesome. I would have so much fun playing with other people, but the lack of enemies to kill, lack of cares I give, and lack of anything interesting in almost a day playing makes it where I don't feel happy recommending this game.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												A fairly unsung RPG in its own right, not sure what I haven't heard that much about it. Nabbed it, plus the DLC during a major sale, getting it all for 10$ though it's certainly worth the full price of admission as this will take ~40 hours or more of your time.The game feels like a mix of Fable and the earlier Bioware games such as Mass Effect, Jade Empire, and Knights of the Old republic, though it's a shinier variant of all of those. It has the aesthetic and music of Fable but with a Bioware-esque RPG mixture.It's not a complicated game to be sure. The dialog doesn't affect much of what you do and there are no companions to fiddle around with.I'd certainly recommend it, especially if you're a fan of all the other games listed and have played the rest of them to death. This will be refreshing.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												Played and completed the game twice. Yes, that's how much I loved it! A very underrated game indeed... Great gameplay with a really fun combat and leveling system. You don't always come across RPGs like this everytime. I would definitely recommend this game to RPG lovers any day and even if you're not into RPGs it would still be worth giving it a try. I'm sure you won't regret it.    Pros:> Gameplay is fun> Combat and leveling systems are pretty good> Story is pretty decent if not that great> Decent graphics and runnable on even low-spec PCs> Dialogs and character voices are good> Loads of quests and other side quests to complete so you don't have to worry about completing the game quickly   Cons (not major and might not even matter for some):> Because of the huge number of side quests and free farming of exp by killing enemies in the wild you level up pretty quickly and you will have a pretty much overpowered character after some time... so, people who are looking for a little challenge might be a little disappointed with that. But the combat is still fun none-the-less and you won't get bored easily.> You get to select what your character will say or do during decision-making events but your character doesn't have a voice of his own. (Like in games like The Elder Scrolls)Lastly, there's no such action as 'jump' in this game (Like in The Witcher games) so, if you want to maybe get down a cliff quickly you'll have to go to a specific spot on that cliff that lets you jump down from it. It isn't exactly a con because the game mechanics are designed that way. However, you do have actions like 'roll' and 'blink' (short distance teleportation) that allow you to dodge enemy attacks. And that's one of the reasons that makes the combat fun aside from the ton of spells and other cool abilities and combos you have access to.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												Fair warning: tall wall of text below.I think if KoA was released an year before it's actual appearance, this game would become way more popular. It was flattened by stronger contenders, such as Skyrim, and didn't get enough recognition. Which, in my opinion, is unfair. This game deserves some love, because it is really well made.The world is open and very large. It has many secrets to share. It's easy to get lost. But you don't get that "Bring me back" feeling, it is an experience - to explore new lands and watch out for new enemies and loot. NPCs are ranging from standart "good guys" and confusing, but adorable, midgets to psychos and evil mages with robes and whatever goes with typical villain appearance. Unfortunately, almost none of the are remarkable. You will often hear voice of the same person when speaking to NPCs in literally same exact location. Base models are quite often reused too. Slightly damages overall atmosphere of "everything new and unusual".Quests are fun. Sometimes. Boring "go-there-and-speak-to-this-person-then-speak-to-other-person" quests are rare, but you will eventually stumble upon those. But even they always come with a twist. Speak to these four persons and find out how to place them in a column, so they won't kill each other, please. Quests are more like little adventrues, that will take you to the unexplored dungeons and cryptic castles (most of which would look exactly the same for you, but don't bother). All of them have stories behind them, but they seem rather... irrelevant. You don't feel the impact of your actions. You just helped that man, who claims to be the wolf, turned into humanoid by evil fairies. Now he thanks you and bids farewell. You will never see him again. And soon enough you will forget about him. Really rarely you get to see what have you done to others. Game simply erases it form the memory. The only reminder of that will calmly sit in your quest book. Strikethrough.The combat on the other hand is developed amazingly. Strikes chain into beautiful combos, combos then develop into cascades of hits and then finishing blow. Rinse, repeat. Never mind that your character will do the same moves over and over. You will never get tired of them. There are tons of weapon types and all of them have their unique move sets. Not all of them will be unlocked at the beginning; it will take few levels and some skill points investments to unlock new attacks. Mixing them with generic weapon attacks will result in gorgeous sights and dead enemies. Charge the key and then... maelstrom of blades or magic envelops you. Truly amusing. You also can kill any NPC that you don't like, ransack a wardrobe only to find peasant's tunic in here, pickpocket someone for sweet cash. Of course it comes with punishment. Of course local guards will try to stop you. And then you have a choice to bribe them, run away or go to prison like a good person (and then escape one moment later, brutally murdering everyone who stands on your way). Game doesn't stop you from being bad guy. You have your own path to follow, there is no set road. And I like it. And some quests actually reward that. So prepare your quick fingers, as a lot of stuff will stick to them quite soon.Graphics are what you expect from 2011 game. Yes. they are not great, yes, they are cartoonish. But then you see a landscape and you finger automatically reaches the F12 button. Not always you will get breathtaking views, but when you do, you will be pleased. Architecture also deserves special mention. Sometimes reminds me of Warcraft, sometimes of Oblivion, other times feels like you were thrown into Witcher. There are many wonderful places, some of them will make you spend time simply staring on puzzling ornament on a wall, while you're being pursued by swarm of spiders. When it comes to NPCs. Most of them are bricky and not looking like someone who can breathe. But on the other hand, when you get used to it, you will skip this part and go straight sor details. And some persons you'll meet look really great. Maybe it's haircut, tattoos or eyes, or even mix of three at the same time, they catch your attention with their features.I enjoyed this game. My only real complaint is that inventory is so small. Picking up everything and the selling it to vendor anyway is, like, my favourite way to play RPG. But seriously, if you want to create your own character and be unbound, be yourself basically; you are not becoming sick after seeing "video-game graphics" and you are not playing any other RPG for some reason - you will enjoy it. The price is relatively low as well, on a sale it becomes nearly free. And good luck, Child of Dust.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
It's a damn shame 38 studios isn't a thing anymore tl;dr Hack&Slash RPG that is 100% worth your money if you want a time sink and a decent story set in a visually outstanding world. Stumbled upon this gem a while back. Fantastic time sink for anyone looking to lose hours of their day in a sytlistically dissimilar game.It's a Hack&Slash RPG. This means that for those who like to fawn over the mechanics of combat in other RPGs, you may find some issues with this game. After a few hours, repitition does rear its' head if you only tend to play one type of the 3 main RPG classes (Spells and pointy hat, quick with a small stick and slow with a big stick).That being said, the game rewards you immensely for spending skill points in all of the 3 main skill trees and usingthe varied types of weapons. Some of the attacks you can pull off with well timed spells after ranged/melee combos are simply outstanding.Story doesn't usually rank highly on my list of things I think NEED to be good for a game to be good but it certainly helps, especially in an RPG. The main quest in Reckoning will send you all over the place in stages, typical to any modern fantasy title. It takes you on a monumental adventure, eventually taking on an enemy no one had a damn clue existed and saving the day etc. good stuff all around.It's in my personal opinion that ending was a bit weak and that it lets down the story as a whole. Rather than bundle up everything, it sort of hangs loose. This may have been due to a desire to create a sequel.Nitpicking for those super into game mechanics i.e. CONS GO HEREThe world itself looks outstanding, however the only real issue I had with this entire game was the lack of ANY major verticality. The world is by no means planar, but the only transition between up, middle and down was if you interacted with the world to perform a jump into a roll landing from up above OR the world slopes down/up to meet the next area. Even if the height difference is an inch, you can't simply step up to that height. While released in 2012, the game has aged fairly well. Would absolutely recommend if it comes up in your Summer Steam sale or a normal purchase if you're simply looking for a solid game.

												An enjoyable, 3rd person, action RPG.+ The voice actors did a good job.+ The writers did even better - NPC dialogues are wonderful. Metaphores, philosophy of life/death cycle, contemplation.+ Story idea is refreshing, it is as if there is a static story from a book, but then the strange element or "you" is thrown in it. And, maybe you are not the only "dynamic" power in the book's story...+ Nice combat with easy controls, with a bit of playing around you can combo things up.+ Big game world, playthrough can be lengthy if you like to sidetrack.- The world might seem a bit MMO-ish (but that is only because of our perception of things). Good part is, nobody can stop you from running to some dangerous areas of the game right from the start.- Too much eye candy - turn off post processing and enjoy the game.~ If you are a person that skips every NPC dialogue and "rushes", you will find the game dull.~ Recommended to play on Hard.

Posted: December 29, 2016
												Not a great rpg but also not a bad one. Runs smoother than any game I've ever owned and the combat is fun but the game does quickly get very repetitive. I would play it more but it just got so old and boring I couldn't stand to finish it. It is hard to pinpoint why it is so boring, it just is. Probably mainly because of the combat getting old fast.The baseball player Curt Schilling who I saw play quite often when I was younger financed the company that made this game and this was the only game they made. They ended up going bankrupt and shutting down after not being able to pay back loans to the state of Rhode Island. Too bad for him they couldn't have had a lot more polish on this game.Game has good graphics which along with combat are its high points. I would not exactly say the graphics are great because they are not, and are not bad either, just colorful and pretty. Weapons are cool and the spells/skills look great, however few skills there are, and enemies are varied and cool also. For sure worth a look if you want a decent RPG. If you want crack, heroin, and a BJ/HJ combo, talk to Josh Holmes' sister. She has spent more time on her back than a mattress salesman with alcoholism and narcolepsy.6.5/10

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												I'm not much of one for writing reviews; I don't do it often, and have no practice at it. But, what I can say here, is that for years I've been looking for a game that's centered primarily, if not wholly, around Celtic mythology, rather than generic European medieval fantasy or feudal Asian mythology. This game delivered, moreso than I could have ever thought a game could. Why there haven't been more games featuring such strong Celtic themes is beyond me, but Kingdoms of Amalur: Recokoning showed that it can be done, and done very well. I was definitely impressed with the story of the game.As far as gameplay, things were pretty good. Combat and controls felt better with a gamepad than mouse and keyboard, but that's never been a dealbreaker for me. I feel there could have been more done with combos and chaining attacks, because combat felt a little static after awhile, but it wasn't awful. Most quests(but not all; here's looking at you, Til's Collection) were interesting and often felt like an interesting task, rather than a chore to do for XP. The main quest line especially was fun, interesting, and kept me pulled in to the game. Factions you could join in the game I felt were pretty mediocre, and are your generic warriors, mages, and rogues factions. Their quests were fun, but I never really felt like my character truely belonged to the faction upon joining. The one major downside I felt in the game was gear drops. Almost always, what you can craft at each level was better than anything you could find, even rare named pieces or sets. As for the DLC, Teeth of Narros had a fun main story line, but for the most part it felt drawn out and monotonous. The side quests were pretty boring, and involved a lot of backtracking. Legend of Dead Kell was much better, and felt more involved.One more note: This game is LONG. And I really mean long, especially if you are a completionist and want to do all of the side quests.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
It's definitely a game worth buying, but sadly it has couple of big flaws in it.Well, firstly the good things;+ It has a pretty interensting storyline, you can get kinda lost and bored at some point, but it's still OK.+ The combat system is flawless, THE BEST I've had in any RPG ever. + Very cool skillset that you can acquire as you level up, especially the sorcery skills look absolutely amazing. Basically there's 3 different trees that you can choose; Finesse, Might and Sorcery, but you can actually also combine these together to go with a hybrid build as for example Finesse/Sorcery and get skills from both trees.+ TONS of quests to do, I can take a guess that it takes about 150+ hours to run through them all?+ A lot of unique weapons and armor sets, always keeps you looting everything throughout the whole game.+ It has the perfect open world, it's large and free, but still it doesn't take half a year to travel trough.+ Decent amount of different enemies, but this also has it flaws.+ Stealth is an (overpowered) option.+ Crafting, Sagecrafting, Alchemy.+ Nice graphics and overall visuals.+ Very enjoyable DLC.As for the negative ones, there is a couple of them;- The game has a lot of bugs and glitches, and couple of them are absolutely game breaking. The most infamous one is probably the ''running bug'' which usually occurs after around 60+ hours of gameplay. It freezes the game always when you are running forward for about a second, every 5 seconds or so. In my understanding there's no way to fix this bug apart from starting a fresh game.- I don't like the level lock in this game, it ruins some areas for you if you enter them too early in the game. Basically it means, if you enter a new area for example at level 5, the enemies and loot in that area will remain at level 5 for the entire game. That makes you always be very careful about progressing through the quests and it's really annoying.- After a while when you get most of the skills in your build of choosing, the game becomes VERY easy. Most of the enemies won't stand a chance against you, few minibosses and bosses excluded.If you combine potions, overpowered gear and ''Fateshift'', you will basically become the supreme God of death and destruction, and just absolutely wreck everything on sight. If you want the most out of your experince in this game, avoid using potions and fateshift.- And a little bit more about the overpowered things, the crafting in this game is kinda broken.It's relatively easy to gather some beastly crafting materials, and after you get your skills high enough to do mastercrafted gear, they are just absolutely disgustingly good. Better than any of the armor sets or unique weapons. I personally avoid crafting just because of that, and suggest you to do the same.- Very repetitive dungeons. A lot of them seem to share the same layout, just with different monsters and quests.- This isn't that big of a flaw, but anyways, some of the bosses also share the same models. For example the ''Widow'' is just another fae with different colors, which was very dissapointing.- Backpack size is way too small for all the drops in the game, items stack in sizes of 10, which also limits the items you can take with you.- I'm actually not quite sure about this, but I think the max level of weapons are like 12-13 or something like that? It's kinda weird since the level cap is at around 40, but you can't actually get any weapons at that level.Overall though, I can recommend to buy this game if you already haven't since it's content will be worth the 20€ + DLC. Very unique combat system and all the other things combined makes this a solid 8/10, despite some of it's flaws.

												First, you CAN NOT play this with an Xbox One Controller. In the current era of changes by MS, cross your fingers with any game. Some games only runs on Win 10, some only on Win 7 64 bit, some are incompatible with Win 7 64 and now a new issue regarding controller conflict. I hate change, because big business does not care about you.  I do wish Steam would at least add a warning o their store page. Thank you internet. Shame on Steam.Game is a well written RPG with good graphics. Each "town folk" has something different to say and, again, even their voice acting is well done.  Side quests are not just generic "fetch this for me" quests and I will pay you.  Armor is useful and well designed right from the beginning.  Weapons come in some fun and useful variations beyond longsword and bows. This is one of the few games for which I will be buying the DLC. Uplay is always a hinderance and general pain, but the game is worth the pains.

Posted: March 26
												This is close enough to Fable to make me want to play it, but far enough away with enough minor issues in just the right places to make it annoying. It's so close to being a great game, but it just isn't. This game was written by my favorite writer: R.A. Salvatore.This game's art was directed by my favorite comic book arist: Todd Macfarlane.One of the creator's of Morrowind's engine was responsible for this game's engine, and I loved Morrowind.I wanted this to succeed more than anyone, but it fell flat. It has the repetition of an MMO, but without the other players to fill that void. The combat is decent, but not good enough to make up for the repetition. The characters are mildly interesting, and the voice acting is good. I would even say the graphics hold up even in 2017 because of the art style they chose. I just keep waiting for the point where I get immersed in the world, and it just isn't happening.

number of helpful: 36 of 71 people (51%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												I spent hours playing this game, hoping at some point that it would get better. Sadly it did not.The action in the game is quite good, one as to be on their toes when fighting multiple monters/enemies. But sadly it gets repetitive.The monsters that you encounter in beginning will be the same ones that you encounter at the very end. All they do is call them different things. Example: "Weak boggart in the beginning versus Strong Boggart" in the end. The characters are forgettable, some of them really even have no business being in the plot. The quests are fun at first but then they just devolve into "go here, kill 5 wolves, come back" The plot is interesting and seemingly original at first but by half way into the story it just turns into total garbage. The main antagonist isn't even that interesting. His dialogue is terrible, one dimensional, and repetitive. The voice acting of him is done by what sounds like a sick old man.And everyone talks to you as if you have NO POWER at all, despite the constant acts you carry out that continually prove that you have god like powers.I literally killed a demon the size of a 6 story building in one part of the story, only for the antagonist to talk to me afterwards as if I was some weak puppy that had the strength of an ant. Even one of your friends in the story acts like she could beat you down any time she wants, even though you constantly kick 500 times more butt than she ever could.The endgame is no fun, not even a challenge. Once you get past a certain level and can make your own gear, you pretty much sleep walk through the late stages of the game.I did my first playthrough of this game on HARD and I killed the final boss in 4 hits... yes you read that right, 4 hits. The difficulty on this game is a total joke.I would only recommend this game for kids, if you are a seasoned RPG or action game players, this will be a serious let down.

Cons;-Areas are kinda empty. There are so many vast (and beautiful) areas without life except harmful creatures. -Vanilla gloomy graphics. -Limitations in areas. (It is not as open-world.)-Missing mounts!

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												Pour ceux et celles qui veulent un jeu semblable à Skyrim, je vous le recommande fortement!Voici ma comparaison avec le jeu Skyrim.Ce qui semblable à Skyrim:-Le jeu est traduit en français.-Il est completement en monde ouvert, par cela je veux dire que vous pouvez voyagez librement à travers d'Amalur, de plus, vous pouvez continuer a jouer même si vous avez complété la quête principale. Comme dans Skyrim.- L'histoire est intriguante.- Style de jeu Médiéval fantaisie- Système de compétances semblable à Skyrim, pour certain point meilleurs, pour d'autre, différents. Ce qui est meilleur que Skyrim.- Variété de style de combat.- Les graphismes sont plus féériques que Skyrim. Ils sont bien fait.Ce qui est différent de Skyrim:-Dans Skyrim, vous pouvez ramasser toute sorte de chose utiles ou inutiles, dans Amalur, non. Vous devez détruire des boîtes ou ouvrir des coffres pour collecter des objets. Si l'enemi que vous tuer avais une épée en acier, lorsque vous allez looter son cadavre, vous optiendrez des objets fort différents voir même rien du tout. Les horaires des PNJs aurraient pu être plus élaborée et réaliste comme dans Skyrim. (Exemple, un garde reste au meme poste 24h/24...Je pourais en dire plus, mais pour résumer, je recommande fortement ce jeu. Il est très immersif et très bien optimisé, je peux y jouer aver mon ordinateur portable Toshiba.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												This game is a third person RPG that truly resembles RPGs around the Era of Oblivion and to be honest if it had been released then it would of made millions. But the timing was not right.It seemed unfinished with only one model for each weapon type and barely any difference in armour.The combat was interesting with different specialised weapons to use with each class. The action bar worked especially well for it. The main mechanic that the combat was all based around was a sort of slow mo that seems to make you do extra damage whilst giving you the ability to do very impressive final hits or death blows. The class systems truly do make a difference and seem to be the biggest decision you will make in the game. The special attacks and weapons were the high point as well as the blends of the difference classes. (I played a Rogue/Mage)The world reminded me a lot of the original Fable with the same reputation system and choice system. But your decisions didnt really feel like they were making a difference... Except for maybe a few larger points.The artwork once again reminded me of Fable but the render distance for me was an issue. The world was always fun to explore with secrets hidden everywhere and new towns and houses to explore. The questing was good and it didnt make you feel like you were grinding like some other RPGs. There are hundreds of side quests to spend your time on until you decide whether you want to buy the DLC or not.Overall I loved this game even though it had its issues.. If it had a little more time and maybe more funding? It could of been amazing but this is where it was at, I have heard that modding the game can fix a lot of the issues I had with it such as the weapon models.I rate it a 7/10

												Pros: Love this game. The world and characters are interesting and well realized. (but you don't have to pay close attention if you don't want to)Combat is fun, and challenging on the hard setting.  Great graphics consideringItems are fairly interestingThe abilities are coolThe amount I enjoyed this game. Started a 20 hour character on my friends PS3, he accidently deleted it.  Started another character on my PS3, leveled him a little past the orginal character, and stopped playing my PS3 in favour of PC, RESTARTED AGAIN, and played the whole story through. ConsI played a rogue(with a TINY bit of mage), seems like good daggers are few and far between, and stealth isn't very useful with boss fights...Travelling is a pain, think Vanilla WoW with no mountsQuests are repeatative. Had to put the game down for a month or two at a time, and come back. Did that about 4 times.Levels are a grind at 25+ I highly recommend this game to any RPG fan with a bit of time.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												 This is the case of a game that could have been more and falters to stumble to a unremarkable finish. The concept of the game allows for free class shifting allowing a wide range of combat playstyles to be changed often but the quest themselves are fairly rotuine for the fantasy genre.  It is however my personal feeling that where the game fails most is in providing an endgame to care about. The climatic battle of the game is comes well before the final boss who is introduced in name but fails to engage as a plot device and dies mere seconds after appearing, the final zones provide nothing that you  haven't seen dozens of times since due to poor level pacing you most likely hit max level several zones ago. But you''ll notice I still recommend the game, despite these drawbacks its still fun to play if taking for what it offers. Picked up on sale it will easily provide enough to make is worth the price and that's really all a game needs to do.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning™, when I first read about this game before it's release it claimed it would be a Elder Scrolls killer but as some people many know that it really wasn't that case.The game has good and bad qualities about it.Lets start with the story, the story isn't a strong point for this game and is pretty generic for an RPG and after you play through it once, playing through it again is something you just seem to want to avoid, though the concept for the story itself was pretty good.The Combat. The Combat is this game is in my opinion better then Skyrims, in Skyrim I just felt like I was just whaling on people like some untrained warrior, but in Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning™ it felt a lot more smooth and just flowed a lot better and some enemies I needed to learns some of there moves and time my dodges right to either take no damage or at least not suffer a large blow. It is true that after a few hours the combat can become a bit or even entirely boring as you will have a solid tactic to spam with crowds, bosses or big creatures.'Fateshift' is basically a super, nothing can really stand up to you when your in this form and the final kill animation is great and the fact that there are many make it so it doesn't become boring that quickly, though I found that in my later level Fateshift was something I always had and clould eaily build up but I never used it as I found no enemy challenging.The World. Kingdom of Amalurs world is extremly nice with a good colour palette, though the game is a bit aged right now it's still a great world to explore and just look at. The characters were very well Voice acted and it was nice to have everyone in the game have a voice instead of just text, well I say everyone what I mean is everyone but the character you play as, he/she is a silent protagonist and it really seemed to kill some of the games immutation as people who you talk to seem to express something to whats going on and to what you just said while you just seem to stand there with a blank expression of nothingness on your face not give a sh*t.The Classes. Now I enjoyed the class system in this game, I found it to be better then Skyrims as you can't get to the point were you can level up every tree (I'm talking without Mods) you have to choose to either focus on one tree and become a Warlord, Nightblade or Archmage which means you master all the weapon and gain the top tier abilities.You could go into two trees and become either a Blademaster, Shadowcaster or Champion with these sorts of builds you don't reach the top of either trees which means you don't gain the top tier abilities.You could go into all three trees at once and become a Jack of all traits person or as it's named Universalist, which means you're gonna be getting mostly the basics of all the trees.The classes themselves some with different effects and stats themselfs, to boost damamge or Mana regan per second also the Shadowcaster class had a poison blink ability that replace dodge.The class system in this game makes choosing a class to strive to a did more hard as you know how far you will go in the trees.Side Quests. Side quests could be both good and bad, in some you just be fetching something and in other you would be exploring caves and dungeons, so overall I find the side quests to be like every other RPG a combination of good and bad, with some being fun and interesting and other being dull and pointless all together.Crafting. I only went into Blacksmithing and made some of my best gear it was simple to do and rewarding still, but for the other crafting options in the game well I'm not gonna say anything about them, not because there bad but because as I said I didn't go into them, I soley did Blacksmithing.The DLC. You have 2 DLC's not including the Weapons pack, these DLC's are Teeth of Naros and The Legend of Dead Kel, both DLC's never seem to improve the story but are good for higher level players to get good gear and fight enemies the same level and sometimes even higher.Teeth of Naros. Honestly I didn't enjoy this one to much, the combat was sameish and the story was just something I didn't pay much attation to as it didn't interest me.I'd give this DLC a 5/10 as the story isn't so great that it kept my attention but the fights were good as you faced a new selection of enemies and got both good armor and gear from it, but when I finished the story line I was gone from that DLC area.The Legend of Dead Kel. I enjoyed this DLC more the Naros, the story was somewhat interesting and the combat was good aswell and with the addition with the Keep that you get which honestly was great at first, after a while you start to feel a bit detatched from it as the pets you get and raise just give you a stat increase and then are in a corner of the Keep, you don't get to take them outside the keep nor can you have them walking with you in the Keep. You also get a Scavenger who will find people in ship wrecks who will become something in your keep and get you closer to the end of the Keeps quest line, but after you find everyone you'll send him out sleep for 24 hours and get items and then repeat and if he says he lost the bag you'll be dealing with a group of bandits you can easily cut through to get Items to sell, gets boring after 2-3 trips there. There are other people who do different things but you'll find that the only person you'll use in the end after you've done everything in the keep is the Scavenger guy because he gets you items to sell and make more money that you don't need because you've got the best gear but because why not.I'd give this DLC a 6/10 the story is somewhat good and the combat is still good but the Keep seems to both be it's strongest and weakest point as when you first get it you;ve got lots of things to do but it runs out in the blink of an eye and the Keep is just something that you have.Overall I enjoyed the game, it had it's flaws and wasn't close to being an Elder scrolls killer8/10 Rating from me

												Great Gem of a Game, especially if you get it on Sale. I actually like this better than Skyrim, which is somewhat similar. Sure, there are a few kinks, you'll have to live with:- Too easy (seriously, this is not Dark Souls, and the only Boss so far which took more than afew attempts for me was the Maiden of Windemere). Strongly recommend to play this on "Hard"...- Somewhat limited amount of different enemy models, which get repeated with increased stats later in the game. Could have used a few more different monsters- Shop system somewhat broken - even though you get tons of great stuff dropped, I would now and then like to buy that specific item from a shop - but they are just to damn expensive, considering you'd also need your cash for trainers - Annoying inventory bugs, especially with Dead Kel DLC, where you can't get rid of items from closed questsOther than that I'd rate it 9 out of 10. Highlight is the great variety of missions and quests, mostly well scripted, combined with a well structured quest system. I also pretty much like the graphics/looks, which - especially for outdoors/Landscapes - are somewhat less grimy than e.g. Skyrim.

												Recommended, as long as you run Widescreen Fixer to give yourself a more zoomed-out camera / wider field of view. The default is waaaay to close for my comfort. If you're looking for an RPG where choices matter, look elsewhere - I completed nearly all the available quests, and I can count on one hand the number of them where you actually had to make any decisions about how to complete them, and maybe... one? where there was any sort of fail state if you picked the wrong dialogue options. If you just want something where you can kill dudes while traversing the overworld and dungeons, perhaps while listing to podcasts or otherwise multitasking, this is it.

												Very good roleplaying game. Graphics and effects are colourists, with nice locations and creatures as well. The mechanics are little clumsy, and has initial problems of control configuration. Huge map based on zones. More than 200 missions of all kinds, with few bugs, many dialogues are repetitive or useless. Is easy, or not fine leveled: passed 75% of game the player can reach max level and be rich, but can reconfigure his skills anytime. Included a stealth system and a really usefull crafting system. Expansions are big and essentials. Strongly recomended for newbies of the genre.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												Pour ceux et celles qui veulent un jeu semblable à Skyrim, je vous le recommande fortement!Voici ma comparaison avec le jeu Skyrim.Ce qui semblable à Skyrim:-Le jeu est traduit en français.-Il est completement en monde ouvert, par cela je veux dire que vous pouvez voyagez librement à travers d'Amalur, de plus, vous pouvez continuer a jouer même si vous avez complété la quête principale. Comme dans Skyrim.- L'histoire est intriguante.- Style de jeu Médiéval fantaisie- Système de compétances semblable à Skyrim, pour certain point meilleurs, pour d'autre, différents. Ce qui est meilleur que Skyrim.- Variété de style de combat.- Les graphismes sont plus féériques que Skyrim. Ils sont bien fait.Ce qui est différent de Skyrim:-Dans Skyrim, vous pouvez ramasser toute sorte de chose utiles ou inutiles, dans Amalur, non. Vous devez détruire des boîtes ou ouvrir des coffres pour collecter des objets. Si l'enemi que vous tuer avais une épée en acier, lorsque vous allez looter son cadavre, vous optiendrez des objets fort différents voir même rien du tout. Les horaires des PNJs aurraient pu être plus élaborée et réaliste comme dans Skyrim. (Exemple, un garde reste au meme poste 24h/24...Je pourais en dire plus, mais pour résumer, je recommande fortement ce jeu. Il est très immersif et très bien optimisé, je peux y jouer aver mon ordinateur portable Toshiba.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Can't recommend this game highly enough ... and at 75% off, it stretches your entertainment dollar beyond all reason. Has been sitting on my wishlist for a couple of years now, jumped on it the first day of the Summer sale and couldn't be happier I did. If you're an RPG fan definitely grab it. Has a much better combat system than Skyrim, expansive areas to explore, simple but highly useful crafting system, and tons of loot. The graphics are fine, nothing to write home about even back when it was made. I'm about 75% through the game and the story is fine and detailed with a good amount of lore. definitely merited a sequel and with the proper amount of money pumped in, could have rivaled the Elder Scrolls --- except with much better combat. Lastly, since you can reset all your abilities and points easily during the game, you can play any way you like whenever you like ... tired of being a Mage and using Staves or scepters ... reset ... be a stealthy rogue, or a two hander or a sword and board or ... 9/10, if I had known how good the game is, I would easily consider buying it at full price without feeling cheated in any way.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Absolutely awesome game! The combat is so good and satisfying that you dont even mind grinding for fun. It works very good and it is fluid and responsive with mouse and keyboard. The developers did a very good job porting this to PCs. If you liked Fable, this is better in my opinion. Anyway, this game is a MUST HAVE for any RPG or Action fan. Even hack'n' slash fans will enjoy the combat. It has combos,spells, two weapon sets, slowing time and fatalities (finishing enemies in style). The game offers easy, normal and hard mode available from the start. If you have bought the Weapon and Armors DLC (buy it as a complete pack, it is so worth it !!!) you will get purple weapons and gold armors at almost the begining of the game, making the game so much easy (Casual Mode only I guess). Those who want challenge can still folow the traditional way and earn and craft their own. The story and quests are fully voiced only your character is silent. It feels like a downside but it is not very important in my opimion. You dont have a quest log on your screen - which is good - but the minimap shows the diresctions you need to go to. Oh!!  and there is fast travel to discovered locations directly from the world map. This is great for returnig to receive rewards.it is worth the full price tag, but now on sales, it is like a gift from gods LOL

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Back when this came out I played the demo and bought it for 360. Played the holy hell out of it. Just picked it up on sale and am repeating. The game is fantastic. Seriously. Such a shame that it will exist as a one off and no follow ups will take place. The world is interesting, rich, and gorgeous. On a meta level the game reminds me of playing an mmo solo but with combat that takes certian elements from the arkham games while adding in a nice dash of strategy to how you go about things. On lower difficulty your build wont matter a whole lot but increase the difficulty and you can find yourself in a bit of a pickle so pay attention to what loot you are getting and how it factors into your way of playing. If I had my play times from the 360 version I would reckon I have spent 200+ hours on the base game and its expansions - which you should also buy because they are every bit as good as the base game. My only real issue is that there is not more DLC. I need more of this game. Strage situation seeing as EA published it and they would milk the♥♥♥♥♥♥off a tic tac toe clone if they could. Strange times.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												Picked this one up on sale back in June for $10 (game + all DLC). If you're looking for blockbuster material, you won't find it here.The story is excellent and the lore to back it up equally great. So if story driven stuff is what you're after, you should enjoy this. For me, it was the sole reason I went ahead with playing it to completion.The main problem is the graphics and gameplay drag it down badly. I've been talking about it in passing as though it was a 2006 release because frankly it doesn't look as nice as Oblivion, then just noticed it has a 2012 date on it. OK.Gameplay is very very MMO-ey, and as it turns out there's a reason for that. It was supposed to be one at one point but got downscaled into a single player game. So yo have lots and lots of combat action and loot grinding going on.The two DLCs were actually much better than the main game too, though that could be because I'm partial to content that gives me castles and keeps to build and upgrade :POver all, worth it when it's on sale. I'd not pay the full $40 for the whole collection though.

												Id like to go on record as saying that I am a picky MO FO when it comes to RPs... That said... This is one fo the best RPGs I have played in the last 20 years, graphics not withstanding. It is masively expansive, every time I thought the game was over it just kept rolling out more story and all of the stories hold their own then come together to form an even larger story! I have spent many hours just getting to lvl 20 and I feel like I have been through wave after wave of build up then grind. I love the look of it as well as the support characters (some of who make me want to slap the poo out of them, others make me want to take them behind closed doors...), I give this game a 9.5/10 It loses .5 points because the merchant buy/sell menu makes you wade through ALL of your gear to sell a few things that you dont want (Including the crafting gear which if you are a collecter can be MASSIVE). The merchant menu should be more like the menu in your houses storage box, now that would be superb! A must buy for any real RPer out there! And dont forget the DLC!

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												WARNING: SPOILERS MAYBETo be honest, this game is bad, despite good combat system and tons of content. It's just failing to hold you to play. It's okay in short bursts. It's a pretty nice action rpg, but killing thousands and thousands of same enemies (which can take a lot of time, esp near the end, because game just throwing dozens of tuatha elite troops, and trolls at you)Combat system has it's own flaws too. It becomes repetitive as heck after a while, because you usually stick to two weapons, which suits you (in my case - chakrams and greatsword). It's still entertaining to watch, but if there a lot of enemies there is a great chance that character will be stunlocked.Quests are pretty bore too. It's either fetch-quests or kill quests, with very very rare puzzles. And tasks - WoW dailies. Bring me ten bear legs to get a bag of gold. Rince and repeat.Factions - kinda good. Travelers and warsworn are pretty good, nothing original, but still pretty good. Backstabbing, heroic deeds all that kind of stuff. Kinda wish there were more epic fight and moments like in main story. Houses of ballads and sorrows, and mage's guild - good story, but notthing incredible. I even can't decide whether i want to be the bad guy or the good guy.Overall i would call this game average at most. Some good ideas, decent fighting system, tons of not so interesting content, but extremely repetitive.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25
												This game crashes on my computer so I don't play it much here, but I've played a few dozen hours on an Xbox.I have never played an RPG with combat this good.  It's so smooth, but still challenging, and you feel like a badass.  Almost every enemy feels like a really easy Dark Souls boss; they all have unique movesets that you have to learn to time your attacks around.  Your own attacks are actually dynamic.  You know how in the Elder Scrolls games, you're totally helpless when you're in mid-swing and melee combat is very straightforward, with almost no variety?  The devs of KoA were like "screw that, let's make combat FUN".  1: you have a dodge roll (a basic requirement for any melee combat game).  2: Up until the last two hits of your combo, you're completely free to move around and cancel your attacks mid-swing.  This is incredible for when you're wailing on a troll and a wolf comes up to bite your♥♥♥♥♥-you can dodge out of there without waiting for your movement to finish.  This makes the game feel much faster-paced.  Being outnumbered is a problem, sure, but you're quick enough to deal with it.  The game is pretty short, though, and there isn't much end-game content.  My friend and I chugged through it in maybe ten or twelve hours.  After that, all you can really do is re-run stuff you've already done.  The combat is so fun that it doesn't really matter, though.

												This is one of the most underrated games ever made. It had the misfortune of releasing just a couple months after skyrim did and I think that is the biggest reason that it was unable to succeed.The combat in this feels great. Switching between your ranged weapon, melee and magic feels smooth and fluid. You definitely have an advantage over the enemies in 1v1 situations but at the same time can get overwhelmed by large number if you're not careful.If you are looking for a RPG to pass your time this is for you.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												This is a fantastic game that had a lot of potential as an MMO. It was intended to be an introduction to a new MMO world, so the game is packed with lore around every corner. If you like lore, this game is for you. If you don't like reading, like all the books in the Elder Scrolls Series, you're in luck because this game gives you the lore through "lorestones." All you have to do is click on the lorestone, and listen to a narrator read off the stone while you continue to aventure. If you happen to miss something they said, you can aways pause the game and listen again through the menu. Each area has a set of 5-7 stones, and listening to all of them gives you a permanent bonus of some kind.The controls are fluid and easy, You have two weapon sets, which you can quickly change between, and spells are set to the number keys 1-9, and cast through the right mouse button. The only problem with the controls is that there is virtually no camera control. You can move the camera around your character, but you cannot zoom in or out which is a huge problem. There are mods to fix this, or you can get used to it if you ignore it long enough.The only other major problem is the leveling system. It's quick and doesn't drag, which seemed good at first, but about halfway through the game it is easy to over-level above the level range of the areas and quickly get boring trying to do quests that extremely underleveled. To avoid this problem simply don't use any gear that gives an XP bonus, and don't get the bonus XP for kills in "reckoning mode."Other than the camera and the experience system, the game is visually stunning and a great play. The story is interesting, which is why i didn't mention much of it here. To sum it up you have died and been brought back to life, which means you are no longer bound by fate. Not being bound by fate means that every life you save should have died, and every life you kill shouldn't have been killed. Your existence can turn the tides of wars long forseen by the gods to end a certain way, and certain powers in the world want to use you to their greater aim.
